translation: In the lotus leaf, recently fallen, with six legs spread out, trembling, and with restless gaze, here indeed are two clusters of horns, still and silent.

sloka: agūḍhahāsasphuṭadantakesaraṃ mukhaṃ svidetadvikasannu paṅkajam | iti pralīnāṃ nalinīvane sakhīṃ vidāṃbabhūvuḥ sucireṇa yoṣitaḥ ||36||
translation: The woman, who in the grove of lotuses, has been seen by her friends with a clearly revealed, unhidden, stainless, and chiseled smile on her face, like a fully bloomed lotus flower, becomes the most distinguished among them.

sloka: priyeṇa saṃgrathya vipakṣasaṃnidhāvupāhitāṃ vakṣasi pīvarastane | srajaṃ na kācidvijahau jalāvilāṃ vasanti hi premṇi guṇā na vastuni||
translation: Embracing closely with affection, having placed the opposing army in front, on the broad chest, no warrior abandoned [the thought of] adorning [with] a garland; for, in love, qualities reside in [their] objects, not in [the mere] words.

sloka: asaṃśayaṃ nyastamupāntaraktatāṃ yadeva roddhuṃ ramaṇībhirañjanam | hṛte'pi tasminsalilena śuklatāṃ nirāsa rāgo nayaneṣu na śriyam 38||
translation: Undoubtedly discarded is the internal darkness when that collyrium-like attraction, even if removed from the water, does not lose its whiteness in the eyes, nor does desire arise, and there is absence of beauty.

sloka: dyutiṃ vahantī vanitāvataṃsakā hṛtāḥ pralobhādiva vegibhirjalaiḥ | upaplutāstatkṣaṇaśocanīyatāṃ cyutādhikārāḥ sacivā ivāyayuḥ 39||
translation: Carried by their pride, these women, once queens, were quickly swept away by the flood of greed, just like courtiers, now, deprived of their rightful status, lament their sudden fall.

sloka: vipatralekhā niralaktakādharā nirañjanākṣīrapi vibhratīḥ śriyam | nirīkṣya rāmā bubudhe nabhaścarairalaṃkṛtaṃ tadvapupaiva maṇḍanam || 40 ||
translation: Observing Rama, adorned by the sky-travelers, even the spotless, stainless, unblemished one, endowed with her own radiance, comes to understand: "This is the ornamentation equivalent to its own splendor."

sloka: tathā na pūrvaṃ kṛtabhūṣaṇādaraḥ priyānurāgeṇa vilāsinījanaḥ | yathā jalārdro nakhamaṇḍanaśriyā dadāha dṛṣṭīśca vipakṣayoṣitām ||41||
translation: In that way, not as before, a person who adores ornamentation, with fondness for beloved ones, consumes just like a raindrop adorned with dewdrops consumes mud; similarly, their gaze consumes (or focuses on) the attractiveness of others.

sloka: śubhānanāḥ sāmburuheṣu bhīravo vilolahārāścalaphenapaṅktiṣu | nitāntagauryohṛtakuṅkumeṣvalaṃ na lebhire tāḥ parabhāgamūrmiṣu || 42 ||
translation: Even in the tumultuous ocean waves, those with auspicious faces never acquire a portion of fear in the surging, foam-crested billows of the divine mountain Gauri's lake.

sloka: hadāmbhasi vyastavadhūkarāhate ravaṃ mṛdaṅgadhvanidhīramujjhati | muhuḥ stanaistālasamaṃ samādade manoramaṃ nṛtyamiva pravepitam || 43||
translation: At the churning of the ocean, the steady rhythm of the drumbeat rises above the cacophony; again and again, it seems to be playing a delightful dance tune, capturing everyone's hearts.

sloka: śriyā hasadbhiḥ kamalāni sasmitairalaṃkṛtāmbuḥ pratimāgatairmukhaiḥ | kṛtānukūlyā surarājayopitāṃ prasādasāphalyamavāpa jāhnavī ||44||
translation: Gaining the favor of Jāhnavī, who has decorated herself with lotus-like faces smiling at her, and who has been bestowed with auspicious qualities by the king of gods, is equivalent to attaining complete success.

sloka: parisphuranmīnavighaṭṭitoravaḥ surāṅganāstrāsaviloladṛṣṭayaḥ | upāyayuḥ kampitapāṇipallavāḥ sakhījanasyāpi vilokanīyatām 45||
translation: Surrounding peacocks, their feathers trembling, having been excited by the nectar of flowers in the grove, hasten to behold the distinguished beauty of their friend.

sloka: bhayādivāśliṣya jhapāhate'mbhasi priyaṃ mudānandayati sma māninī | akṛtrimapremarasāhitairmano haranti rāmāḥ kṛtakairapīhitaiḥ || 46 ||
translation: Embracing fear and others, throwing them into water, she formerly delighted in her beloved with joyful pleasure. Even with their concealed, premeditated affections, the Rama women carry away unpracticed love, along with their own hearts.

sloka: tirohitāntāni nitāntamākulairapāṃ vigāhādalakaiḥ prasāribhiḥ | yayurvadhūnāṃ vadanāni tulyatāṃ dvirephavṛndāntaritaiḥ sarorūhaiḥ ||47||
translation: The flowing streams, obstructed by masses of waves, made the faces of the women equal in hue, as if adorned with rows of similar dark red flowers.

sloka: karau dhunānā navapallavākṛtī payasyagādhe kila jātasaṃbhramā | sakhīṣu nirvācyamadhārthyadṛṣitaṃ priyāṅgasaṃśleṣamavāpa māninī ||48||
translation: The hands, newly resembling sprouts, have been born in the churning of the ocean of milk, it seems. The modest one has achieved the union of beloved limbs among her friends, an act worthy of being pointed out and considered meaningful.

sloka: priyaiḥ salīlaṃ karavārivāritaḥ pravṛddhaniḥśvāsavikampitastanaḥ | savibhramādhūtakarāgrapallavo yathārthatāmāpa vilāsinījanaḥ || 49||
translation: Just like a mature tree, standing still, whose roots are nourished by water from beloved sources, and adorned by the topmost shoots of budding leaves, similarly, I settle down, stabilizing my breathing, in this yoga posture.

sloka: udasya dhairya dayitena sādaraṃ prasāditāyāḥ karavārivāritam | mukhaṃ nimīlannayanaṃ natabhruvaḥ śriyaṃ sapatnīvadanādivādade || 50 ||
translation: With respect, the calm one (udasya) has cheered up (prasaditayah) the dearest one's (dayitena) heart (hrdayam) by offering (adade) a handful (vari) of water (udakam) as a gesture of greeting (sadaram), steadfastly looking (nimilannayanam) without lowering (natabhruvah) his forehead (bhruvah) and not averting (iva) his gaze (vadanat) from the rival's wife (sapatni), thus revealing his grace and generosity (shriyam).

sloka: vihasya pāṇau vidhṛte dhṛtāmbhasi priyeṇa vadhvā madanārdracetasaḥ | sakhīva kāñci payasā ghanīkṛtā babhāra vītoccayavandhamaṃśukam 51||
translation: With a suppressed smile, holding [her] hands, and standing on the churning ocean, dear to Madana, with love, she, as a friend, made the dense ocean somewhat turbid, having been agitated by the excitement of separation.

sloka: nirañjane sācivilokitaṃ dṛśāvayāvakaṃ vepathuroṣṭapallavam | natabhruvo maṇḍayati sma vigrahe balikriyā cātilakaṃ tadāspadam 52||
translation: In the flawless moon, conspicuous by sight, adorned with curved eyebrows, a slender nose, and a gentle smile, what ornaments could ever enhance its beauty?

sloka: nimīladākekaralolacakṣuṣāṃ priyopakaṇṭhaṃ kṛtagātravepathuḥ | nimañjatīnāṃ śvasitoddhatastanaḥ śramo nu tāsāṃ madano nu paprathe 53||
translation: For those with eyes flickering like a lotus leaf in the water body, what a delightful object of attention it is, when their bodily exhaustion rises and then subsides, such that they are filled with love and enthusiasm.

sloka: priyeṇa siktā caramaṃ vipakṣataścukopa kācinna tutoṣa sāntvanaiḥ | janasya rūḍhapraṇayasya cetasaḥ kimapyamarṣo'nunaye bhṛśāyate || 54 ||
translation: Has not even a trace of displeasure arisen in the loving heart of someone, who has been touched by kind and conciliatory gestures, no matter how deep their natural roughness of feeling may be?

sloka: atha parimalajāmavāpya lakṣmīmavayavadīpitamaṇḍanaśriyastāḥ | vasatimabhivihāya ramyahāvāḥ surapatisūnuvilobhanāya jagmuḥ ||1||
translation: Having acquired Lakshmi, adorned with bodily beauty and radiance, they went, eager to please the sons of Indra, after respectfully greeting the revered one.

sloka: drutapadamabhiyātumicchatīnāṃ gaganaparikramalāghavena tāsām | avaniṣu caraṇaiḥ pṛthustanīnāmalaghunitambatayā ciraṃ niṣede || 2||
translation: Striving to swiftly approach, they wish - for whom? With a mind set on traversing the sky, their desire remains long thwarted, held back by mere footprints on the earth.

sloka: nihitasarasayāvakairbabhāse caraṇatalaiḥ kṛtapaddhatirvadhūnām | aviralavitateva śakragopairaruṇitanīlatṛṇolapā dharitrī || 3 ||
translation: Illuminated by the toes submerged in the cool, clear water, the earth, resembling a vast, unfolding lotus, shines like a disc of gold.

sloka: dhvaniragavivareṣu nūpurāṇāṃ pṛthuraśanāguṇaśiñjitānuyātaḥ | pratiravavitato vanāni cakre mukharasamutsukahaṃsasārasāni || 4 ||
translation: The resonant sound, issuing from the striking of large bells, filled the air as a delighted swan-like artist skillfully played the ancient drum, causing the forests to echo back with melodious notes.

sloka: nṛpatimuniparigraheṇa sā bhūḥ surasacivāpsarasāṃ jahāra tejaḥ | upahitaparamaprabhāvadhāmnāṃ na hi jayināṃ tapasāmalaṅghyamasti ||6||
translation: With the acquisition of the king's power, even the earth was taken by this one, who was like a sage among the company of the celestial servants and celestial nymphs. Indeed, for those who are victorious, there is nothing that can surpass the power of austerity.

sloka: sacakitamiva vismayākulābhiḥ śucisikatāsvatimānuṣāṇi tābhiḥ | kṣitiṣu dadṛśire padāni jipṇorupahitaketurathāṅgalāñchanāni ||7||
translation: Observing footprints resembling those of a sacrificial post, as if astonished, on the earth, did those beings, more pure than the most pure, behold.

sloka: atiśayitavanāntaradyutīnāṃ phalakusumāvacaye'pi tadvidhānām | ṛturiva taruvīrudhāṃ samṛddhyā yuvatijanairjagṛhe muniprabhāvaḥ || 8 ||
translation: Like the seasons' flourishing of trees, the sage's influence also makes young people in a household blossom with excellent fruit; such is the supremacy of those who possess inner radiance.

sloka: mṛditakisalayaḥ surāṅganānāṃ sasalilavulkalabhārabhugnaśākhaḥ | bahumatimadhikāṃ yayāvaśokaḥ parijanatāpi guṇāya sadguṇānām ||9||
translation: The tree in the garden of the divine, beaten by the rain and winds, has become limp. How can one who seeks excellence endure such sorrow, when assessing the qualities of those who excel?

sloka: yamaniyamakṛśīkṛtasthirāṅgaḥ paridadṛśe vidhṛtāyudhaḥ sa tābhiḥ | anupamaśamadīptatāgarīyānkṛtapadapaṅktiratharvaṇeva vedaḥ || 10 ||
translation: The one who has subdued his senses and is firmly established in self-control, who carries his weapons (of discrimination) always ready, such a one, through his arrangement of unsurpassed brilliance, makes the scripture (of self-knowledge) shine like the Atharvan hymns in the Vedas.

sloka: śaśadhara iva locanābhirāmairgaganavisāribhiraṃśubhiḥ parītaḥ | śikharanicayamekasānusadmā sakalamivāpi dadhanmahīdharasya || 11||
translation: Surrounded by delightful eyes like the moon, resembling a stack of peaks, and adorned with all sides by retinues shining like the stars, he holds everything, just like the earth's supporter.

sloka: surasariti paraṃ tapo'dhigacchanvidhutapiśaṅgabṛhajjaṭākalāpaḥ | haviriva vitataḥ śikhāsamūhaiḥ samabhilapannupavedi jātavedāḥ ||12||
translation: A ascetic, rid of impurities, superior to the behavior of even the gods, with matted hair piled high, chanting the sacred verses, just like the offering of havis (during a yajna) spread out wide, addressed the call of the fire-priest JātaVEDAS.

sloka: sadṛśamatanumākṛteḥ prayatnaṃ tadanuguṇāmaparaiḥ kriyāmalaṅadhyām | dadhadalaghu tapaḥ kriyānurūpaṃ vijayavatīṃ ca tapaḥsamāṃ samṛddhim 13||
translation: Performing effort equivalent to that entity, coupled with qualities similar to it, along with light austerities, and in accordance with one's duty, one attains victory-like success, as well as prosperity.

sloka: ciraniyamakṛśo'pi śailasāraḥ śamanirato'pi durāsadaḥ prakṛtyā | sasaciva iva nirjane'pi tiṣṭhanmunirapi tulyarucistrilokabhartuḥ||14||
translation: Even someone who is steadfast in austerity for a long time, slender like a mountain peak, and hard to approach, just like a stone, is equal in attraction in this world when compared to the one who is the stabilizer of the three worlds, just as a muni sitting alone in the forest is like any other object in that place.

sloka: tanumavajitalokasāradhāmnīṃ tribhuvanaguptisahāṃ vilokayantyaḥ | avayayuramarastriyo'sya yatnaṃ vijayaphale viphalaṃ tapodhikāre ||15||
translation: Observing the decorous lady, adorning the world, who is difficult to attain, along with the guardians of the three worlds, King Marutstriya makes an effort. But this effort, aimed at gaining victory over her in the ascetic's challenge, turns out to be futile.

sloka: munidanutanayānvilobhya sadyaḥ pratanubalānyadhitiṣṭhatastapāṃsi | alaghuni bahumenire ca tāḥ svaṃ kuliśabhṛtā vihitaṃ pade niyogam 16||
translation: Having immediately embraced the teachings of the sage, she stands firm with increased strength, fending off all distractions. She, on her own, follows the appointed duty, holding the weight of her own burden, as prescribed.

sloka: atha kṛtakavilobhanaṃ vidhitsau yuvatijane harisūnudarśanena | prasabhamavatatāra cittajanmā harati mano madhurā hi yauvanaśrīḥ ||17||
translation: Then, indeed, the enchanting sight of a young woman suddenly seizes the mind of a man, swiftly stealing it away, such is the sweet allure of youthful beauty.

sloka: sapadi harisakhairvadhūnideśādhvdanītamanoramavallakīmṛdaṅgaiḥ | yugapadṛtugaṇasya saṃnidhānaṃ viyati vane ca yathāyathaṃ vitene ||18||
translation: At once, with the sounds of drums and other musical instruments, the gathering of the troops takes place in the forest, just as it should in an ordered manner.

sloka: sajalajaladharaṃ nabho vireje vivṛtimiyāya rucistaḍillatānām | vyavahitarativigrahairvitene jalagurubhiḥ stanitaurdigantareṣu || 19||
translation: Undulating in the sky, a cloud laden with moisture, adorned with various shapes, skillfully covers and conceals with its coolness the summits of mountains, where rivers originate.

sloka: parisurapatisūnudhāma sadyaḥ samupadadhanmukulāni mālatīnām | viralamapajahāra baddhabinduḥ sarajasatāmavanerapāṃ nipātaḥ || 20 ||
translation: The best of kings' son, having suddenly opened today the fully blown buds, abandoned the tied drop; like a raindrop falling from the sky, he forsook the multitude of Malati flowers.

sloka: pratidiśamabhigacchatābhimṛṣṭaḥ kakubhavikāsasugandhinānilena | nava iva vibabhau sacittajanmā gatadhṛtirākulitaśca jīvalokaḥ ||21||
translation: Approaching the east, greeted by the fragrant and dark blue cornea of the lotus, the mind-born being, now appearing like a newborn, sets out with a steady mind and agitated life in the world.

sloka: vyathitamapi bhṛśaṃ mano harantī pariṇatajambuphalopabhogahṛṣṭā | parabhṛtayuvatiḥ svanaṃ vitene navanavayojitakaṇṭharāgaramyam ||22||
translation: Even a mind troubled greatly is delighted by the enjoyment of ripe jambufruit; so too, why wouldn't the young heart of another be captivated by your charm, adorned with fresh, carefully chosen qualities?

sloka: abhibhavati manaḥ kadambavāyau madamadhure ca śikhaṇḍināṃ nināde | jana iva na dhṛteścacāla jiṣṇurna hi mahatāṃ sukaraḥ samādhibhaṅgaḥ 23||
translation: The mind of the Kadamba forest's elephants is captivated by the irresistible sound of Śikhaṇḍin's call, just like an unwavering, skilled person easily overpowers even the mighty.

sloka: dhṛtabisavalayāvalirvahantī kumudavanaikadukūlamāttabāṇā | śaradamalatale sarojapāṇau ghanasamayena vadhūrivālalambe || 24 ||
translation: Wearing a garland and a girdle, carrying a single lotus flower, resembling an autumnal fully bloomed flower, she, the bride, holds it near her chest.

sloka: samadaśikhirutāni  haṃsanādaiḥ kumudavanāni kadambapuṣpavṛṣṭyā | śriyamatiśayinīṃ sametya jagmurguṇamahatāṃ mahate guṇāya yogaḥ ||25||
translation: Unified by the gathering of swans at the lotus ponds, enriched by a shower of Kadamba flowers, such is the union of the great qualities, with preeminent glory, becoming one with the supreme excellent quality.

sloka: sarajasamapahāya ketakīnāṃ prasavamupāntikanīpareṇukīrṇam | priyamadhurasanāni ṣaṭpadālī malinayati sma vinīlabandhanāni || 26 ||
translation: Having abandoned the impure collection of stamens of ketaki flowers, rid of the residue from washing them, she adorns herself with priya (beloved) and madhura (sweet-smelling) six-petaled flowers, rid of impurities.

sloka: mukulitamatiśayya bandhujīvaṃ dhṛtajalabindupu śādvalasthalīṣu | aviralavapuṣaḥ surendragopā vikacapalāśacayaśriyaṃ samīyuḥ || 27 ||
translation: Wearing a single-petaled lotus, the foremost among companions, holding a water droplet, standing on the plain of śādvala, with unblemished form, along with Indra and gopas, he has joined the beautiful leafy branches of vikaca palasa trees.

sloka: aviralaphalinīvanaprasūnaḥ kusumitakundasugandhigandhavāhaḥ | guṇamasamayajaṃ cirāya lebhe viralatuṣārakaṇastuṣārakālaḥ || 28 ||
translation: With an unstoppable flow, carrying the fragrance of forest blooms, the wagon of Kusumita and Kunda, always possessing excellent qualities, acquires for a long time the fine dust of gems during the sacred ritual.

sloka: nicayini lavalīlatāvikāse janayati lodhrasamīraṇe ca harṣam | vikṛtimupayayau na pāṇḍusūnuścalati nayānna jigīṣatāṃ hi cetaḥ || 29 ||
translation: In the gathering, the Madhavi creeper, on blooming, gives joy; it does not waver, shining, as the son of Pandu, attracting the minds of those who desire victory.

sloka: katipayasahakārapuṣparamyastanutuhino'lpavinidrasinduvāraḥ | surabhimukhahimāgamāntaśaṃsī samupayayau śiśiraḥ smaraikabandhuḥ || 30 ||
translation: Approaching like a partial ally, not staying away from the expanse of the blue lotus, facing the fragrant breeze, with the coolness of winter, and as a companion to the frost, the cold season arrived, accompanied by the friend, reminiscence, alone.

sloka: kusumanagavanānyupaitukāmā kisalayinīmavalambya cūtayaṣṭim | kvaṇadalikulanūpurā nirāse nalinavaneṣu padaṃ vasantalakṣmīḥ || 31 ||
translation: With a blooming desire, embracing the tender creeper, she steps in the spring-filled groves, like anklets on the lotus ponds making soft tinkling sounds.

sloka: vikasitakusumādharaṃ hasantīṃ kurabakarājivadhūṃ vilokayantam | dadṛśuriva surāṅganā niṣaṇṇaṃ saśaramanaṅgamaśokapallaveṣu || 32 ||
translation: The goddesses, like ones enamored, beheld him, as he looked at the bride, decorated with fully bloomed kusuma flowers, smiling, and seated amidst the arrows, quivers and other symbols of war, yet appearing to be free from any distress.

sloka: muhuranupatatā vidhūyamānaṃ viracitasaṃhati dakṣiṇānilena | alikulamalakākṛtiṃ prapede nalinamukhāntavisarpi paṅkajinyāḥ ||
translation: Dropping frequently and scattering, the artificially arranged bundle made of southern cotton-like fibers approaches the lotus filament free from dirt and resembling a row of hair, emerging from the mouth of the lotus.

sloka: śvasanacalitapallavādharoṣṭhe navanihiterṣyamivāvadhūnayantī | madhusurabhiṇi ṣaṭpadena puṣpe mukha iva śālalatāvadhūścucumbe ||
translation: Like a breeze causing a tender creeper to sway, and like a fragrant breeze playing on a fully bloomed flower, what appears to be a honey bee, drawn by the scent, approaches the blooming muhuh in six steps.

sloka: prabhavati na tadā paro vijetuṃ bhavati jitendriyatā yadātmarakṣā | avajitabhuvanastayā hi lebhe sitaturage vijayaṃ na puṣpamāsaḥ ||
translation: When one's senses are fully controlled, then one cannot be conquered by others; it is then that self-protection occurs. By merely remaining in that state, one will achieve victory, not in the form of a fleeting flower-month, but as a steady, firm victory.

sloka: kathamiva tava saṃmatirbhavitrī samamṛtubhirmunināvadhīritasya | iti viracitamallikāvikāsaḥ smayata iva sma madhuṃ nidāghakālaḥ ||
translation: "How, like immortality, has your renown been made equal to that of the sage who has mastered self-control? So it seems that the time for harvesting honey has come."

sloka: balavadapi balaṃ mithovirodhi prabhavati naiva vipakṣanirjayāya | bhuvanaparibhavī na yattadānīṃ tamṛtugaṇaḥ kṣaṇamunmanīcakāra ||
translation: Even one who is strong can't arise as an opponent in the face of balanced forces, not to mention that it's impossible for an opposing party to prevail over the entire world. That being said, in a fleeting moment, the assembly of divine forces made him unconscious.

sloka: śrutisukhamupavīṇitaṃ sahāyairaviralalāñchanahāriṇaśca kālāḥ | avihitaharisūnuvikriyāṇi tridaśavadhūṣu manobhavaṃ vitenuḥ ||
translation: Learning pleasing to the ears through scriptural study, accompanied by loyal and splendid allies, moves along time; it also overcomes the nature of the thirty gods, becoming their lord.

sloka: na dalati nicaye tathotpalānāṃ na viṣamacchadagucchayūthikāsu | abhiratimupalebhire yathāsāṃ haritanayāvayaveṣu locanāni ||
translation: Just as the contrasting-colored patterns on utpala flowers do not spoil their delight, similarly, the eyes do not lose their luster, even when affected by contrasting colors, such as kajal, in their application.

sloka: munimabhimukhatāṃ ninīṣavo yāḥ samupayayuḥ kamanīyatāguṇena | madanamupadadhe sa eva tāsāṃ duradhigamā hi gatiḥ prayojanānām ||
translation: The wicked who approach the sage with the intention of obtaining his auspicious qualities, their objective is hard to achieve and that is union with him.

sloka: prakṛtamanusasāra nābhineyaṃ pravikasadaṅguli pāṇipallavaṃ vā | prathamamupahitaṃ vilāsi cakṣuḥ sitaturage na cacāla nartakīnām ||
translation: In the very beginning, the dancer's eyes, adorned with the loveliest lashes, did not move, even slightly, while engaged in their first performance on this earthly plane, adorned by human society and nature's beauty.

sloka: abhinayamanasaḥ surāṅganāyā nihitamalaktakavartanābhitāmram | caraṇamabhipapāta ṣaṭpadālī dhṛtanavalohitapaṅkajābhiśaṅkā ||
translation: The gait of the maidens adorned with reddish kunkuma on their feet, applied in a hidden manner by the actors, resembles the movement of a swan; it causes anxiety in the mind of the passionate spectators.

sloka: aviralamalaseṣu nartakīnāṃ drutapariṣiktamalaktakaṃ padeṣu | savapuṣamiva cittarāgamūhurnamitaśikhāni kadambakesarāṇi ||
translation: Like unruffled, spotless kadamba flowers, adorned with swiftly falling droplets, on the feet of dancers, similar are the untainted thoughts, arising in the mind, steady and pure, compared to those flowers adorned with fresh droplets, just as a row of fresh, wet kesara flowers.

sloka: nṛpasutamabhitaḥ samanmathāyāḥ parijanagātratirohitāṅgayaṣṭeḥ | sphuṭamabhilaṣitaṃ babhūva vadhvā vadati hi saṃvṛtireva kāmitāni ||
translation: The king's son, now clearly yearned for by the citizens, whose limbs had been concealed, has become manifest; he speaks, indeed, of desires that are veiled.

sloka: abhimuni sahasā hṛte parasyā ghanamarutā jaghanāṃśukaikadeśe | cakitamavasanoru satrapāyāḥ pratiyuvatīrapi vismayaṃ nināya ||
translation: The sudden abduction of the wife of the raja by a dense storm cloud leaves not only the king, but also the young women in his court, astonished.

sloka: dhṛtabisavalaye nidhāya pāṇau mukhamadhirūṣitapāṇḍugaṇḍalekham | nṛpasutamaparā smarābhitāpādamadhumadālasalocanaṃ nidadhyau ||
translation: Having placed his foot on a flat stone, remembering the prince, his eyes filled with compassion and sadness, he fixed his gaze.

sloka: sakhi dayitamihānayeti sā māṃ prahitavatī kusumeṣuṇābhitaptā | hṛdayamahṛdayā na nāma pūrvaṃ bhavadupakaṇṭhamupāgataṃ viveda ||
translation: Oh friend, she who had previously not known even in name the intimate one, has now come to recognize the one who has entered her innermost heart through the fragrance of the Kusumeshu flower.

sloka: ciramapi kalitānyapārayantyā parigadituṃ pariśuṣyatā mukhena | gataghṛṇa gamitāni satsakhīnāṃ nayanayugaiḥ samamārdratāṃ manāṃsi ||
translation: For a long time, their faces turned towards each other, the close friends exhaust themselves in speaking to each other, as their minds become fully engaged with their eyes meeting each other, even giving up their other activities.

sloka: acakamata sapallavāṃ dharitrīṃ mṛdusurabhiṃ virahayya puṣpaśayyām | bhṛśamaratimavāpya tatra cāsyāstava sukhaśītamupaitumaṅkamicchā ||
translation: Having failed to notice the soft, fragrant grass, she who lies on a flower bed departs; eagerly seeking supreme happiness there, she will make that place her own.

sloka: jahihi kaṭhinatāṃ prayaccha vācaṃ nanu karuṇāmṛdu mānasaṃ munīnām | upagatamavadhīrayantyabhavyāḥ sa nipuṇametya kayācidevamūce ||
translation: Reject harshness, offer a gentle and compassionate speech to the sages, as they approach. With a skilled and controlled body, proclaim thus: "Welcome."

sloka: salalitacalitatrikābhirāmā śirasijasaṃyamanākulaikapāṇiḥ | surapatitanaye'parā nirāse manasijajaitraśaraṃ vilocanārdham ||
translation: With hair adorned by cascades of tears, hands gesturing to calm the mind, revered by gods and despised by the wicked, with a heart full of love, and eyes filled with joy, this is how She appears.

sloka: kusumitamavalambya cūtamuccaistanuribhakumbhapṛthustanānatāṅgī | tadabhimukhamanaṅgacāpayaṣṭirvisṛtaguṇeva samunnanāma kācit ||
translation: Embracing the blooming tree, an ascetic, tall and slender, with pendulous breasts, moves towards it; some think her movements are like those of an unstrung bow.

sloka: sarabhasamavalambya nīlamanyā vigalitanīvi vilolamantarīyam | abhipatitumanāḥ sasādhvaseva cyutaraśanāguṇasaṃditāvatasthe ||
translation: Having seized (avalambya) the wild elephant (sarabhasam), he firmly stands (avatasthe), in this world, with a steady mind (manah), having cast off (vigalita) all mean attachment (nīvi), his noble qualities (guṇa) shining (vilolamantarīya), as he approaches (abhipati) and serves (aseva) the righteous (sādhu), unshaken (cyuta) even when faced with a reversal of fortune (raśanā).

sloka: yadi manasi śamaḥ kimaṅga cāpaṃ śaṭha viṣayāstava vallabhā na muktiḥ | bhavatu diśati nānyakāminībhyastava hṛdaye hṛdayeśvarāvakāśam ||
translation: If calmness of mind is not present, what use is a weapon to a deceitful person attracted to sensory pleasures? May there be an opening in your heart for your Lord, not attachment to other love interests.

sloka: iti viṣamitacakṣuṣābhidhāya sphuradadharoṣṭhamasūyayā kayācit | agaṇitagurumānalajjayāsau svayamurasi śravaṇotpalena jaghne ||
translation: Having been named "Viṣamitra" by his own will, he himself, free from envy, and with a body marked by asceticism, burned down the teacher, who was unbeknownst to him, along with his pride and shame, by his own inner awakening, like a lotus by the sun's rays.

sloka: karuṇamabhihitaṃ trapā nirastā tadabhimukhaṃ ca vimuktamaśru tābhiḥ | prakupitamabhisāraṇe'nunetuṃ priyamiyatī hyabalājanasya bhūmiḥ ||
translation: The earth becomes easily accessible, gentle, and favorable towards a weak person when greeted with a kind word, who has removed anger, turns towards them, is freed from crying, and attempts to appease their agitation.

sloka: asakalanayanekṣitāni lajjā gatamalasaṃ paripāṇḍutā viṣādaḥ | iti vividhamiyāya tāsu bhūṣāṃ prabhavati maṇḍayituṃ vadhūranaṅgaḥ ||
translation: The bashful modesty of a woman, along with her downward gazing eyes, becomes unsteady, falters, and is overshadowed by dejection, as she adorns herself with various ornaments in preparation for her lover.

sloka: alasapadamanoramaṃ prakṛtyā jitakalahaṃsavadhūgati prayātam | sthitamurujaghanasthalātibhārāduditapariśramajihnitekṣaṇaṃ vā ||
translation: With a weary mind, having conquered time like a swan leaves a lake, (the sun) sets, established in its course, revealing its radiant, heavy form marked by the toil of a day's journey.

sloka: bhṛśakusumaśareṣupātamohādanavasitārthapadākulo'bhilāpaḥ | adhikavitatalocanaṃ vadhūnāmayugapadunnamitabhru vīkṣitaṃ  ||
translation: Having thoroughly agitated the crowd, who were focused on the objective of removing the delusion caused by the rivalry of Kusuma and Sharesha, he looked at the unglazed, widely open eyes of the bride, accompanied by her lover, with a sidelong glance.

sloka: rucikaramapi nārthavadbabhūva stimitasamādhiśucau pṛthātanūje | jvalayati mahatāṃ manāṃsyamarṣe na hi labhate'vasaraṃ sukhābhilāṣaḥ ||
translation: Even a person with a taste for pleasure does not become truly accomplished if they lack steadfastness in their meditative absorption and purity in their mind and body. Passion does not arise in the great minds that seek joy, for they do not find an opportune moment for it.

sloka: svayaṃ saṃrādhyaivaṃ śatamakhamakhaṇḍena tapasā parocchittyā labhyāmabhilaṣati lakṣmīṃ harisute | manobhiḥ sodvegaiḥ praṇayavihatidhvastarucayaḥ sagandharvā dhāma tridaśavanitāḥ svaṃ pratiyayuḥ ||
translation: Cultivating herself, Hiranyakesi's daughter desires to obtain wealth through a hundredfold unbroken concentration and penance. With minds free from disturbance, Gandharvas and Apsaras approach their own abodes, as does the united group of divine women.

sloka: athāmarṣānnisargācca jitendriyatayā tayā | ājagāmāśramaṃ jiṣṇoḥ pratītaḥ pākaśāsanaḥ ||
translation: Having given up anger and naturally overcoming his senses, the famed Pāka, having recognized, came to the hermitage.

sloka: munirūpo'nurūpeṇa sūnunā dadṛśe puraḥ | drāghīyasā vayotītaḥ pariklāntaḥ kilādhvanā ||
translation: The sage saw before him, with a similar form, someone who was lagging behind, somewhat advanced in age, and bent over on the path.

sloka: jaṭānāṃ kīrṇayā keśaiḥ saṃhatyā paritaḥ sitaiḥ | pṛktayendukarairahnaḥ paryanta iva saṃdhyayā ||
translation: Surrounded by scattered, matted locks of hair, interspersed with bright white streaks, resembling the twilight around the end of daylight.

sloka: viśadabhrūyugacchannavalitāpāṅgalocanaḥ | prāleyāvatatimlānapalāśābja iva hradaḥ ||
translation: Like a lotus rising from a clear-browed lake, surrounded by matted locks and curved eyebrows, shining eyes, and overgrown with submerged leaves and roots.

sloka: āsaktabharanīkāśairaṅgaiḥ parikṛśairapi | ādyūnaḥ sadgṛhiṇyeva prāyo yaṣṭyāvalambitaḥ ||
translation: Embraced by lean arms, adorned with bangles, and leaning on a staff, who is that common person who resembles a noble elder?

sloka: gūḍho'pi vapuṣā rājandhāmnā lokābhibhāvinā | aṃśumāniva tanvabhrapaṭalacchannavigrahaḥ ||
translation: Even though hidden by a physical form that resembles a mass of storm clouds, he is powerful in the world, just like the sun's rays are hidden by clouds.

sloka: jaratīmapi bibhrāṇastanumaprākṛtākṛtiḥ | cakārākrāntalakṣmīkaḥ sasādhvasamivāśramam ||
translation: Even someone aged like Indra's thunderbolt can establish a hermitage that resembles a fortified city, adorned with extraordinary beauty.

sloka: abhitastaṃ pṛthāsūnuḥ rnehena paritastare | avijñāte'pi bandhau hi balātprahnādate manaḥ ||
translation: Even the son of Pritha, though unaware, cannot resist the urge to come to the aid of a relative when they are in danger, as the strength of this bond is not easily abandoned.

sloka: ātitheyīmathāsādya sutādapacitiṃ hariḥ | viśramya viṣṭare nāma vyājahāreti bhāratīm ||
translation: Having received the respect due to a guest, the sun, after resting, revealed himself by his name "Bhāratī" (an epithet of the sun deity).

sloka: tvayā sādhu samārambhi nave vayasi yattapaḥ | hriyate viṣayaiḥ prāyo varṣīyānapi mādṛśaḥ ||
translation: With your auspicious beginning, a young man, who is otherwise advanced in age, dedicates himself to austerities, being primarily engaged in sense objects.

sloka: śreyasīṃ tava saṃprāptā guṇasaṃpadamākṛtiḥ | sulabhā ramyatā loke durlabhaṃ hi guṇārjanam ||
translation: Your acquisition of virtuous prosperity is auspicious. Easy to approach is pleasantness in the world, but hard to find is one who cultivates virtue.

sloka: śaradambudharacchāyāgatvaryo yauvanaśriyaḥ | āpātaramyā viṣayāḥ paryantaparitāpinaḥ ||
translation: In the autumn season, he who possesses the beauty of youth, and who, like a cloud, provides shade, making enjoyments free from excessive grief, who is that person?

sloka: antakaḥ paryavasthātā janminaḥ saṃtatāpadaḥ | iti tyājye bhave bhavyo muktāvuttiṣṭhate janaḥ ||
translation: The end-maker, being established in the preservation of beings, moves from the past to the future. Having abandoned [the body], a person arises in liberation.

sloka: cittavānasi kalyāṇī yattvāṃ matirupasthitā | viruddhaḥ kevalaṃ veṣaḥ saṃdehayati me manaḥ ||
translation: If you're endowed with a discerning mind, O auspicious one, a consistent disposition disturbs my thoughts, creating uncertainty within me.

sloka: yuyutsuneva kavacaṃ kimāmuktamidaṃ tvayā | tapasvino hi vasate kevalājinavalkale ||
translation: Like a warrior, why isn't this armor discarded by you? For, a dedicated ascetic surely dwells in just animal skin.

sloka: prapitsoḥ kiṃ ca te muktiṃ niḥspṛhasya kalevare | maheṣudhī dhanurbhīmaṃ bhūtānāmanabhidruhaḥ ||
translation: What about your liberation, O uninterested one in the physical body? Mahaishudi, wielding a mighty bow, should you not fight against these creatures?

sloka: bhayaṃkaraḥ prāṇabhṛtāṃ mṛtyorbhuja ivāparaḥ | asistava tapaḥsthasya na samarthayate śamam ||
translation: The source of fear among living beings, resembling death's arm, is unable to be pacified by the austerities of one who is established (in spiritual practices) and remains unchanged.

sloka: jayamatrabhavānnūnamarātiṣvabhilāṣukaḥ | krodhalakṣma kṣamāvantaḥ kvāyudhaṃ kva tapodhanāḥ ||
translation: Seeking victory, what warrior is free from greed and anger, and where are generosity and forbearance found?

sloka: yaḥ karoti vadhodarkā niḥśreyasakarīḥ kriyāḥ | glānidoṣacchidaḥ svacchāḥ sa mūḍhaḥ paṅkayatyapaḥ ||
translation: The one who performs sacrificial duties that bestow supreme well-being, eradicating the flaws of degeneration, is pure, yet considered a deluded fool, sinking into the mud.

sloka: mūlaṃ doṣasya hiṃsāderarthakāmau sma mā puṣaḥ | tau hi tattvāvabodhasya durucchedāvupaplavau ||
translation: The root of fault arising from violence, along with desires for worldly gains, should not have flourished in us. Indeed, they are major obstacles in realizing the truth.

sloka: abhidroheṇa bhūtānāmarjayangatvarīḥ śriyaḥ | udanvāniva sindhūnāmāpadāmeti pātratām ||
translation: Just as the wind, moving over the rivers, makes them capable of holding water, so does Arjuna's attack make the beings capable of attaining prosperity.

sloka: yā gamyāḥ satsahāyānāṃ yāsu khedo bhayaṃ yataḥ | tāsāṃ kiṃ yanna duḥkhāya vipadāmiva saṃpadām ||
translation: What suffering or fear could there not be for those who seek out good companions, given that even auspicious circumstances can lead to misfortune?

sloka: durāsadānarīnugrāndhṛterviśvāsajanmanaḥ | bhogānbhogānivāheyānadhyāsyāpanna durlabhā ||
translation: Gaining the trust of a difficult-to-approach enemy and appropriating possessions through force are difficult to attain and are subject to being abandoned.

sloka: nāntarajñāḥ śriyo jātu priyairāsāṃ na bhūyate | āsaktāstāsvamī mūḍhā vāmaśīlā hi jantavaḥ ||
translation: Never do those who know lesser truths compete for prosperity with their dear ones, for foolish beings, infatuated and of perverse nature, are never in control of themselves.

sloka: ko'pavādaḥ stutipade yadaśīleṣu cañcalāḥ | sādhuvṛttānapi kṣudrā vikṣipantyeva saṃpadaḥ ||
translation: When does condemnation, along with flattery, make virtue's steadfastness unsteady, even the insignificant ones?

sloka: kṛtavānanyadeheṣu kartā ca vidhuraṃ manaḥ | apriyairiva saṃyogo viprayogaḥ priyaiḥ saha ||
translation: Having acted in other bodies, being the doer, having a detached mind, shunning unfavorable associations, like an outsider, yet maintaining favorable connections with dear ones.

sloka: śūnyamākīrṇatāmeti tulyaṃ vyasanamutsavaiḥ | vipralambho'pi lābhāya sati priyasamāgame ||
translation: Equating emptiness and crowdedness, prosperity and adversity, separation too yields gain when love and beloved meet.

sloka: tadā ramyāṇyaramyāṇi priyāḥ śalyaṃ tadāsavaḥ | tadaikākī sabandhuḥ sanniṣṭena rahito yadā ||
translation: Then, when it is so, the most charming among the charming, the beloved, the thorn (i.e., problem) also arises. At that time, one is alone, without relatives, and separate, just as it should be.

sloka: yuktaḥ pramādyasi hitādapetaḥ paritapyase | yadi neṣṭātmanaḥ pīḍā mā sañji bhavatā jane ||
translation: Being united, if you indulge in heedlessness, abandoning what is beneficial and tormenting yourself, may there not arise in you affliction from not pursuing what is dear to your self, O fellow being.

sloka: janmino'sya sthitiṃ vidvāṃllakṣmīmiva calācalām | bhavānmā sma vadhīnnyāyyaṃ nyāyādhārā hi sādhavaḥ ||
translation: Knowing the establishment of him who has taken birth, like fleeting fortune, the wise one becomes like steadfastness itself; for, righteousness is the foundation of such a one.

sloka: vijahīhi raṇotsāhaṃ mā tapaḥ sādhu nīnaśaḥ | ucchedaṃ janmanaḥ kartumedhi śāntastapodhana ||
translation: Reject, O brave one, this eagerness for battle; do not be passionate about violence. Achieving liberation from the cycle of birth is the true goal of a peaceful, self-controlled person like you.

sloka: jīyantāṃ durjayā dehe ripavaścakṣurādayaḥ | jiteṣu nanu loko'yaṃ teṣu kṛtsnastvayā jitaḥ ||
translation: Let sensory organs such as sight, which are difficult to overcome, prevail within this body; indeed, through your control, this entire world has been conquered in those that are conquered.

sloka: paravānarthasaṃsiddhau nīcavṛttirapatrapaḥ | avidheyendriyaḥ puṃsāṃ gaurivaiti vidheyatām ||
translation: For achieving others' welfare, base conduct is shameful for men; self-control over the senses, resembling a cow, should be practiced.

sloka: śvastvayā sukhasaṃvittiḥ smaraṇīyādhunātanī | iti svapnopamānmatvā kāmānmā gāstadaṅgatām ||
translation: With happiness recognized by you, may this remembrance be brought to mind at once, considering it as similar to a dream, lest worldly desires lead to attachment.

sloka: śraddheyā vipralabdhāraḥ priyā vipriyakāriṇaḥ | sudustyajāstyajanto'pi kāmāḥ kaṣṭā hi śatravaḥ ||
translation: The objects of faith that deceive, those that are dear yet act unfavorably, even those desires that are difficult to give up and yet unfruitful - indeed, such enemies are arduous.

sloka: vivikte'sminnage bhūyaḥ plāvite jahnukanyayā | pratyāsīdati muktistvāṃ purā mā bhūrudāyudhaḥ ||
translation: In this secluded place, by submerging (yourself) again and again in the waters of the Ganga, you will attain liberation; oh weapon-wielder, do not hesitate now.

sloka: vyāhṛtya marutāṃ patyāviti vācamavasthite | vacaḥ praśrayagambhīramathovāca kapidhvajaḥ ||
translation: Having uttered the word "lord of Maruts," Hanuman stood there silently for a while, then spoke in a deep and serious tone, "O monkey-bannered one."

sloka: prasādaramyamojasvi garīyo lāghavānvitam | sākāṅkṣamanupaskāraṃ viṣvaggati nirākulam ||
translation: A graceful, radiant, distinguished, and lightweight offering, ever ready for acceptance, unperturbed in all directions.

sloka: nyāyanirṇītasāratvānnirapekṣamivāgame | aprakampyatayānyeṣāmāmnāyavacanopamam ||
translation: Impartial like a decision made through proper deliberation, firm and unshakeable like a statement made by tradition.

sloka: alaṅghyatvājjanairanyaiḥ kṣubhitodanvadūrjitam | audāryādarthasaṃpatteḥ śāntaṃ cittamṛṣeriva ||
translation: Like a calm lake undisturbed by even powerful winds, a selfless person, who has amassed wealth for the benefit of others, remains unperturbed by fame or criticism.

sloka: idamīdṛgguṇopetaṃ labdhāvasarasādhanam | vyākuryātkaḥ priyaṃ vākyaṃ yo vaktā nedṛgāśayaḥ ||
translation: The one who has acquired the appropriate opportunity should make use of this very auspicious gain, endowed with good qualities, by speaking a beloved and pleasing speech, without any deceitful intent.

sloka: na jñātaṃ tāta yatnasya paurvāparyamamuṣya te | śāsituṃ yena māṃ dharmaṃ munibhistulyamicchasi ||
translation: O father, you do not seem to know the extent of my effort, for you wish to teach me dharma as if we were equal in knowledge.

sloka: avijñātaprabandhasya vaco vācaspaterapi | vrajatyaphalatāmeva nayadruha ivehitam ||
translation: Even the speech of one who doesn't recognize the power of the lord of speech's arrangement, sets out to bear fruit, just like something set in motion by force.

sloka: śreyaso'pyasya te tāta vacaso nāsmi bhājanam | nabhasaḥ sphuṭatārasya rātreriva viparyayaḥ ||
translation: I am not, O dear one, the enhancer of this one's speech, even though I am capable of being so; like the increased clarity of the sky at night, I am the opposite.

sloka: kṣatriyastanayaḥ pāṇḍorahaṃ pārtho dhanaṃjayaḥ | sthitaḥ prāstasya dāyādairbhrāturjyeṣṭhasya śāsane ||
translation: I, Pārtha also known as Dhanañjaya, am a royal prince, the son of Pāṇḍu, stationed in front of the eldest brother's heirs, ready to follow the command of the one who is superior to them all, the throne's rightful occupant.

sloka: kṛṣṇadvaipāyanādeśādvibharmi vratamīdṛśam | bhṛśamārādhane yattaḥ svārādhyasya marutvataḥ ||
translation: Adhere to this kind of vow, as instructed by Krishna Dvaipayana, so as to properly worship and please the Lord of Wind, with great devotion.

sloka: durakṣāndīvyatā rājñā rājyamātmā vayaṃ vadhūḥ | nītāni paṇatāṃ nūnamīdṛśī bhavitavyatā ||
translation: The queen, it seems, must now be prepared for a change in ruling, as the king's mental state is unpredictable and uncertain.

sloka: tenānujasahāyena draupadyā ca mayā vinā | bhṛśamāyāmiyāmāsu yāminīṣvabhitapyate ||
translation: Accompanied by this younger sibling, along with Draupadi, and without me, she feels extremely distressed in the battlefield.

sloka: hṛtottarīyāṃ prasabhaṃ sabhāyāmāgatahriyaḥ | marmacchidā no vacasā niratakṣannarātayaḥ ||
translation: Arriving uninvited in the assembly, recklessly seated on a higher garment, they, who are unsteady, constantly cutting through the essence with their speech, are not worthy of respect.

sloka: upādhatta sapatreṣu kṛṣṇāyā gurusaṃnidhau | bhāvamānayane satyāḥ satyaṃkāramivāntakaḥ ||
translation: In the presence of the guru, one who establishes genuine feelings towards Kṛṣṇāyāḥ among the three, resembling a bringer of truth, indeed acts as a veritable embodiment of truth.

sloka: tāmaikṣanta kṣaṇaṃ sabhyā duḥśāpuraḥsarām | abhisāyārkamāvṛttāṃ chāyāmiva mahātaroḥ ||
translation: Like the immense shadow enveloping all, just for a moment, the assembly of corrupt politicians is overshadowed by the resplendent sun of righteousness.

sloka: ayathārthakriyārambhaiḥ patibhiḥ kiṃ tavekṣitaiḥ | arudhyetāmitīvāsyā nayane bāṣpavāriṇā ||
translation: With what purpose are started actions contrary to their true purpose by your husbands, and why are they not noticed by you? Her eyes become filled with tears, as if she would say, "This is not how it should be done."

sloka: soḍhavānno daśāmantyāṃ jyāyāneva guṇapriyaḥ | sulabho hi dviṣāṃ bhaṅgo durlabhā satkhavācyatā ||
translation: A person who is superior in virtue is easily approachable by friends but hard to win over by enemies, such a one's fame is rarely found.

sloka: sthityatikrāntibhīrūṇi svacchānyākulitānyapi | toyāni toyarāśīnāṃ manāṃsi ca manasvinām ||
translation: Even the calm and still waters of the purest kind, as well as those agitated, belong to the multitude of liquids, including that of the noble-minded.

sloka: dhārtarāṣṭraiḥ saha prītirvairamasmāsvasūyata | asanmaitrī hi doṣāya kūlacchāyeva sevitā ||
translation: Pleasing the Dhartarastras, hostility towards us, indifference considered a flaw, served like a shadow's trace.

sloka: apavādādabhītasya samasya guṇadoṣayoḥ | asadvṛtterahovṛttaṃ durvibhāvaṃ vidheriva ||
translation: Overcoming fear, for a steadfast person, it is as per the rule to judge between merit and demerit, between unrighteous behavior and righteous conduct; this is hard to attain.

sloka: dhvaṃseta hṛdayaṃ sadyaḥ paribhūtasya me paraiḥ | yadyamarṣaḥ pratīkāraṃ bhujālambaṃ na lambhayet ||
translation: The heart is instantly destroyed for one who has been overwhelmed by my foes, if impatience does not grasp the support of the arm as a countermeasure.

sloka: avadhūyāribhirnītā hariṇaistulyavṛttitām | anyonyasyāpi jihrīmaḥ kiṃ punaḥ sahavāsinām ||
translation: Even among rival deer sharing equal habits, they still tolerate each other; what then to speak of associates?

sloka: śaktivaikalyanamrasya niḥsāratvāllaghīyasaḥ | janmino mānahīnasya tṛṇasya ca samā gatiḥ ||
translation: The fate of a person lacking strength and self-respect is no different from that of a straw; such a one never experiences the true essence of their own power.

sloka: alaṅghyaṃ tattadudvīkṣyaṃ yadyaduccairmahībhṛtām | priyatāṃ jyāyasīṃ mā gānmahatāṃ kena tuṅgatā ||
translation: That should not be transgressed, scrutinizing it carefully, whatever is unattainable for the arrogant leaders; do not choose a more dear greatness over it, by any means.

sloka: tāvadāśrīyate lakṣmyā tāvadasya sthiraṃ yaśaḥ | puruṣastāvadevāsau yāvanmānānna hīyate ||
translation: As long as one is adorned with prosperity, for that long his fame remains steady; indeed, he is a virtuous person up until he does not become egotistical.

sloka: sa pumānarthavajjanmā yasya nāmni puraḥsthite | nānyāmaṅgulimabhyeti saṃkhyāyāmudyatāṅguliḥ ||
translation: That man, whose name is established before birth, does not exceed the number of fingers he has kept ready for counting.

sloka: durāsadavanajyāyāngamyastuṅgo'pi bhūdharaḥ | na jahāti mahaujaskaṃ mānaprāṃśumalaṅghyatā ||
translation: Even the lofty mountain of the earth, which is harder to reach, does not abandon its great strength, majesty, and honor that cannot be overstepped.

sloka: gurunkurvanti te vaṃśyānanvarthā tairvasuṃdharā | yeṣāṃ yaśāṃsi śubhrāṇi hrepayantīndumaṇḍalam ||
translation: By honoring their gurus, those descendants earn fame that eclipses even the brilliance of the moon.

sloka: udāharaṇamāśīḥṣu prathame te manasvinām | śuṣke'śanirivāmarṣo yairarātiṣu pātyate ||
translation: In the very first instance, among the intelligent ones, those who have controlled their senses are comparable to a tree that has shed its leaves, in their ability to remain unruffled by disturbances.

sloka: na sukhaṃ prārthaye nārthamudanvadvīcicañcalam | nānityatāśanestrasyanviviktaṃ brahmaṇaḥ padam ||
translation: I do not pray for fleeting happiness or for an unsteady, constantly changing object of desire. I seek the detached and serene abode of Brahman, free from transient sorrows.

sloka: pramārṣṭumayaśaḥpaṅkamiccheyaṃ chadmanā kṛtam | vaidhavyatāpitārātivanitālocanāmbubhiḥ ||
translation: Desiring to conquer the marshy (pramārṣṭum paṅkam) and conquer (ayaśaḥ), this deed (kṛtam) was done by Chadmana. The eyes (locana) of the woman (vanitā), pained (tāpita) by her husband's absence (arāti), were filled (ambubhiḥ) with tears.

sloka: apahasye'thavā sadbhiḥ pramādo vāstu me dhiyaḥ | asthānavihitāyāsaḥ kāmaṃ jihretu mā bhavān ||
translation: Keep your secret from the virtuous, or reveal it; it's my wish that causes your dilemma does not overcome you, so that you don't abandon your endeavor due to fear of its consequences.

sloka: vaṃśalakṣmīmanuddhṛtya samucchedena vidviṣām | nirvāṇamapi manye'hamantarāyaṃ jayaśriyaḥ ||
translation: Extracting Laksmi from her dynastic line, I think I have achieved liberation from being an obstacle to Jayashri.

sloka: ajanmā puruṣastāvadgatāsustṛṇameva vā | yāvanneṣubhirādatte viluptamaribhiryaśaḥ ||
translation: Until when, oh mortal, will you remain like mere grass, indifferent to the lure of sense objects? Having been fully consumed by them, your reputation will be lost.

sloka: anirjayena dviṣatāṃ yasyāmarṣaḥ praśāmyati | puruṣoktiḥ kathaṃ tasminbrūhi tvaṃ hi tapodhana ||
translation: How can one's anger be appeased who cannot be conquered by enemies, O wealthy in austerities? Explain about that man.

sloka: kṛtaṃ puruṣaśabdena jātimātrāvalambinā | yo'ṅgīkṛtaguṇaiḥ ślāghyaḥ savismayamudāhṛtaḥ ||
translation: Recognized as praiseworthy, one who upholds himself by the designation of "puruṣa" (person) alone and by his inherent qualities, has been declared as established by his own actions.

sloka: grasamānamivaujāṃsi sadasā gauraveritam | nāma yasyābhinandanti dviṣo'pi sa pumānpumān ||
translation: Like powerful elephants, who is he that even enemies praise by name, respected by all and adorned with majesty?

sloka: yathāpratijñaṃ dviṣatāṃ yudhi praticikīrṣayā | mamaivādhyeti nṛpatistṛṣyanniva jalāñjaleḥ ||
translation: Like a thirsty king would drink water, my soldiers, with determination to fulfill their promise in battle, each individually come to me (in terms of loyalty/devotion).

sloka: sa vaṃśasyāvadātasya śaśāṅkasyeva lāñchanam | kṛcchreṣu vyarthayā yatra bhūyate bharturājñayā ||
translation: Like the distinguishing feature of the moon's dynasty, it [this] becomes pointless to endure hardships by the command of the master where it is used in vain in difficult situations.

sloka: kathaṃ vādīyatāmarvāṅmunitā dharmarodhinī | āśramānukramaḥ pūrvaiḥ smaryate na vyatikramaḥ ||
translation: How should one properly speak, according to ancient teachings, in a manner that upholds dharma, while following the traditional sequence in ascending through the ashramas? There should be no transgression of this established order.

sloka: āsaktā dhūriyaṃ rūḍhā jananī dūragā ca me | tiraskaroti svātantryaṃ jyāyāṃścācāravānnṛpaḥ ||
translation: This clumped earth and distant mother reject my independent nature, as do this wind and this fire, along with this noble behavior.

sloka: svadharmamanurundhante nātikramamarātibhiḥ | palāyante kṛtadhvaṃsā nāhavānmānaśālinaḥ ||
translation: Neglecting one's own duty, they should not overstep the boundaries of respect; those who are destroyed by their own arrogance will retreat when their duties are ruined, not one who is truly brave.

sloka: vicchinnābhravilāyaṃ vā vilīye nagamūrdhani | ārādhya vā sahasrākṣamayaśaḥśalyamuddhare ||
translation: Worshiping Sahasraksha, with a serpent's hood above his head, who has vanquished the assault of vicchinnabhravilaya (a type of disturbance) and vilīya (another type of disturbance).

sloka: ityuktavantaṃ parirabhya dorbhyāṃ tanūjamāviṣkṛtadivyamūrtiḥ | aghopaghātaṃ maghavā vibhūtyai bhavodbhavārādhanamādideśa ||
translation: Embracing his son, revealed in divine form, [Indra] commanded, "Perform acts that enhance your and others' prosperity, not those that cause harm."

sloka: prīte pinākini mayā saha lokapālairlokatraye'pi vihitāprativāryavīryaḥ | lakṣmīṃ samutsukayitāsi bhṛśaṃ pareṣāmuccārya vācamiti tena tirobabhūve ||
translation: Having been commanded by me along with the guardians of the three worlds, with irresistible power, to make Lakshmi eager, you loudly proclaimed these words in my presence. Therefore, you became hidden.

sloka: atha vāsavasya vacanena ruciravadanastrilocanam | klāntirahitamabhirādhayituṃ vidhivattapāṃsi vidadhe dhanaṃjayaḥ ||
translation: Then, at Indra's behest, Dhanañjaya bestowed riches upon the three-eyed, handsome, and blemishless one, capable of being worshipped with proper rites, as ordered.

sloka: abhiraśmimāli vimalasya dhṛtajayadhṛteranāśuṣaḥ | tasya bhuvi bahutithāstithayaḥ pratijagmurekacaraṇaṃ niṣīdataḥ ||
translation: The one, pure and adorned with steady rays, having conquered enemy host, all seek the shelter of his feet on earth, approaching him one by one.

sloka: vupurindriyopatapaneṣu satatamasukheṣu pāṇḍavaḥ | vyāpa nagapatiriva sthiratāṃ mahatāṃ hi dhairyamavibhāvyavaibhavam ||
translation: The Pandava, steadfast like a serpent king, consistently rejoices in the pleasures of sense control, demonstrating great courage that is both unseen and unparalleled.

sloka: na papāta saṃnihitapaktisurabhiṣu phaleṣu mānasam | tasya sucini śiśire ca payasyamṛtāyate hi sutapaḥ sukarmaṇām ||
translation: The pure-minded Sutapa does not fall from his steadfastness even when offered fragrant flowers' rewards, for in him, the water in the mind turns into amrita.

sloka: na visismiye na viṣasāda muhuralasatāṃ na cādade | sattvamurudhṛti rajastamasī na hataḥ sma tasya hataśaktipelave ||
translation: I don't marvel at the poison's (*viṣa*) power (*śakti*) that doesn't wane (*hataḥ*) even for a moment (*muhuḥ ala satām*) in those who possess (*pelave*) firmness (*dhṛti*) in sattva, rajas, or tamas (*sattvam, rajas, tamasī*). I don't see (*na visismiye*) any decrease (*hataḥ*) in their strength (*śakti*) either.

sloka: tapasā kṛśaṃ vapuruvāha sa vijitajagantrayodayam | trāsajananamapi tattvavidāṃ kimivāsti yanna sukaraṃ manasvibhiḥ ||
translation: Through austere discipline, one attains a lean physique and has subdued the senses; even for the knowers of truth, what is easier than this for the intelligent?

sloka: jvalato'nalādanuniśīthamadhikarucirambhasāṃ nidheḥ | dhairyaguṇamavajayanvijayī dadṛśe samunnatataraḥ sa śailataḥ ||
translation: The victorious one, shining brightly from the depths of the fire, surpassing even the quality of steadfastness, was seen rising taller than a mountain.

sloka: japataḥ sadā japamupāṃśu vadanamabhito visāribhiḥ | tasya daśanakiraṇaiḥ śuśubhe pariveṣa bhīṣaṇamivārkamaṇḍalam ||
translation: The one who constantly recites [japataḥ] always [sadā], the continuous repetition [japam] of mantras [upāṃśu], illuminates [śuśubhe] with his radiant teeth [tasya daśanakiraṇaiḥ] the surrounding area, just like the terrifying [bhīṣaṇam iva] sun's disk [arka maṇḍalam].

sloka: kavacaṃ sa bibhradupavītapadanihitasajyakārmukaḥ | śailapatiriva mahendradhanuḥparivītabhīmagahano vididyute ||
translation: Wearing a coat of armor, bow, and arrow, adorned with upavita, sacred thread, and holding a spear, like Indra's mountain-bow, moving through the dense forest, shining in lightning.

sloka: praviveśa gāmiva kṛśasya niyamasavanāya gacchataḥ | tasya padavinamito himavāngurutāṃ nayanti hi guṇā na saṃhatiḥ ||
translation: Just as the slender stalk of a plant bends towards the earth, seeking to take root, similarly, the qualities of a disciplined person lead them towards the greatness of Himavat (a mountain range identified with Himalayas). This does not happen due to a collection of qualities, but rather due to each quality leading them in that direction.

sloka: parikīrṇamudyatabhujasya bhuvanavivare durāsadam | jyotirupari śiraso vitataṃ jagṛhe nijānmunidivaukasāṃ pathaḥ ||
translation: The resplendent one, with raised arms, has grasped the path of seers and celestial beings, encompassing the expanse of the world, making it difficult to look at, shining from above the head.

sloka: rajanīṣu rājatanayasya bahulasamaye'pi dhāmabhiḥ | bhinnatisiranikaraṃ na jahe śaśiraśmisaṃgamayujā nabhaḥśriyā ||
translation: Even during numerous royal gatherings in the night, the moon's radiance does not abandon its union with the sky, nor does it leave the group of stars.

sloka: mahatā mayūkhanicayena śamitaruci jiṣṇujanmanā | hrītamiva nabhasi vītamale na virājate sma vapuraṃśumālinaḥ ||
translation: With a large collection of peacock feathers, resembling the sky free from impurities, neither does the radiant and pure peacock's plumage shine nor does it appear to be so.

sloka: tamudīritāruṇajaṭāṃśumadhiguṇaśarāsanaṃ janāḥ | rudramanuditalalāṭadṛśaṃ dadṛśurmimanthiṣumivāsurīḥ purīḥ ||
translation: The people have seen the Rudra, whose forehead was marked by the reddish, thick and waved hair, who was extolled by hymns, and who was endowed with superior qualities and weapons.

sloka: marutāṃ patiḥ svidahimāṃśuruta pṛthuśikhaḥ śikhī tapaḥ | taptumasukaramupakramate na jano'yamityavayaye sa tāpasaiḥ ||
translation: Is the lord of the Maruts, Indra, who has a wide expanse of clouds and a tuft of hair, the one who begins to undergo austerities that are difficult to perform? Mankind does not know this to be true in the case of one who is ever youthful and always engaged in asceticism.

sloka: na dadāha  bhūruhavanāni haritanayadhāma dūragam | na sma nayati pariśoṣamapaḥ susahaṃ babhūva na ca siddhatāpasaiḥ ||
translation: The earth did not burn up the dry sacrificial fires, nor did it direct them far away; it did not become dry nor did it make others so; it did not become easily irritated, but rather remained calm and unperturbed, nor did it become exhausted by austerities.

sloka: vinayaṃ guṇā iva vivekamapanayabhidaṃ nayā iva | nyāyamavadhaya ivāśaraṇāḥ śaraṇaṃ yayuḥ śivamatho maharṣayaḥ ||
translation: Seeking refuge in the auspicious (śiva) like the great sages (mahāṛṣayaḥ), have resorted (yayuḥ) to him who has discipline (vinayam) similar to virtues (guṇāḥ), who is like a guide (nayāḥ) in discernment (viveka) and renunciation (apanaaya), and who is established in justice (nyāyam) without any protection (aśaraṇāḥ).

sloka: parivītamaṃśubhirudastadinakaramayūkhamaṇḍalaiḥ | śaṃbhumupahatadṛśaḥ sahasā na ca te nicāyitumabhiprasehire ||
translation: Surrounded by powerful arms, but looking weakened by time, lord Shambhu does not hesitate to assemble his forces suddenly.

sloka: atha bhūtabhavyabhavadīśamabhimukhayituṃ kṛtastavāḥ | tatra mahasi dadṛśuḥ puruṣaṃ kamanīyavigrahamayugmalocanam ||
translation: Having been determined to directly face the Lord of all that exists, has existed, and will exist, the great seers saw there the puruṣa with a desirable form and diadem adorned eyes.

sloka: kakude vṛṣasya kṛtabāhumakṛśapariṇāhaśālini | sparśasukhamanubhavantamumākucayugmamaṇḍala ivārdracandane ||
translation: Feeling pleasure at the touch, resembling Uma's twin breasts, slender-waisted one, who has skillfully milked the elephant (Lord Shiva), who is in this world.

sloka: sthitamunnate tuhinaśailaśirasi bhuvanātivartinā | sādrijaladhijalavāhapathaṃ sadigaśnuvānamiva viśvamojasā ||
translation: Resting firmly on the peak of Mount Tuhina, transcending the world, like the all-delighting course of rivers, merging with the ocean.

sloka: anujānumadhyamavasaktavitatavapuṣā mahāhinā | lokamakhilamiva bhūmibhṛtā ravitejasāmavadhinādhiveṣṭitam ||
translation: Following closely behind, borne aloft by a powerful, expansive form, like the sun's radiance illuminating all the world, enveloping it from every side.

sloka: pariṇāhinā tuhinarāśiviśadamupavītasūtratām | nītamuragamanurañjayatā śitinā galena vilasanmarīcinā ||
translation: Adorned with a sacred thread that has been purified by a ritual bath, a person, who has steadily practiced self-control, makes a serpent-like moving object delightful with their cool and shining gaze.

sloka: plutamālatīsitakapālakumudamavaruddhamūrdhajam | śeṣamiva surasaritpayasāṃ śirasā visāri śaśidhāma bibhratam ||
translation: Wearing on his head a moon-crest jeweled like a fully blown Mālatī flower, shining like the remaining part of a milky way for the celestial rivers, adorned with.

sloka: bahubhiśca bāhubhirahīnabhujagavalayairvirājitam | candanatarubhirivālaghubhiḥ prabalāyatairmalayamedinībhṛtam ||
translation: Adorned with many arms, shining with serpentine bracelets, endowed with strong and sturdy balance, and covered with fragrant sandalwood paste, [it/she/he] stands out.

sloka: munayastato'bhimukhametya nayanavinimeṣanoditāḥ | pāṇḍutanayatapasā janitaṃ jagatāmaśarma bhṛśamācacakṣire ||
translation: The sages, having turned their gaze toward him, revealed, with pupils unblinking, the great comfort for the world, produced by Pandu's son's austerities.

sloka: tarasaiva ko'pi bhuvanaikapuruṣa puruṣastapasyati | jyotiramalavapuṣo'pi raverabhibhūya vṛtra iva bhīmavigrahaḥ ||
translation: Who in the world, similarly to how Indra overcame Vrtra, can be found with a shining, spotless form, glowing like the sun, and who is observing austere practices?

sloka: sa dhanurmaheṣudhi bibharti kavacamasimuttamaṃ jaṭāḥ | valkamarajinamiti citramidaṃ munitāvirodhi na ca nāsya rājate ||
translation: He, the superior wielder of the mighty bow, wears a helmet, a coat of mail, and a crest of matted hair. Adorned with a garland of tiger claws, he is a marvel to behold, one who is not opposed by even the wise. Yet, royal authority does not exist in him.

sloka: calane'vaniścalati tasya karaṇaniyame sadiṅmukham | stambhamanubhavati śāntamarudgrahatārakāgaṇayutaṃ nabhastalam ||
translation: In the act of moving, his limbs become steady; his face is always serene. He experiences stillness, like a mass of clouds filled with calm winds, in his navel region.

sloka: sa tadojasā vijitasāramamaraditijopasaṃhitam | viśvamidamapidadhāti purā kimivāsti yanna tapasāmaduṣkaram ||
translation: With his supreme power, having vanquished his foes, like Indra did to Diti's son, he (such a one) in the past has established this entire world, which was not previously achievable through any effortless or unchallenging austerity.

sloka: vijigīṣate yadi jaganti yugapadatha saṃjihīrṣati | prāptumabhavamabhivāñchati vā vayamasya no viṣahituṃ kṣamā rucaḥ ||
translation: If one aspires to conquer (\vijigīṣate) this world (\jaganti) all at once (\yugapat) and strives hard (\sañjihīrṣati) to achieve (\prāptum) that state (\abhavam), then they have the capacity (\kṣamā) to endure (\viṣahitum) this, referring to the hardship, rather than us (\naḥ) being incapable. Such (\vā) an intent (\rucaḥ) is indeed admirable.

sloka: kimupekṣase kathaya nātha  na tava viditaṃ na kiṃcana | trātumalamabhayadārhasi nastvayi mā sma śāsati bhavatparābhavaḥ ||
translation: Why do you ignore, lord, what is not known to you and what is only slightly known? You should be able to protect us from great fear. Do not let your own downfall threaten you.

sloka: iti gāṃ vidhāya virateṣu muniṣu vacanaṃ samādade | bhinnajaladhijalanādaguru dhvanayandiśāṃ vivaramandhakāntakaḥ ||
translation: Having arranged the song, he resolved among the ascetics who were practiced in restraint; the breaker of the delusion caused by the waves of the ocean of Samsara, he proclaimed his teachings, dispelling the dense darkness, like the resounding sun illuminating all directions.

sloka: badarītapovananivāsaniratamavagāta mānyathā | dhāturudayanidhane jagatāṃ naramaṃśamādipuruṣasya gāṃ gatam ||
translation: Having taken up residence in the tranquil abode of Badari vana, otherwise known as the forest of spiritual practice, the universal being's fragment, the human, has descended to the earthly realm, residing in the womb, the source of all physical elements.

sloka: dviṣataḥ parāsisiṣureṣa sakalabhuvanābhitāpinaḥ | krāntakuliśakaravīryabalānmadupāsanaṃ vihitavānmahattapaḥ ||
translation: A great ascetic, who has undertaken to worship the powerful and crushing weapon of Kranta, has been established to alleviate the suffering of all worlds, has become an object of hatred for enemies.

sloka: ayamacyutaśca vacanena sarasiruhajanmanaḥ prajāḥ | pātumasuranidhanena vibhū bhūvamabhyupetya manujeṣu tiṣṭhataḥ ||
translation: This pure one, Acyuta, by his words, gives protection to the offspring of those who take birth from the lotus. With his power, he has entered the minds of people and dwells there.

sloka: surakṛtyametadavagamya niṣuṇamiti mūkadānavaḥ | hantumabhipatati pāṇḍusutaṃ tvarayā tadatra saha gamyatāṃ mayā ||
translation: The virtuous one, not easily approachable, a silent demon, approaches swiftly to kill the son of Pandu. Let's go there together to stop him, I suggest.

sloka: vivare'pi nainamanigūḍhamabhibhavitumeṣa pārayan | pāpaniratiraviśaṅkitayā vijayaṃ vyavasyati varāhamāyayā ||
translation: Even in a battle, this resolute warrior does not underestimate an unnamed enemy; instead, they firmly decide victory through the power of their own cleverness, overcoming any feelings of doubt or fear.

sloka: nihate viḍambitakirātanṛpativapuṣā ripau mayā | muktaniśitaviśikhaḥ prasabhaṃ mṛgayāvivādamayamācariṣyati ||
translation: Upon defeating the deceptive king Kirāta, I will swiftly and aggressively hunt like a hunter, releasing my sharpened weapon, after being set free from this assumed form.

sloka: tamasā nipīḍitakṛśasya virahitasahāyasaṃpadaḥ | sattvavihitamatulaṃ bhujayorbalamasya paśyata mṛdhe'dhikupyataḥ ||
translation: Witness, in battle, the immense strength of the one who is lean due to being oppressed by tamas, lacking companionship, and devoid of wealth; such is the effect of sattva taking precedence.

sloka: iti tānudāramanunīya viṣamaharicandanālinā | gharmajanitapulakena lasadgajamauktikāvaliguṇena vakṣasā ||
translation: Wearing a garland of equal parts of fragrant candana and shining pearls, thus, those with generous breasts, have been adorned, overcome by heat-generated passion.

sloka: vadanena puṣpitalatāntaniyamitavilambimaulinā | bibhradaruṇanayanena rucaṃ śikhipicchalāñchitakapolabhittinā ||
translation: Adorned with a reddened face, maintaining control over the creepers of his curly hair, and with his arched eyebrows, he carries himself with a charming elegance.

sloka: bṛhadudvahajjaladanādi dhanurupahitaikamārgaṇam | meghanicaya iva saṃvavṛte ruciraḥ kirātapṛtanāpatiḥ śivaḥ ||
translation: The four-faced, elegantly adorned Lord Shiva, holding a thunderbolt-like weapon, has enveloped the world like a cloud, embracing all rivers, mountains, and clouds as his own.

sloka: anukūlamasya ca vicintya gaṇapatibhirāttavigrahaiḥ | śūlaparaśuśaracāpabhṛtairmahatī vanecaracamūrvinirmame ||
translation: Taking into consideration the arrangements of this [divine] figure's retinue, consisting of Gaṇapatis, along with their respective weaponries such as spears, axes, arrows, and bows, I caused to be erected a great and grand encampment.

sloka: viracayya kānanavibhāgamanugiramatheśvarājñayā | bhīmaninadapihitorubhuvaḥ parito'padiśya mṛgayāṃ pratasthire ||
translation: Ordered by the lord of the forest, who is also the lord of all beings, and who inspires awe, arrange the division of the forest, after marking the boundaries all around, and then set out for hunting.

sloka: kṣubhitābhiniḥsṛtavibhinnaśakunimṛgayūthaniḥkhanaiḥ | pūrṇapṛthuvanaguhāvivaraḥ sahasā bhayādiva rarāsa bhūdharaḥ ||
translation: With the sudden emergence of scared, agitated and scattered bird and animal groups from their dens in the full and expansive natural surroundings, a great earthquake-like event occurred.

sloka: na virodhinī ruṣamiyāya pathi mṛgavihaṅgasaṃhatiḥ | ghnanti sahajamapi bhūribhiyaḥ samamāgatāḥ sapadi vairamāpadaḥ ||
translation: A group of natural enemies, consisting of animals and birds, does not hesitate to attack even a non-aggressor who happens to be on their path.

sloka: camarīgaṇairgaṇabalasya balavati bhaye'pyupasthite | vaṃśavitatiṣu viṣaktapṛthupriyabālavāladhibhirādade dhṛtiḥ ||
translation: Even in the presence of a fearsome elephant army, the strength of unity lies in maintaining steadfastness through the use of affectionate encouragement from loved ones, however young or small in stature they may be.

sloka: harasainikāḥ pratibhaye'pi gajamadasugandhikesaraiḥ | svasthamabhidadṛśire sahasā pratibodhajṛmbhitamukhairmṛgādhipaiḥ ||
translation: Upon the approach of danger, even elephants smeared with musk become suddenly alert, lifting up their majestic faces.

sloka: bibharāṃbabhūvurapavṛttajaṭharaśapharīkulākulāḥ | paṅkaviṣamitataṭāḥ saritaḥ karirugṇacandanarasāruṇaṃ payaḥ ||
translation: Carrying the burden of waves, born from the cycle of changing seasons, rivers swell, mixing with the mud, their water turns poisonous, tinged with the color of clay, sandalwood, and saffron.

sloka: mahiṣakṣatāgurutamālanaladasurabhiḥ sadāgatiḥ | vyastaśukanibhaśilākusumaḥ praṇudanvavau vanasadāṃ pariśramam ||
translation: The fragrant breeze, constantly bringing coolness, always refreshing like sandalwood, kusumaka trees, and tamala, surabhi, and aguru; it dispels the fatigue of those residing in the forest.

sloka: mathitāmbhaso rayavikīrṇamṛditakadalīgavedhukāḥ | klāntajalaruhalatāḥ sarasīrvidadhe nidāgha iva sattvasaṃplavaḥ ||
translation: Like lotus flowers blossoming in a stirred pond, pure virtues bloom in a mind purified by knowledge, resembling a cool, peaceful lake.

sloka: iti cālayannacalasānuvanagahanajānumāpatiḥ | prāpa muditahariṇīdaśanakṣatavīrudhaṃ vasatimaindrasūnavīm ||
translation: Having reached, as lord of herdsman of cows that roam in the unfathomable forest, the abode adorned with the marks of the elephant's victory, he became joyful.

sloka: sa tamāsasāda ghananīlamabhimukhamupasthitaṃ muneḥ | potranikaṣaṇavibhinnabhuvaṃ danujaṃ dadhānamatha saukaraṃ vapuḥ ||
translation: That (sa) dense darkness (tamāsasāda ghananīlam) facing (abhimukham) appeared (upasthitam) before the sage (muneḥ), resembling (vapuḥ) a cloud (danujam) split by the vision (potranikaṣaṇavibhinnabhuvaṃ) of a small creature (potranika), similar to (atha) a pig (saukaram) in form (rūpaṃ).

sloka: kacchānte surasarito nidhāya senāmanvītaḥ sa katipayaiḥ kirātavaryaiḥ | pracchannastarugahanaiḥ sagulmajālairlakṣmīvānanupadamasya saṃpratasthe ||
translation: Who in the world, after laying down his weapons near the river at twilight, has stealthily advanced, accompanied by a few chieftains of the Kiratas, shrouded by dense fog and cobwebs, eager for a chance at the hidden treasure?

sloka: vapuṣā parameṇa bhūdharāṇāmatha saṃbhāvyaparākramaṃ vibhede | mṛgamāśu vilokayāṃcakāra sthiradaṃṣṭrogramukhaṃ mahendrasūnuḥ ||
translation: With his supreme form, the valiant son of Indra, at that moment, made out the fleet-footed beast's unwavering tusks and fierce mouth.

sloka: sphuṭabaddhasaṭonnatiḥ sa dūrādabhidhāvannavadhīritānyakṛtyaḥ | jayamicchati tasya jātaśaṅke manasīmaṃ muhurādade vitarkam ||
translation: With clear resolve and unflinching determination, he who is advancing towards achieving great feats from a distance, even his established duties do not deter him; he is eager for victory, as anxiety arises in his mind, he constantly ponders over this.

sloka: ghanapotravidīrṇaśālamūlo nibiḍaskandhanikāṣarugṇavapraḥ | ayamekacaro'bhivartate māṃ samarāyeva samājuhūṣamāṇaḥ ||
translation: With a thunderous roar, like a powerful elephant, advancing towards me, this one, who has uprooted the foundation of the forest of palm trees, who is adorned with compact tufts of hair and who shines with a garland of ashoka blossoms, seems like the personification of war itself.

sloka: iha vītabhayāstaponubhāvājjahati vyālamṛgāḥ pareṣu vṛttim | mayi tāṃ sutarāmayaṃ vidhatte vikṛtiḥ kiṃ nu bhavediyaṃ nu māyā ||
translation: In this world, having overcome fear through discipline, the beasts of vice abandon their nature and adopt a virtuous path in others. What could their transformation be, if they were to take refuge in me, compared to this illusion?

sloka: athavaiṣa kṛtajñayeva pūrvaṃ bhṛśamāsevitayā ruṣā na muktaḥ | avadhūya virodhinīḥ kimārānmṛgajātīrabhiyāti māṃ javena ||
translation: Is this one, who is beholden, still not released from intense anger, despite having been served faithfully in the past? What if he rushes at me like an elephant goaded by a mahout, driven by contrary urges?

sloka: na mṛgaḥ khalu ko'pyayaṃ jighāṃsuḥ skhalati hyatra tathā bhṛśaṃ mano me | vimalaṃ kaluṣībhavacca cetaḥ kathayatyeva hitaiṣiṇaṃ ripuṃ vā ||
translation: Indeed, no animal here suddenly lusts after its prey without faltering, while my mind, on the other hand, speaks of an enemy or a well-wisher without hesitation or impurity.

sloka: munirasmi nirāgasaḥ kuto me bhayamityeṣa na bhūtaye'bhimānaḥ | paravṛddhiṣu baddhamatsarāṇāṃ kimiva hyasti durātmanāmalaṅghyam ||
translation: I am a sage, free from desires, from whom does this fear come to me? This is not a concern for one's own welfare, but for those who are selfishly motivated, what is truly worthy for them, except for being disregarded by others?

sloka: danujaḥ svidayaṃ kṣapācaro vā vanaje neti balaṃ vatāsti sattve | abhibhūya tathā hi meghanīlaḥ skalaṃ kampayatīva śailarājam ||
translation: This nocturnal emissary of the Danavas, or else a forest-dweller, has strength that equals the wind. With his power, he can shake the king of mountains as if it were a mere tuft of cloud.

sloka: ayameva mṛgavyasatrakāmaḥ prahariṣyanmayi māyayā śamasthe | pṛthubhirdhvajinīravairakārṣīccakitodbhrāntamṛgāṇi kānanāni ||
translation: This very deer-longing hunter, controlled by his own illusion, has made agitated and bewildered deer roam in the forests, as if they were banner-waving elephants.

sloka: bahuśaḥ kṛtasatkṛtervidhātuṃ priyamicchannathavā suyodhanasya | kṣubhitaṃ vanagocarābhiyogādgaṇamāśiśriyadākulaṃ tiraścām ||
translation: Desiring to establish the arrangements that please Suyodhana, they hurriedly gathered together, disturbed, as a result of the excitement of the forest-dwelling warriors, even from afar.

sloka: avalīḍhasanābhiraśvasenaḥ prasabhaṃ khāṇḍavajātavedasā vā | pratikartumupāgataḥ samanyuḥ kṛtamanyuryadi vā vṛkodareṇa ||
translation: Having quickly assembled his forces, mighty Aśvasena, scorcher of foes, is set on averting the forest fire caused by Vedic rituals or by Vṛka; so too is Samanyu, if he has completed his assigned tasks or not.

sloka: balaśālitayā yathā tathā vā dhiyamucchedaparāmayaṃ dadhānaḥ | niyamena mayā nibarhaṇīyaḥ paramaṃ lābhamarātibhaṅgamāhuḥ ||
translation: With a gentle or harsh mind, whichever way, one who focuses their attention on the ultimate detachment, they say that such a person, through discipline, can attain the supreme gain that breaks the cycle of birth and death.

sloka: kuru tāta tapāṃsyamārgadāyī vijayāyetyalamanvaśānmunirmām | balinaśca vadhāddhṛte'sya śakyaṃ vratasaṃrakṣaṇamanyathā na kartum ||
translation: Oh son, make him embrace the path that bestows spiritual practices and victory. Even a strong person cannot protect this vow if they do not take up arms in its defense, quite impossible otherwise.

sloka: iti tena vicintya cāpanāma prathamaṃ pauruṣacihnamālalambe | upalabdhaguṇaḥ parasya bhede sacivaḥ śuddha ivādade ca bāṇaḥ ||
translation: Thus contemplating the chief personal emblem, named "cāpa" (bow), he found it pure, like a companion, coming across the other's distinguished qualities; he then respectfully offered it.

sloka: anubhāvavatā guru sthiratvādavisaṃvādi dhanurdhanaṃjayena | svabalavyasane'pi pīḍyamānaṃ guṇavanmitramivānatiṃ prapede ||
translation: Even when faced with his own weakness, a virtuous disciple, firm in his conduct like a steady archer, approaches adversity as if it were a friend, not letting it affect his duties.

sloka: pravikarṣaninādabhinnarandhraḥ padaviṣṭambhanipīḍitastadānīm | adhirohati gāṇḍivaṃ maheṣau sakalaḥ saṃśayamāruroha śailaḥ ||
translation: With the sound of the bowstring being violently drawn, the previously blocked passage is forcibly opened now. At this moment, the great-hearted hero masterfully lifts up his powerful Gandiva bow, as all doubts regarding the course of action are dispelled from his mind.

sloka: dadṛśe'tha savismayaṃ śivena sthirapūrṇāyatacāpamaṇḍalasthaḥ | racitastisṛṇāṃ purāṃ vithātuṃ vadhamātmeva bhayānakaḥ pareṣām ||
translation: Just then, Shiva, appearing fearsome as the one who can put an end to all beings, was seen by me, stationed on a steady, full and wide-spread bow, ready to release his arrow.

sloka: vicakarṣa ca saṃhiteṣuruccaiścaraṇāskandananāmitācalendraḥ | dhanurāyatabhogavāsukijyāvadanagranthivimuktavahni śaṃbhuḥ ||
translation: Drawing the arrow from his unflinching grasp, the unwavering ruler of mountains, Indra, endowed with immense strength, skillfully makes it ready on his bowstring, released by the serpent Vāsuki, who has shed his knots, as his fiery manifestation, Śambhu.

sloka: sa bhavasya bhavakṣayaikahetoḥ sitasapteśca vidhāsyatoḥ sahārtham | ripurāpa parābhavāya madhyaṃ prakṛtipratyayayorivānubandhaḥ ||
translation: He, the common link, binds together being and non-being, for the destruction and creation of existence; just as the mutual interdependence of cause and effect, like an enemy being destroyed in battle, or like the relationship between a cool breeze and its time of occurrence.

sloka: atha dīpitavārivāhavartmā ravavitrāsitavāraṇādavāryaḥ | nipapāta javādiṣuḥ pinākānmahato'bhrādiva vaidyutaḥ kṛśānuḥ ||
translation: Then, the lightning, resembling a feathered arrow of Shiva, pierced through the fast-moving clouds, shining brightly like a blazing fire, resembling a powerful weapon thrown by the sun.

sloka: vrajato'sya bṛhatpatatrajanmā kṛtatārkṣyopanipātavegaśaṅkaḥ | pratinādamahānmahoragāṇāṃ hṛdayaśrotrabhidutpapāta nādaḥ ||
translation: Upon his departure, a great sound arises from the hearts and ears of serpents, a sound that matches the swift descent of Garuda, caused by his fear.

sloka: nayanādiva śūlinaḥ pravṛttairmanaso'pyāśutaraṃ yataḥ piśaṅgaiḥ | vidadhe vilasattaḍillatābhaiḥ kiraṇairvyomani mārgaṇasya mārgaḥ ||
translation: The path of the arrow, starting from the eyes, quickly made gentle by the mind's inclinations, is adorned by the flashes of light, like a row of lightning, that resemble creepers in the sky.

sloka: apayandhanuṣaḥ śivāntikasthairvivaresadbhirabhikhyayā jihānaḥ | yugapaddadṛśai viśanvarāhaṃ tadupoḍhaiśca nabhaścaraiḥ pṛṣatkaḥ ||
translation: The one who has mastered self-control, standing near the sacred fig tree, is recognized by those who approach him respectfully, who, with his powerful gaze, causes the flying birds in the sky to fall down.

sloka: sa tamālanibhe ripau surāṇāṃ ghananīhāra ivāviṣaktavegaḥ | bhayaviplutamīkṣito nabhaḥsthairjagatīṃ grāha ivāpagāṃ jagāhe ||
translation: He, like a thundercloud charging against a dark storm cloud, resembling a planetoid moving among stars, advances upon the battlefield, gazed upon in terror by the heavens, as if swallowing up the earth.

sloka: sapadi priyarūpaparvarekhaḥ sitalohāgranakhaḥ khamāsasāda | kupitāntakatarjanāṅguliśrīrvyathayanprāṇabhṛtaḥ kapidhvajeṣuḥ ||
translation: Upon immediately seeing his beloved's image, his hair standing on end due to joy, holding a bow in his hand, the angry monkey king, with a gleaming coppery complexion, with a trimmed nail, with a reddened palm, draws back his bowstring, ready to release his arrow.

sloka: paramāstraparigrahorutejaḥ sphuradulkākṛti vikṣipanvaneṣu | sa javena patanparaḥśatānāṃ patatāṃ vrāta ivāravaṃ vitene ||
translation: The radiant splendor, wielder of supreme weapons, like a leader in battle, whirls around in the midst of falling troops, as if a flock of birds were swirling in the sky.

sloka: avibhāvitaniṣkramaprayāṇaḥ śamitāyāma ivātiraṃhasā saḥ | saha pūrvataraṃ nu cittavṛtterapatitvā nu cakāra lakṣyabhedam ||
translation: Having not previously ventured forth, he made himself restrained, like a dam. Then, deviating from his usual thought patterns, he set a new target.

sloka: sa vṛṣadhvajasāyakāvabhinnaṃ jayahetuḥ pratikāyameṣaṇīyam | laghu sādhayituṃ śaraḥ prasehe vidhinevārthamudīritaṃ prayatnaḥ ||
translation: This, being the cause of victory, resembles a distinguished elephant with a banner and a dart; an arrow, made light by proper means, is effortlessly used for the intended purpose.

sloka: avivekavṛthāśramāvivārthaṃ kṣayalobhāviva saṃśritānurāgam | vijigīṣumivānayapramādāvavasādaṃ viśikhau vininyatustam ||
translation: Mistaking the true nature of his hermitage, seeking to hastily gain profit, having taken refuge in greed, eager to acquire, unmindful, and prone to lapses, he has prepared a wretched state for himself.

sloka: atha dīrghatamaṃ tamaḥ pravekṣyansahasā rugṇarayaḥ sa saṃbhrameṇa | nipatantamivoṣṇaraśmimurvyāṃ valayībhūtataruṃ dharāṃ ca mene ||
translation: Advancing into the long, densest darkness, suddenly, as if pierced by a heated ray, he regarded the tree and earth as if they were transformed and bound.

sloka: sa gataḥ kṣitimuṣṇaśoṇitārdraḥ khuradaṃṣṭrāgranipātadāritāśmā | asubhiḥ kṣaṇamīkṣitendrasūnurvihitāmarṣagurudhvanirnirāse ||
translation: The thirsty elephant, having reached the water source, shakes off the heat, sweat, and dirt from his limbs, trunk, and forehead, as, in an instant, the anger of Indra's son is dispelled by the sound of his guru's voice.

sloka: sphuṭapauruṣamāpapāta pārthastamatha prājyaśaraḥ śaraṃ jighṛkṣuḥ | na tathā kṛtavedināṃ karipyanpriyatāmeti yathā kṛtāvadānaḥ ||
