translation: Like a flawless warrior, Partha, drawing his arrow, not delighting in the deeds of those who know the Vedas, thus goes about, just as a story unfolds according to its own course.

sloka: upakāra ivāsati prayuktaḥ sthitimaprāpya mṛge gataḥ praṇāśam | kṛtaśaktiravāṅmukho gurutvājjanitavrīḍa ivātmapaurupeṇa ||
translation: Acting like a helpful person, but having failed to achieve a stable position, similar to a deer, he has met his end; his own strength exhausted, appearing aimless, as if brought down by a heavier force, due to his inflated ego.

sloka: sa samuddharatā vicintya tena svarucaṃ kīrtimivottamāṃ dadhānaḥ | anuyukta iva svavārtamuccaiḥ parirebhe nu bhṛśaṃ vilocanābhyām ||
translation: Reflecting deeply, he/she raised/rescued [it/him/her]; thus bestowing an excellent reputation with [its/his/her] own radiance. Following orders, as if looking around attentively with both eyes, extremely.

sloka: tatra kārmukabhṛtaṃ mahābhujaḥ paśyati sma sahasā vanecaram | saṃnikāśayitumagrataḥ sthitaṃ śāsanaṃ kusumacāpavidviṣaḥ ||
translation: There, the powerful one, wielding a bow, suddenly saw in the forest a target suitable for shooting. Ready to take aim, he stood near it, holding a flower-decorated bow.

sloka: sa prayujya tanaye mahīpaterātmajātisadṛśīṃ kilānatim | sāntvapūrvamabhinītihetukaṃ vaktumitthamupacakrame vacaḥ ||
translation: Having engaged that son, the emperor himself, in a conversation resembling his own social class, began to speak in a conciliatory manner, with appropriate reasons, expressing his intention clearly.

sloka: śāntatā vinayayogi mānasaṃ bhūri dhāma vimalaṃ tapaḥ śrutam | prāha te nu sadṛśī divaukasāmanvavāyamavadātamākṛtiḥ ||
translation: The one who has control over his mind, who is deeply established in humility and simplicity, whose austerity is pure, and who has listened to the scriptures, has attained a divine form similar to the celestial beings.

sloka: dīpitastvamanubhāvasaṃpadā gauraveṇa laghayanmahībhṛtaḥ | rājse munirapiha kārayannādhipatyamiva śātamanyavam ||
translation: Illumined one, with brilliance you endowed, lightening the earth, a sage even in royal midst, silently establishing your dominion, as if natural.

sloka: tāpaso'pi vibhṛtāmupeyivānāspadaṃ tvamasi sarvasaṃpadām | dṛśyate hi bhavato vinā janairanvitasya sacivairiva dyutiḥ ||
translation: Even ascetics, endowed with austere practices, attain your presence, for you are the possessor of all prosperity. Indeed, your radiance is seen, just like a king's court, filled with ministers, without you (O Lord), being absent among people.

sloka: vismayaḥ ka iva vā jayaśriyā naiva muktirapi te davīyasī | īpsitasya na bhavedupāśrayaḥ kasya nirjitarajastamoguṇaḥ ||
translation: What wonder is it if he who seeks victory and prosperity is not free, nor does he find support in one who has vanquished the darkness of his own ignorance?

sloka: hrepayannahimatejasaṃ tviṣā sa tvamitthamupapannapaurupaḥ | hartumarhasi varāhabhedinaṃ nainamasmadadhipasya sāyakam ||
translation: You, who are radiant with the splendor of snow, should not try to untether this deer that has come so fittingly, it is not right for you, strong-armed one, to take away the arrow from our lord.

sloka: smaryate tanubhṛtāṃ sanātanaṃ nyāyyamācaritamuttamairnubhiḥ | dhvaṃsate yadi bhavādṛśastataḥ kaḥ prayātu vada tena vartmanā ||
translation: It is declared that the ancient, excellent way of conduct of those who inhabit a body endures, if it does not deteriorate due to the likes of you; then who, having gone that way, can declare?

sloka: tiṣṭhatāṃ tapasi puṇyamāsajansaṃpado'nuguṇayansukhaiṣiṇām | yogināṃ pariṇamanvimuktaye kena nāstu vinayaḥ satāṃ priyaḥ ||
translation: For those who engage in asceticism, seeking to increase their merit, what could be a more suitable virtue than humility, dear to the noble-minded, for facilitating their spiritual evolution?

sloka: nūnamatrabhavataḥ śarākṛtiṃ sarvathāyamanuyāti sāyakaḥ | so'yamityanupapannasaṃśayaḥ kāritastvamapathe padaṃ yayā ||
translation: Surely, an arrow, following its inherent nature, always reaches its target in all circumstances. This is beyond doubt, what will you do in this matter?

sloka: anyadīyaviśikhe na kevalaṃ niḥspṛhasya bhavitavyamāhṛte | nighnataḥ paranibarhitaṃ mṛgaṃ vrīḍitavyamapi te sacetasaḥ ||
translation: For one who desires higher knowledge, it is not only necessary to renounce cravings, but also to feel shame when harming even an animal, if one has a discerning mind.

sloka: saṃtataṃ niśamayanta utsukā yaiḥ prayānti mudamasya mūrayaḥ | kīrtitāni hasite'pi tāni yaṃ vrīḍayanti caritāni māninam ||
translation: Recounting constantly with excitement, those who set out, are embarrassed by the actions known for their fame and censure, even when laughed at, of this prideful one.

sloka: anyadopamiva sa svakaṃ guṇaṃ khyāpayetkathamadhṛṣṭatājaḍaḥ | ucyate sa khalu kāryavattayā dhigvibhinnabudhasetumarthitām ||
translation: "How can one who is insensitive and devoid of shame boastfully declare his own quality as if it were unparalleled? Such behavior is certainly unbecoming of a wise person seeking success."

sloka: durvacaṃ tadatha mā sma bhūnmṛgastvayyasau yadakariṣyadojasā | nainamāśu yadi vāhinīpatiḥ pratyapatsyata śitena patriṇā ||
translation: "Don't utter harsh words towards him, for if this lord of the herd, instigated by envy, were to act against you, he would not easily be stopped by even a powerful river, flowing with icy waters."

sloka: ko nvimaṃ harituraṅgamāyudhastheyasīṃ dadhatamaṅgasaṃhatim | vegavattaramṛte camūpaterhantumarhati śareṇa daṃṣṭriṇam ||
translation: Who now can, with a weapon in hand, approach and confront this green-colored, elephantine form that moves swiftly like death itself?

sloka: mitramiṣṭamupakāri saṃśaye medinīpatirayaṃ tathā ca te | taṃ virodhya bhavatā nirāsi mā sañjanaikavasatiḥ kṛtajñatā ||
translation: Regarding the friend who is dear for his helpfulness, if there is doubt about the ruler of the earth and wealth, then, having confronted him, do not quickly become ungrateful and forgetful of your duty.

sloka: labhyamekasukṛtena durlabhā rakṣitāramasurakṣyabhūtayaḥ | svantamantavirasā jigīṣatāṃ mitralābhamanu lābhasaṃpadaḥ ||
translation: Able to be attained through a single virtuous act, yet hard to find, is a protector who can safeguard us from enemies. Eagerly seeking such a friend, who is also a boon and a fortune, is the wise course of action.

sloka: cañcalaṃ vasu nitāntamunnatā medinīmapi harantyarātayaḥ | bhūdharasthiramupeyamāgataṃ māvamaṃsta suhṛdaṃ hīpatim ||
translation: Even the mobile wealth, the limitless sky, and the lofty earth are seized by time. Here has come the steadfast ruler, do not despise your well-wisher and lord.

sloka: jetumeva bhavatā tapasyate nāyudhāni dadhate mumukṣavaḥ | prāpsyate ca sakalaṃ mahībhṛtā saṃgatena tapasaḥ phalaṃ tvayā ||
translation: Aspirant, you practice austerities alone, without weapons, for the purpose of conquest. The great lord will grant you everything through the power of your asceticism.

sloka: vājibhūmiribharājakānanaṃ santi ratnanicayāśca bhūriśaḥ | kāñcanena kimivāsya patriṇā kevalaṃ na sahate vilaṅghanam ||
translation: On the earth, indeed, there exist abundant elephants, royal groves, and treasures. With gold, can one of its parts alone endure being lifted?

sloka: sāvalepamupalipsite parairabhyupaiti vikṛtiṃ rajasyapi | arthitastu na mahānsamīhate jīvitaṃ kimu dhanaṃ dhanāyitum ||
translation: Even in pursuit of wealth, one does not adopt dishonest methods like bribing others; for, even though life and wealth may be lost, one should not lose one's good reputation, especially a great person who has the aspiration for a successful and virtuous life.

sloka: tattadīyaviśikhātisarjanādastu vāṃ guru yadṛcchayāgatam | rāghavaplavagarājayoriva prema yuktamitaretarāśrayam ||
translation: That, having emerged from your own crest jewel, has come to you by the will of the guru, like the love of Raghava, Plavaga, and the king - united in mutual support.

sloka: nābhiyoktumanṛtaṃ tvamiṣyase yastapasviviśikheṣu cādaraḥ | santi bhūbhṛti śarā hi naḥ pare ye parākramavasūni vajriṇaḥ ||
translation: One who does not resort to untruth, will you witness, O you who are capable in austerities, being attentive among ascetics; there are in this world, indeed, arrows like their powerful offspring, belonging to those who possess supreme strength.

sloka: mārgaṇairatha tava prayojanaṃ nāthase kimu patiṃ na bhūbhṛtaḥ | tvadvidhaṃ suhṛdametya so'rthinaṃ kiṃ na yacchati vijitya medinīm ||
translation: With the purpose of seeking (atha), O lord (nathase), what need is there (kimu) for you to obtain (patim) a ruler (bhubhrtah) through arrows (marganaih)? For, once he has conquered (vijitya) the earth (medini), what worthy person (arthinam) would not give himself (yacchati) to someone like you (tvat), who is a well-wisher (suhrdam) such as this?

sloka: tena sūrirupakāritādhanaḥ kartumicchati na yācitaṃ vṛthā | sīdatāmanubhavannivārthināṃ veda yatpraṇayabhaṅgavedanām ||
translation: Impelled by that revered one's noble deeds, he does not wish to perform the requested duty in vain. The knower of the true nature of things restrains his senses, for he has realized that emotions towards the breaking of vows bring about suffering.

sloka: śaktirarthapatiṣu svayaṃgrahaṃ prema kārayati vā niratyayam | kāraṇadvayamidaṃ nirasyataḥ prārthanādhikabale vipatphalā ||
translation: Power, when applied to attaining wealth, itself brings about love, unfailingly. This result arises from the combination of two causes: increased fervor in prayer, and greater strength in one's efforts.

sloka: astravedamadhigamya tattvataḥ kasya ceha bhujavīryaśālinaḥ | jāmadagnyamapahāya gīyate tāpaseṣu caritārthamāyudham ||
translation: Having acquired the true meaning of the scripture concerning weapons, who in this world is capable enough to wield such weapons, abandoning Jamadagnya? His deeds are celebrated among ascetics.

sloka: abhyaghāni municāpalāttvayā yanmṛgaḥ kṣitipateḥ parigrahaḥ | akṣamiṣṭa tadayaṃ pramādyatāṃ saṃvṛṇoti khalu doṣamajñatā ||
translation: The unsteady muni (sage) indeed reveals the fault of seizing the king's property, having been inebriated by that which is most coveted.

sloka: janmaveṣatapasāṃ virodhinīṃ mā kṛthāḥ punaramūmapakriyām | āpadetyubhayalokadūṣaṇī vartamānamapathe hi durmatim ||
translation: Do not, who obstructs the path of those who have taken birth, practiced austerities, and possess virtues, commit such a mistake again. The one who treads the path that harms both worlds is indeed evil.

sloka: yaṣṭamicchasi pitṝnna sāṃprataṃ saṃvṛto'rcicayiṣurdivaukasaḥ | dātumeva padavīmapi kṣamaḥ kiṃ mṛge'ṅga viśikhaṃ nyavīviśaḥ ||
translation: The one who, desiring to give, is now encircled by his forefathers, has become fit to offer the sacred oblation, even though he may be a mortal; what has he inserted into the deer's body?

sloka: sajjano'si vijahīhi cāpalaṃ sarvadā ka iva vā sahiṣyate | vāridhīniva yugāntavāyavaḥ kṣobhayantyanibhṛtā gurūnapi ||
translation: Are you always enduring like a stable river even at the time of world's destruction, or will you succumb to being unsteady, just as the wind disturbs even heavy objects, including the gurus?

sloka: astravedavidayaṃ mahīpatiḥ parvatīya iti māvajīgaṇaḥ | gopituṃ bhuvamimāṃ marutvatā śailavāsamanunīya lambhitaḥ ||
translation: The lord of the earth, identified as "Parvatīya," keeps a distance from the scriptures of weaponry, being absorbed in protecting this earth, like a wind-god, dwelling in the mountains.

sloka: tattitikṣitamidaṃ mayā munerityavocata vacaścamūpatiḥ | bāṇamatrabhavate nijaṃ diśanpnuhi tvamapi sarvasaṃpadaḥ ||
translation: This, tolerated by the sage, has been declared by him, the commander of the army: "Make this your own sharp weapon, and you will obtain all kinds of riches as well."

sloka: ātmanīnamupatiṣṭhete guṇāḥ saṃbhavanti viramanti cāpadaḥ | ityanekaphalabhāji mā smabhūdarthitā kathamivāryasaṃgame ||
translation: Establishing oneself in one's own self, qualities arise and cease, so also the feet. How can one who enjoys multiple fruits of actions ever be in need, like a victor in a game?

sloka: dṛśyatāmayamanokahāntare tigmahetipṛtanābhiranvitaḥ | sāhivīciriva sindhuruddhato bhūpatiḥ samayasetuvāritaḥ ||
translation: Like a snake, fully equipped with sharp fangs, dwells hidden in the depths of the river, so does the ruler maintain his concealed dominance over the subjects.

sloka: sajyaṃ dhanurvahati yo'hipatisthavīyaḥ stheyāñjayanharituraṃgamaketulakṣmīm | asyānukūlaya matiṃ matimannanena sakhyā sukhaṃ bhiyāsyasi cintitāni ||
translation: The one who skillfully wields the bow, being firmly established as a ruler, possessing a nature that aids in victory, attractiveness, and brilliance, should develop a friendly attitude with a similar disposition, for by doing so, one can attain happiness and overcome fears.

sloka: tataḥ kirātasya vacobhiruddhataiḥ parāhataḥ śaila ivārṇavāmbubhiḥ | jahau na dhairyaṃ kupito'pi pāṇḍavaḥ sudurgrahāntaḥkaraṇā hi sādhavaḥ ||
translation: Having been struck by the forceful words of the Kirāta, like waves against a mountain, even though angered, the righteous Pāṇḍava still did not lose his composure, being difficult to provoke as he was.

sloka: saleśamulliṅgitaśātraveṅgitaḥ kṛtī girāṃ vistaratatvasaṃgrahe | ayaṃ pramāṇīkṛtakālasādhanaḥ praśāntasaṃrambha ivādade vacaḥ ||
translation: The eloquent one, celebrated in the battle of the god Shalishupa, possesses fame. This (speech) has been established as a means of determining the right time, resembling a peaceful resolution.

sloka: viviktavarṇābharaṇā sukhaśrutiḥ prasādayantī hṛdayānyapi dviṣām | pravartate nākṛtapuṇyakarmaṇāṃ prasannagambhīrapadā sarasvatī ||
translation: Even the hearts of enemies are softened by Saraswati, who has a distinct appearance, adorned only with inner beauty, has a pleasant voice, and whose pure and serene nature arises from virtuous actions, not from unripe or sinful deeds.

sloka: bhavanti te sabhyatamā vipaścitāṃ manogataṃ vāci niveśayanti ye | nayanti teṣvapyupapannanaipuṇā gabhīramarthaṃ katicitprakāśatām ||
translation: Those who can cultivate in themselves the virtues of being refined and wise, and can skillfully establish those virtues in their speech, they can also lead others towards a deeper understanding of some aspect of knowledge or wisdom.

sloka: stuvanti gurvīmabhidheyasaṃpadaṃ viśuddhimukterapare vipaścitaḥ | iti sthitāyāṃ pratipūrupaṃ rucau sudurlabhāḥ sarvamanoramā giraḥ ||
translation: The wise ones extol the supreme excellence of the revered teacher, who has attained purification and liberation. In this state, only rarely do such delightful and charming words, which bring joy to the mind, manifest.

sloka: samasya saṃpādayatā guṇairimāṃ tvayā samāropitabhāra bhāratīm | pragalbhamātmā dhuri dhurya vāggmināṃ vanecareṇāpi satādhiropitaḥ ||
translation: By assembling noble qualities, you have taken on the burden of this great kingdom, Bharati. Even as a wandering speaker, your boldness and self-assurance have been assumed.

sloka: prayujya sāmācaritaṃ vilobhanaṃ bhayaṃ vibhedāya dhiyaḥ pradarśitam | tathābhiyuktaṃ ca śilīmukhārthinā yathetarannyāyyamivāvabhāsate ||
translation: Having put into use the established conduct that dispels fear, it has been demonstrated for the purpose of splitting open the minds; and in the same way, having been engaged, the one who pursues mundane objectives shines like an exception to the rule.

sloka: virodhi siddheriti kartumudyataḥ sa vāritaḥ kiṃ bhavatā na bhūpatiḥ | hite niyojyaḥ khalu bhūtimicchatā sahārthanāśena nṛpo'nujīvinā  ||
translation: When ready to establish opposition to the accomplished one, what would a king do but prevent it? A person desiring prosperity, indeed, should engage together with allies, for the sake of ensuring mutual welfare, not for destroying it, O ruler who sustains on the strength of others.

sloka: dhuvaṃ praṇāśaḥ prahitasya patriṇaḥ śiloccaye tasya vimārgaṇaṃ nayaḥ | na yuktamatrāryajanātilaṅghanaṃ diśatyapāyaṃ hi satāmatikramaḥ ||
translation: The downfall of one who has been invited as a guest is certain if his host neglects him; searching for another refuge is appropriate for him, not transgressing the established codes of conduct of respectable people.

sloka: atītasaṃkhyā vihitā mamāgninā śilīmukhāḥ khāṇḍavamattumicchatā | anādṛtasyāmarasāyakeṣvapi sthitā kathaṃ śailajanāśuge dhṛtiḥ ||
translation: The fire sacrifices prescribed in the past, how can the mountain dwellers maintain their composure when ignoring them, while desiring to consume the Khandava forest, and even when they are not respected with offerings of food and drink?

sloka: yadi pramāṇīkṛtamāryaceṣṭitaṃ kimityadoṣeṇa tiraskṛtā vayam | ayātapūrvā parivādagocaraṃ satāṃ hi vāṇī guṇameva bhāṣate ||
translation: If the established conduct of the noble Arya is discredited due to some fault, have we not ourselves been repelled from an unparalleled, praiseworthy association of virtuous people?

sloka: guṇāpavādena tadanyaropaṇādbhṛśādhirūḍhasya samañjasaṃ janaḥ | dvidheva kṛtvā hṛdayaṃ nigūhataḥ sphurannasādhorvivṛṇoti vāgasi  ||
translation: The person who, after thoroughly examining another's qualities, excessively associates those qualities with them, should be careful. By dividing the heart in two, they reveal their own corrupt nature through their speech, even if they try to hide it.

sloka: vanāśrayāḥ kasya mṛgāḥ parigrahāḥ śṛṇāti yastānprasabhena tasya te | prahīyatāmatra nṛpeṇa mānitā na mānitā cāsti bhavanti ca śriyaḥ ||
translation: Whose animals take shelter in the forests, who hears of them unexpectedly, his respect, even if withdrawn by a king, does not result in loss of prosperity.

sloka: na vartma kasmaicidapi pradīyatāmiti vrataṃ me vihitaṃ maharṣiṇā | jighāṃsurasmānnihato mayā mṛgo vratābhirakṣā hi satāmalaṃkriyā  ||
translation: The vow I've been instructed by great sages to follow: never reveal the path to one who hasn't asked for it. By guarding this way, I, a successful hunter, perform a righteous act, protecting virtue for noble souls.

sloka: mṛgānvinighnanmṛgayuḥ svahetunā kṛtopakāraḥ kathamicchatāṃ tapaḥ | kṛpeti cedasta mṛgaḥ kṣataḥ kṣaṇādanena pūrvaṃ na mayeti kā gatiḥ  ||
translation: Hunting animals, how can one who is himself an animal, by his own will, perform a favor through causing harm to them with a sudden action? Where would be his path after that?

sloka: anāyudhe sattvajighāṃsite munau kṛpeti vṛttirmahatāmakṛtrimā | śarāsanaṃ bibhrati sajyasāyakaṃ kṛtānukampaḥ sa kathaṃ pratīyate ||
translation: How can one who shows mercy even to wild animals, carries weapons and projectiles for hunting, be perceived as virtuous among the great?

sloka: atho śarastena madarthamujjhitaḥ phalaṃ ca tasya pratikāyasādhanam | avikṣate tatra mayātmasātkṛte kṛtārthatā nanvadhikā camūpateḥ ||
translation: Thus, for the sake of his own purpose, the archer, having abandoned, seeks the fruit that comes from his skillful shot. There, I do not see any greater purpose than the establishment of self-realization in that army's chief.

sloka: yadāttha kāmaṃ bhavatā sa yācyatāmiti kṣamaṃ naitadanalpacetasām | kathaṃ prasahyāharaṇaiṣiṇāṃ priyāḥ parāvanatyā malinīkṛtāḥ śriyaḥ  ||
translation: When asked for your desire by someone, it is not proper for those of small understanding to readily give away what has been requested. How can the prosperity of those who forcibly take what belongs to others be everlastingly dear and unsullied?

sloka: abhūtamāsajya viruddhamīhitaṃ balādalabhyaṃ tava lipsate nṛpaḥ | vijānato'pi hyanayasya raudratāṃ bhavatyapāye parimohinī matiḥ  ||
translation: The king, even if knowing, craves for what is unreal, conflicting, and not meant to be obtained by force; his wisdom becomes dangerously deluded by the power of such unrighteousness.

sloka: asiḥ śarā varma dhanuśca noccakairvivicya kiṃ prārthitamīśvareṇa te | athāsti śaktiḥ kṛtameva yācñayā na dūṣitaḥ śaktimatāṃ svayaṃgrahaḥ  ||
translation: Arrows, armor, and bow having examined, what more is desired by you, god, from me? Indeed, there exists excellent power that can be obtained through request, not tainting the power of those who possess it themselves.

sloka: sakhā sa yuktaḥ kathitaḥ kathaṃ tvayā yadṛcchayāsūyati yastapasyate | guṇārjanocchrāyaviruddhabuddhayaḥ prakṛtyamitrā hi satāmasādhavaḥ ||
translation: A friend, being thus equipped, is spoken of - how does he become jealous, or engage in austerities, according to your desire? Those who seek to cultivate virtues are true friends to nature.

sloka: vayaṃ kva varṇāśramarakṇocitāḥ kva jātihīnā mṛgajīvitacchidaḥ | sahāpakṛṣṭairmahatāṃ na saṃgataṃ bhavanti gomāyusakhā na dantinaḥ ||
translation: Are we, who follow varna-asrama rules and have a proper birth, or are we those who live like animals, lacking a caste and devoid of culture? Even among the noble, one does not associate with those who are wicked or cruel, just as a friend who milks a cow does not associate with a snake.

sloka: paro'vajānāti yadajñatājaṅastadunnatānāṃ na vihanti dhīratām | samānavīryānvayapauruṣeṣu yaḥ karotyatikrāntimasau tiraskriyā ||
translation: The wise one looks down upon whom does not recognize the knowledge that uplifts the downtrodden; such a one who maintains equality in treating those with similar strength and perseverance, and excels in achieving extraordinary feats, is certainly not contemptible.

sloka: yadā vigṛhṇāti hataṃ tadā yaśaḥ karoti maitrīmatha dūṣitā guṇāḥ | sthitiṃ samīkṣyobhayathā parīkṣakaḥ karotyavajñopahataṃ pṛthagjanam ||
translation: When a discerning one criticizes the defeated, they elevate their fame, while tarnishing the guileless friendship and qualities; they also subdue those unaware who have been overpowered by arrogance.

sloka: mayā mṛgānhanturanena hetunā viruddhamākṣepavacastitikṣitam | śarārthameṣtyatha lapsyate gatiṃ śiromaṇiṃ dṛṣṭiviṣājjighṛkṣataḥ  ||
translation: By me, animals are killed with this as the reason, an opposing force expelled, endured steadfastly. Thus, the supreme path is obtained, coveted by those with sight inspired by poison.

sloka: itīritākūtamanīlavājinaṃ jayāya dūtaḥ pratitarjya tejasā | yayau samīpaṃ dhvajinīmupeyuṣaḥ prasannarūpasya virūpacakṣuṣaḥ ||
translation: The messenger, radiant with vigor, has been sent to invite the flag-holder of the camp, who is serene in appearance but has unusual eyes, to victory.

sloka: tato'pavādena patākinīpateścacāla nirhādavatī mahācamūḥ | yugāntavātābhihateva kurvatī ninādamambhonidhivīcisaṃhatiḥ ||
translation: Then, with the uprooting sound, just like at the end of an era, the great host stirred, making a rushing noise like that of a flooding deluge.

sloka: raṇāya jaitraḥ pradiśanniva tvarāṃ taraṅgitālambitaketusaṃtatiḥ | puro balānāṃ saghanāmbuśīkaraḥ śanaiḥ pratasthe surabhiḥ samīraṇaḥ  ||
translation:
Ready for battle like a banner unfurled, advancing slowly, exuding a fragrance,
For the benefit of allies, a radiant leader, borne by many elephants, gleaming.

sloka: jayāravakṣveḍitanādamūrcchitaḥ śarāsanajyātalavāraṇadhvaniḥ | asaṃbhavanbhūdhararājakukṣiṣu prakampayangāmavatastare diśaḥ ||
translation: Struck by victory's loud clamor, the deer, pierced by the arrow, shudders in the unaccustomed regions of the king of mountains.

sloka: niśātaraudreṣu vikāsatāṃ gataiḥ pradīpayadbhiḥ kakubhāmivāntaram | vanesadāṃ hetiṣu bhinnavigrahairvipusphure raśmimato marīcibhiḥ ||
translation: In the darkness and showers, like a heron's hidden space, using split and flickering beams, like a tree's branches, adorned with blossoms, do the radiant shining sources illuminate.

sloka: udūḍhavakṣaḥsthagitaikadiṅmukho vikṛṣṭavisphāritacāpamaṇḍalaḥ | vitatya pakṣadvayamāyataṃ babhau vibhurguṇānāmuparīva madhyagaḥ ||
translation: Having expanded his chest, facing a single direction, with well-unfurled banners and a sprawling expanse, shining like the chief among those possessing auspicious qualities, in the midst of all, such was the majestic form of the Lord.

sloka: sugeṣu durgeṣu ca tulyavikramairjavādahaṃpūrvikayā yiyāsubhiḥ | gaṇairavicchedaniruddhamābabhau vanaṃ nirucchvāsamivākulākulam ||
translation: With equal prowess advancing in favorable and unfavorable circumstances, I manifested like a forest thicket disturbed by groups of moving beings, along with their unobstructed movements.

sloka: tirohitaśvabhranikuñjarodhasaḥ samaśnuvānāḥ sahasātiritktatām | kirātasainyairapidhāya recitā bhuvaḥ kṣaṇaṃ nimnatayeva bhejire ||
translation: Instantaneously collapsing, as if in an instant, were the fortifications hidden by the mountain of the Kirāta army, after being consumed by their fierce hunger.

sloka: pṛthūrūparyastabṛhallatātatirjavānilāghūrṇitaśālacandanā | gaṇādhipānāṃ paritaḥ prasāriṇī vanānyavāñcīva cakāra saṃhatiḥ ||
translation: A collection was made all around by Prthu, the tall one, of vana plants growing upwards on his body, starting from his feet, consisting of creepers, small, thin, and crushed by the wind, resembling a bunch of sticks, and belonging to the leaders of groups of trees.

sloka: tatḥ sadarpaṃ pratanuṃ tapasyayā madasrutikṣāmamivaikavāraṇam | parijvalantaṃ nidhanāya bhūbhṛtāṃ dahantamāśā iva jātavedasam ||
translation: With full concentration, I will kindle the fire of austerity, which, like a single raincloud, removes the intense heat of the world for the living beings, shining brightly, ready to consume their fuel, just like the fire-god Agni himself.

sloka: anādaropāttadhṛtaikasāyakaṃ jaye'nukūle suhṛdīva saspṛham | śanairapūrṇapratikārapelave niveśayantaṃ nayane balodadhau ||
translation: With a single weapon, obtained without disrespect, skillfully and steadily taken up, gracefully and in a controlled manner, he who is friendly yet remains slightly distant, is settling it in the open eye of the battlefield, like a strong warrior wielding his weapon.

sloka: niṣaṇṇamāpatpratikārakāraṇe śarāsane dhairya ivānapāyini | alaṅghanīyaṃ prakṛtāvapi sthitaṃ nivātaniṣkampamivāpagāpatim  ||
translation: Displaying patience like an arrow on the battlefield, ready to counter an attack, yet steady and unwavering like a fixed pillar, unperturbed by natural calamities such as wind.

sloka: upeyuṣīṃ bibhratamantakadyutiṃ vadhādadūre patitasya daṃṣṭriṇaḥ | puraḥ samāveśitasatpaśuṃ dvijaiḥ patiṃ paśūnāmiva hūtamadhvare ||
translation: Approaching while carrying the radiance like that of the destroyer, with his fangs bared, lying far away from the sacrifice, the beast has been tamed by the twice-born as if taming their own domestic animals in the sacrificial arena.

sloka: nijena nītaṃ vijitānyagauravaṃ gabhīratāṃ dhairyaguṇena bhūyasā | vanodayeneva ghanoruvīrudhā samandhakārīkṛtamuttamācalam ||
translation: With her own hand, she has conquered the pride of others; with preeminent courage, she has raised herself like a cloud filled with rain. Just as the dense dark cloud brings forth a peak of light, so she has made her highest position manifest.

sloka: maharṣabhaskandhamanūnakaṃdharaṃ bṛhacchilāvapraghanena vakṣasā | samujjihīrṣuṃ jagatīṃ mahābharāṃ mahāvarāhaṃ mahato'rṇavādiva ||
translation: Stretching his vast chest, resembling a great ocean, the mighty-bull among sages, Manu, lifts up the mountain residing on Kandharma, eager to shake off the great burden of the earth.

sloka: gurukriyārambhaphalairalaṃkṛtaṃ gatiṃ pratāpasya jagatpramāthinaḥ | gaṇāḥ samāseduranīlavājinaṃ tapātyaye toyaghanā ghanā iva ||
translation: The groups (of sages) approached and gathered around the bull among men, adorned with the fruits of his sacred duties as a student, resembling dark clouds amassing in the sky, at the onset of his austere penance for the welfare of the world.

sloka: yathāsvamāśaṃsitavikramāḥ purā muniprabhāvakṣatatejasaḥ pare | yayuḥ kṣaṇādapratipattimūḍhatāṃ mahānubhāvaḥ pratihanti pauruṣam ||
translation: Just as previously the greatness of the self-controlled sage's powerful prowess waned in a moment, so does greatness swiftly counteract smallness.

sloka: tataḥ prajahve samameva tatra tairapekṣitānyonyabalopapattibhiḥ | mahodayānāmapi saṅghavṛttitāṃ sahāyasādhyāḥ pradiśanti siddhayaḥ ||
translation: Then, at the sacrificial ceremony, those accomplished ones, with impartial judgment of each other's strengths, indicate the achievable assistances for even the great rising powers, gathered there.

sloka: kirātasainyādurucāpanoditāḥ samaṃ samutpeturupāttaraṃhasaḥ | mahāvanādunmanasaḥ khagā iva pravṛttapatradhvanayaḥ śilīmukhāḥ ||
translation: Kirata troops, incited by uru, emit a great sound, equal in force, resembling birds taking flight, set on their respective courses.

sloka: gabhīrarandhreṣu bhṛśaṃ mahībhṛtaḥ pratisvanairunnamitena sānuṣu | dhanurninādena javādupeyuṣā vibhidyamānā iva dadhvanurdiśaḥ ||
translation: In the deeply hidden recesses, the earth-holder, strongly, is being pierced all around by the sharp sound of the bowstring, as it were, like (a warrior) advancing in battle.

sloka: vidhūnayantī gahanāni bhūruhāṃ tirohitopāntanabhodigantarā | mahīyasī vṛṣṭirivānileritā ravaṃ vitene gaṇamārgaṇāvaliḥ ||
translation: The wind, like a flowing and expanding mass, drives away the deep clouds that have arisen and cover the directions, resembling a heavy rainstorm that has arrived.

sloka: trayīmṛtūnāmanilāśinaḥ sataḥ prayāti poṣaṃ vapuṣi prahṛṣyataḥ | raṇāya jiṣṇorvidupeva satvaraṃ ghanatvamīye śithilena varmaṇā ||
translation: For one who delights in the nectar of the three Vedas, their nourishment and strength grow, as a sharpened weapon becomes firm in the hands of a skilled warrior.

sloka: patatsu śastreṣu vitatya rodasī samantatastasya dhanurdudhūṣataḥ | saroṣamulkeva papāta bhīṣaṇā baleṣu dṛṣṭirvinipātaśaṃsinī ||
translation: The terrifying sight, as a fiery meteor falls, having stretched its bowstring in all directions among the weapons in that battle.

sloka: diśaḥ samūhanniva vikṣipanniva prabhāṃ raverākulayannivānilam | muniścacāla kṣayakāladāruṇaḥkṣitiṃ saśailāṃ calayanniveṣubhiḥ ||
translation: Like a crowd of stars scattering and a sun darkened, a sage, swept away by the advancing age's cruelty, shakes the crowned mountain's stability.

sloka: vimuktamāśaṃsitaśatrunirjayairanekamekāvasaraṃ vanecaraiḥ | sa nirjaghānāyudhamantarā śaraiḥ kriyāphalaṃ kāla ivātipātitaḥ  ||
translation: Having been released from enemies, praised by many victors, in a single opportunity, that person, as if time itself, has surpassed the fruit of actions, leaving behind weapons deprived of their targets.

sloka: gataiḥ pareṣāmavibhāvanīyatāṃ nivārayadbhirvipadaṃ vidūragaiḥ | bhṛśaṃ babhūvopacito vṛhatphalaiḥ śarairupāyairiva pāṇḍunandanaḥ ||
translation: Warded off by the expertly aimed missiles of the distant ones, Pandu's son has been greatly adorned with an abundance of immense fruit; who indeed in this world can surpass this virtue and valor?

sloka: divaḥ pṛthivyāḥ kakubhāṃ nu maṇḍalātpatanti vimbāduta tigmatejasaḥ | sakṛdvikṛṣṭādatha kārmukānmuneḥ śarāḥ śarīrāditi te'bhimenire  ||
translation: From the circle of the sun and moon, showers of heated raindrops fall onto the earth's shoulder. Like arrows, expertly released from a muni's bow, they penetrate the body, becoming one with it.

sloka: gaṇādhipānāmavidhāya nirgataiḥ parāsutāṃ marmavidāraṇairapi | javādatīye himavānadhomukhaiḥ kṛtāparādhairiva tasya patribhiḥ ||
translation: Even the mighty Himalayas, which reveal their peaks, are as if guilty by the extraction of hidden gems, for the rulers' assembly (gaṇa-ādhipānām) caused by those who have left (nirgataiḥ) and specialized in gem extraction (marmavidāraṇaiḥ).

sloka: dviṣāṃ kṣatīryāḥ prathame śilīmukhā vibhidya dehāvaraṇāni cakrire | na tāsu pete viśikhaiḥ punarmuneraruṃtudatvaṃ mahatāṃ hyagocaraḥ ||
translation: For the cruel ones, in the first instance, they split open the protective sheaths of the bodies by means of sharp arrows, but even after being pierced by those arrows, they did not experience any decrease in their great power.

sloka: samujjhitā yāvadarāti niryatī sahaiva cāpānmunibāṇasaṃhatiḥ | prabhā himāṃśoriva paṅkajāvaliṃ nināya saṃkocamumāpateścamūm ||
translation: As long as the moon that has risen has not set, together with its arrows, that is, the stars, it illuminates like a garland of lightning along with the expanding mass of clouds; thus, the commander-in-chief, Umā's consort, withdraws his army.

sloka: ajihmamojiṣṭhamamoghamaklamaṃ kriyāsu bahvīṣu pṛthaṅgiyojitam | prasehire sādayituṃ na sāditāḥ śaraughamutsāhamivāssa vidviṣaḥ  ||
translation: Even those who are adept at many tasks, joined with the foremost one, are unable to please those who bear enmity, like [one is unable to] make a cloud of dust settle down during a gust of wind.

sloka: śivadhvajinyaḥ pratiyodhamagrataḥ sphurantamugreṣumayūkhamālinam | tamekadeśasthamanekadeśagā nidadhyurarkaṃ yugapatprajā iva ||
translation: Adorning a banner bearing the symbol of Shiva, a resplendent figure, wielding a spear and adorned with garlands, is fixed in the sky by the multitudes inhabiting various regions, as if giving birth to the sun all at once.

sloka: muneḥ śaraugheṇa tadugraraṃhasā balaṃ prakopādiva viṣvagāyatā | vidhūnitaṃ bhrāntimiyāya saṅginīṃ mahānileneva nidāghajaṃ rajaḥ  ||
translation: Like a great cloud dispelled by the strong wind of a sage's wrath, what strength can persist, spreading in all directions, ready to delude the ignorant?

sloka: tapobalenaiṣa vidhāya bhūyasīstanūradṛśyāḥ svidiṣūnnirasyati | amuṣya māyāvihataṃ vihanti naḥ pratīpamāgatya kimu svamāyudham  ||
translation: By exerting oneself in austerity and gaining strength, how can one's hidden, faded form be made conspicuous again? Having overcome this deceptive illusion, what weapon can protect us?

sloka: hṛtā guṇairasya bhayena vā munestirohitāḥ svitpraharanti devatāḥ | kathaṃ nvamī saṃtatamasya sāyakā bhavantyaneke jaladherivormayaḥ ||
translation: With his qualities stolen by fear, does the sage truly consider the celestial beings as enemies, or are they merely acting like waves on the surface of a disturbed body of water?

sloka: jayena kaccidviramedayaṃ raṇādbhavedapi svasti carācarāya vā | tatāpa kīrṇā nṛpasūnumārgaṇairiti pratarkākulitā patākinī ||
translation: With what victory, might one ever ensure peace for moving and non-moving beings in this battlefield, now overrun by the confusion of contradictory opinions, even after subduing the son of a king?

sloka: amarṣiṇā kṛtyamiva kṣamāśrayaṃ madoddhateneva hitaṃ priyaṃ vacaḥ | balīyasā tadvidhineva pauruṣaṃ balaṃ nirastaṃ na rarāja jiṣṇunā ||
translation: With forbearance like a duty, the respected one took shelter, as if uplifted by me; thus, spoken words became more powerful, dispelling the ordinary strength, nor did the conqueror shine.

sloka: pratidiśaṃ plavagādhipalakṣmaṇā viśikhasaṃhatitāpitamūrtibhiḥ | ravikaraglapitairiva vāribhiḥ śivabalaiḥ parimaṇḍalatādadhe ||
translation: Facing every direction, Lakshmana, chief of monkeys, has assembled and energized his formidable sumtotal of strength, like the sun's rays gathering and distributing their own powerful brilliance.

sloka: pravitataśarajālacchannaviśvāntarāle vidhuvati dhanurāvirmaṇḍalaṃ pāṇḍusūnau | kathamapi jayalakṣmīrbhītabhītā vihātuṃ viṣamanayanasenāpakṣapātaṃ viṣehe ||
translation: Even in the secluded expanse of the world, concealed by the scattering mists of a rain shower, how could the steadfast aim of Pāṇḍu's son endure any disturbance, as Indra's wife, filled with fear, attempts to flee, even for a moment, from the uneven battlefield?

sloka: atha bhūtāni vārtraghnaśarebhyastatra tatrasuḥ | bheje diśaḥ parityaktamaheṣvāsā ca sā camūḥ ||
translation: Then, the beings, enemies of the flood, here and there, dismissed arms, along with their great bows and troops, as well as their eagerness for battle.

sloka: apaśyadbhiriveśānaṃ raṇānnivavṛte gaṇaiḥ | muhyatyeva hi kṛcchreṣu saṃbhramajvalitaṃ manaḥ ||
translation: Witnessing the lord surrounded by divisions of warriors, the mind becomes agitated in critical situations, as if getting lost in a mirage.

sloka: khaṇḍitāśaṃsayā teṣāṃ parāṅmukhatayā tayā | āviveśa kṛpā ketauṃ kṛtoccairvānaraṃ naram ||
translation: With the elimination of their fears, approaching the human in the form of a monkey, having turned toward him, the flag of mercy, Kṛta, fully equipped, I entered.

sloka: āsthāmālambya nīteṣu vaśaṃ kṣudrevarātiṣu | vyaktimāyāti mahatāṃ māhātmyamanukampayā ||
translation: Establishing himself firmly, he gains control over those who are insignificant yet difficult to govern, revealing his greatness through compassion for the great.

sloka: sa sāsiḥ sāsusūḥ sāso yeyāyeyāyayāyayaḥ | lalau līlāṃ lalo'lolaḥ śaśīśaśiśuśīḥ śaśan ||
translation: He, as a spouse, endured; as a father, he nurtured; as a son, he honored; as a relative, he shared; as a protector, he safeguarded; as a lover, he played; as a friend, he delighted; as a guru, he taught; as a boy, he studied; as the moon, he shone.

sloka: trāsajihmaṃ yataścaitānmandamevānvitāya saḥ | nātipīḍayituṃ bhagnānicchanti hi mahaujasaḥ ||
translation: Even these, who are naturally fierce, make efforts to avoid afflicting (pīḍayitum) those who are subdued (bhagnān), desiring (icchanti) to not cause excessive distress (atipīḍayituṃ).

sloka: athāgre hasatā sācisthitena sthirakīrtinā | senānyā te jagadire kiṃcidāyastacetasā ||
translation: Now, at the forefront, stand firm, renowned one, with steadfast mind, what can armies do for you in this world?

sloka: mā vihāsiṣṭa samaraṃ samarantavyasaṃyataḥ | kṣataṃ kṣuṇṇāsuragaṇairagaṇairiva kiṃ yaśaḥ ||
translation: Why would a self-controlled warrior, ready for battle, care for fame when compared to being surrounded by an army of demons, destroyed and defeated?

sloka: vivasvadaṃśusaṃśleṣadviguṇīkṛtatejasaḥ | amī vo moghamudgūrṇā hasantīva mahāsayaḥ ||
translation: Worshipped twofold, the splendor of Vivasvan amplified, these great souls laugh as if in vain.

sloka: vane'vane vanasadāṃ mārgaṃ mārgamupeyuṣām | bāṇairbāṇaiḥ māsaktaṃ śaṅke'śaṃ kena śāmyati ||
translation: In forests, where hermits tread their own path, how does one appease their fear, pierced by each other's arrows?

sloka: pātitottaṅgamāhātmyaiḥ saṃhṛtāyatakīrtibhiḥ | gurvīṃ kāmāpadaṃ hantuṃ kṛtamāvṛttisāhasam ||
translation: With the amassed glory of subduing overwhelming waves, a monumental effort has been made to destroy the powerful downfall of worldly desires.

sloka: nāsuro'yaṃ na vā nāgo dharasaṃstho na rākṣasaḥ | nā sukho'yaṃ navābhogo raṇistho hi rājasaḥ ||
translation: This in the world is not a devil, nor a snake, nor firmly established on a mountain, nor a ghost. Nor is there happiness or new renunciation for a warrior engaged in battle, indeed.

sloka: mandamasyanniṣulatāṃ ghṛṇayā munireṣa vaḥ | praṇudatyāgatāvajñaṃ jaghaneṣu paśūniva ||
translation: With a disdainful glance, this sage, having understood, makes insignificant the ignorance of those who belittle him, just as a butcher would trivialize the lives of animals.

sloka: na nonanunno nunnono nānā nānānanā nanu | nunno'nunno nanunneno nānenā nunnanunnanut ||
translation: Not even one, not diminished, not diminishing, diverse, having diverse forms, indeed; not diminished by either, not increasing by either, neither incomplete nor complete.

sloka: varaṃ kṛtadhvastaguṇādatyantamaguṇaḥ pumān | prakṛtyā hyamaṇiḥ śreyānnālaṃkāraścyutopalaḥ ||
translation: The best among men is one whose virtues have been destroyed at the very limit, who is without qualities, like a polished gem by nature, and who has transcended the need for ornamentation or external displays of merit.

sloka: syandanā no caturagāḥ surebhā vāvipattayaḥ | syandanā no ca turagāḥ surebhā vā vipattayaḥ ||
translation: Not only are our four-footed horses attractive, but even our two-footed horses (i.e. warriors) are also attractive and skilled in avoiding mishaps.

sloka: bhavadbhiradhunārātiparihāpitapauruṣaiḥ | hṛdairivārkaniṣpītaiḥ prāptaḥ paṅko duruttaraḥ ||
translation: Acquired with difficulty, through your recent sincere efforts, is this hard-to-reach mud, warmed by the sun-like hearts.

sloka: vetraśākakuje śaile'leśaije'kukaśātrave | yāta kiṃ vidiśo jetuṃ tuñjaśo divi kiṃtayā ||
translation: Having gone where, in the peak of Śāka, on the isolated hill, in the battle against Kuku-śātru, what is there to conquer in a foreign land or in the sky, being indifferent?

sloka: ayaṃ vaḥ klaibyamāpannāndṛṣṭapṛṣṭhānarātinā | icchatīśaścyutācārāndārāniva nigopitum ||
translation: This, you should understand, is cowardice that has come into view - like

sloka: nanu ho manthanā rāgho ghorā nāthamaho nu na | tayadātavadā bhīmā mābhīdā bata dāyata ||
translation: Is it not surprising that the fierce Rāgha, who churns (manthanā), is not the Lord, although he appears terrible (ghorāḥ) and has power (nātha)? Indeed, he who is known as Tayadātava has become so formidable (bhīmā), as if he were a second creator (mābhīdā), alas! has given (dāyata) something.

sloka: kiṃ tyaktāpāstadevatvamānuṣyakaparigrahaiḥ | jvalitānyaguṇairgurvī sthitā tejasi mānitā ||
translation: What is this abandonment of godhood, accepted by human grasp, that stands out, shining, with inherent qualities, established in radiance, and recognized?

sloka: niśitāsirato'bhīko nyejate'maraṇā rucā | sārato na virodhī naḥ svābhāso bharavānuta ||
translation: Sharp at sunset, one who is not hostile to us, is chosen to be honored, not contrary to our own light, heavy with burden, and accompanied by offerings.

sloka: tanuvārabhaso bhāsvānadhīro'vinatorasā | cāruṇā ramate janye ko'bhīto rasitāśini ||
translation: Wearing a slender waist, radiant, steadfast, and not easily agitated, who is charming and delights the mind while being praised?

sloka: vibhinne pātitāśvīyaniruddharathavartmani | hatadvipanagaṣṭyūtarudhirāmbunadākule ||
translation: In the scattered (battle)field, toppled are the enemy's elephants, chariots, and horses; drenched in blood and mud.

sloka: devākānini kāvāde vāhikāsvasvakāhi vā | kākārebhabhare kākā nisvabhavyavyabhasvani ||
translation: In the assembly of the gods or in that of the Gandharvas, or even among serpents, which crow crows in imitation, perched on a tree, just about to lose its feathers?

sloka: pranṛttaśavavitrastaturagākṣiptasārathau | mārutāpūrṇatūṇīravikruṣṭahatasādini ||
translation: The charioteer and his steeds, shaken off by the sound of the dance, are bellowing in the blast of the maddened wind, filled with the tumultuous din.

sloka: sasattvaratide nityaṃ sadarāmarṣanāśini | tvarādhikakasannāde ramakatvamakarṣati ||
translation: Ever steadfast, always free from anger and malice, constantly serene, and instantly performing actions - such a person draws towards themselves the quality of being delightful.

sloka: āsure lokavitrāsavidhāyini mahāhave | yuṣmābhirunnatiṃ nītaṃ nirastamiha pauruṣam ||
translation: By you all, in this great battle, the dispeller of the enemy's joy and the one who instills fear has been lifted up and defeated.

sloka: iti śāsati senānyāṃ gacchatastānanekadhā | niṣidhya hasatā kiṃcittasthe tatrāndhakāriṇā ||
translation: Thus ordering the troops, he moves about in various ways, suppressing some with a frown in that very place, wielding blind darkness.

sloka: munīṣudahanātaptā~llajjayā nivivṛtsyataḥ | śivaḥ prahlādayāmāsa tānniṣedhahimāmbunā ||
translation: Feeling ashamed due to being scolded by the sage's son, those who were tormented by fear were comforted by Shiva's soothing words and the rain he sent.

sloka: dūnāste'ribalādūnā nirebhā bahu menire | bhītāḥ śitaśarābhītāḥ śaṃkaraṃ tatra śaṃkaram ||
translation: Terrified by the two-footed and four-footed enemies, they see Shankara (Rudra) as their protector in that very place, who has cooling weapons.

sloka: maheṣujaladhau śatrorvartamānā duruttare | prāpya pāramiveśānamāśaśvāsa patākinī ||
translation: Having reached the inaccessible position of ruling over the ocean of enemies, the mighty archer breathes easier, as if having attained a supreme divine abode.

sloka: sa babhāra raṇāpetāṃ camūṃ paścādavasthitām | puraḥsūryādapāvṛttāṃ chāyāmiva mahātaruḥ ||
translation: He supported from behind the army positioned opposite, like a great tree casting its shade in front.

sloka: muñcatīśe śarāñjiṣṇau pinākasvanapūritaḥ | dadhvāna dhvanayannāśāḥ sphuṭanniva dharādharaḥ ||
translation: Wielding Pinaka, appearing as a powerful shooter of sharp arrows, roaring loudly, and holding firmly to the earth, He moves about.

sloka: tadraṇā dadṛśurbhimaṃ citrasaṃsthā ivācalāḥ | vismayena tayoryuddhaṃ citrasaṃsthā ivācalāḥ ||
translation: Witnessing that banner, they were struck with wonder, as if fixed and stable like a marvelous stage setting. Similarly, their amazement was aroused by the battle itself.

sloka: parimohayamāṇena śikṣālāghavalīlayā | jaiṣṇavī viśikhaśreṇī parijahre pinākinā ||
translation: Being captivated by the shower of teachings from the crest jewel of Jaiṣṇavas, who is skillfully making use of scriptural examples, the arrow (of his teachings) pierces.

sloka: avadyanpatriṇaḥ śaṃbhoḥ sāyakairavasāyakaiḥ | pāṇḍavaḥ paricakrāma śikṣayā raṇaśikṣayā ||
translation: Pandava encircled Shambhu's (Shiva's) target, the marked ones, with arrows for the purpose of battle training.

sloka: cāracuñcuścirārecī cañcaccīrarucā rucaḥ | cacāra ruciraścāru cārairācāracañcuraḥ ||
translation: Moving gently, always beautiful, and charming, displaying grace in movements, and being attractive in conduct – such a person, who is beautiful in every way, moves around.

sloka: sphuratpiśaṅgamaurvīkaṃ dhunānaḥ sa bṛhaddhanuḥ | dhṛtolkānalayogena tulyamaṃśumatā babhau ||
translation: Resplendent with a color like that of a partridge, wielding a massive bow, and resembling a column of fire through the combination of his radiant energy and arrow.

sloka: pārthabāṇāḥ paśupaterāvavrurviśikhāvalīm | payomuca ivārandhrāḥ sāvitrīmaṃśusaṃhatim ||
translation: Arrows of Partha (Arjuna) rained upon Shiva, resembling showers of water from clouds, forming a united line, like the rays of the moon and sun.

sloka: śaravṛṣṭiṃ vidhūyorvīmudastāṃ savyasācinā | rurodha mārgaṇairmārgaṃ tapanasya trilocanaḥ ||
translation: Discarding the rain of arrows, the three-eyed one, wielding his favorite weapon, cried out, "I have found the path!"

sloka: tena vyātenire bhīmā bhīmārjanaphalānanāḥ | na nānukampya viśikhāḥ śikhādharajavāsasaḥ ||
translation: With that (tena), thoroughly agitated (vyātenire), becoming fierce (bhī māḥ), bhīma (in name), having faces like the remover of fear (arjana+phala+ānanāḥ), are (na) not to be pitied (anukampya), the crests (viśikhāḥ) of one wearing a deer-skin as clothing (śikhā+dhara+ja+vāsasaḥ).

sloka: dyuviyadgāminī tārasaṃrāvavihataśrutiḥ | haimīṣumālā śuśubhe vidyutāmiva saṃhatiḥ ||
translation: Adorning the sky like a garland of lightning, the celestial sound, disrupted by the roar of thunder, shines.

sloka: vilaṅghaya patriṇāṃ paṅktiṃ bhinnaḥ śivaśilīmukhaiḥ | jyāyo vīryamupāśritya na cakampe kapidhvajaḥ ||
translation: Separated from the ranks of his foes, bearing the banner of a monkey, Kapidhvaja, relying on his valor, did not falter.

sloka: jagatīśaraṇe yukto harikāntaḥ sudhāsitaḥ | dānavarṣī kṛtāśaṃso nāgarāja ivābabhau ||
translation: Joined in the protector of the world, serene like the nectar-filled Hari's* heart, that Dānava ṛṣi** became like a noble king.

sloka: viphalīkṛtayatnasya kṣatabāṇasya śaṃbhunā | gāṇḍīvadhanvanaḥ khebhyo niścakrāma hutāśanaḥ ||
translation: Having made his efforts in vain, Arjuna, named "Gāṇḍīvadhanvanah," along with his sharp-shooting abilities, has been abandoned by "Śambhunā" (an epithet of Indra's weapon) as it departs into the sky.

sloka: sa piśaṅgajaṭāvaliḥ kirannurutejaḥ parameṇa manyunā | jvalitauṣadhijātavedasā himaśailena samaṃ vididyute ||
translation: He, with tawny hair like a snake's hood, shining like a thousand suns, blazes like a plant-born fire, equal in brilliance to the lightning, and is as resplendent as the summit of Himavat.

sloka: śataśo viśikhānavadyate bhṛśamasmai raṇavegaśāline | prathayannanivāryavīryatāṃ prajighāyeṣumadhātukaṃ śivaḥ ||
translation: A hundred times does the war arrow fly swiftly towards the irresistible warrior. Manifesting inviolable strength, Shiva invokes the destruction of the enemy's armor.

sloka: śaṃbhordhanurmaṇḍalataḥ pravṛttaṃ taṃ maṇḍalādaṃśumivāṃśubhartuḥ | nivārayiṣyanvidadhe sitāśvaḥ śilīmukhacchāyavṛtāṃ dharitrīm ||
translation: Like an arrow shot from Shambho's (Lord Shiva's) bow, driving away (nivārayiṣyan) and placing (vidadhe) the cool horse (sita āśvaḥ) in the midst of the spread-out portion (silīmukhacchāyavṛtām) of the moon's disk ( maṇḍalāt aṃśum iva aṃśu bhartuḥ), the earth becomes steady (dharitrīm).

sloka: ghanaṃ vidāryārjunabāṇapūgaṃ sasāravāṇo'yugalocanasya | ghanaṃ vidāryārjunabāṇapūgaṃ sasāra bāṇo'yugalocanasya ||
translation: Arjuna, causing the dense eyelash to spread, just like an arrow shot from a bow, making the two eyes look wide open.

sloka: rujanmaheṣūnbahudhāśupātino muhuḥ śaraughairapavārayandiśaḥ | calācalo'neka iva kriyāvaśānmaharṣisaṃdhairbubudhe dhanaṃjayaḥ ||
translation: "O Dhanañjaya, like many quick-falling arrows, great īśu (archer, warrior) is constantly bombarded by adversities, just as if pinned down by numerous immovable objects."

sloka: vikāśamīyurjagatīśamārgaṇā vikāśamīyurjagatīśamārgaṇāḥ | vikāśamīyurjagatīśamārgaṇā vikāśamīyurjagatīśamārgaṇāḥ ||
translation: Spreading, they search for the path of the lord of the world; spreading, they search for the path of the lord of the world.

sloka: saṃpaśyatāmiti śivena vitāyamānaṃ lakṣmīvataḥ kṣitipatestanayasya vīryam | aṅgānyabhinnamapi tattvavidāṃ munīnāṃ romāñcamañcitataraṃ vibharāṃbabhūvuḥ ||
translation: Observing, the god Shiva causes the virtuous power of the prince, the son of the lord of the earth, to be manifested in a striking way, even in the separate limbs, for the seers and knowers of truth; it is as radiant as Lakshmi herself.

sloka: tataḥ kirātādhipateralaghvīmājikriyāṃ vīkṣya vivṛddhamanyuḥ | sa tarkayāmāsa viviktatarkaściraṃ vicinvanniti kāraṇāni ||
translation: After that, observing the rapidly growing anger of the Kirāta king, he pondered alone, reflecting on the causes, for a long time, mulling over them carefully.

sloka: madasrutiśyāmitagaṇḍalekhāḥ krāmanti vikrāntanarādhirūḍhāḥ | sahiṣṇavo neha yudhāmabhijñā nāgā nagocchrāyamivākṣipantaḥ  ||
translation: Even as they ride upon fierce elephants, marked by pride and insignia, those recognizing the battle, yet forbearing, do not let themselves be swept away by anger in such conflicts, like a steady elephant in rut.

sloka: vicitrayā citrayateva bhinnāṃ rucaṃ raveḥ ketanaratnabhāsā | mahārathaughena na saṃniruddhā payodamandradhvaninā dharitrī ||
translation: Adorned with diverse, variegated radiance, the earth, seemingly, reveals its own unique charm, just like a supreme charioteer does not subdue the moon's resounding light with his mighty army.

sloka: samullasatprāsamahormimālaṃ parisphuraccāmaraphenapaṅkti | vibhinnamaryādamihātanoti nāśvīyamāśā jaladherivāmbhaḥ ||
translation: The crest of the great wave, shining and adorned with froth, when fully expanded, does not quickly diminish the hope (of a big wave) like the cloud in the sky.

sloka: hatāhatetyuddhatabhīmaghoṣaiḥ samujjhitā yoddhṛmirabhyamitram | na hetayaḥ prāptataḍittviṣaḥ khe vivasvadaṃśujvalitāḥ patanti ||
translation: Defeated or victorious, with loud cries, the warring champion has emerged from battle, unvanquished by his foes. Not due to any external compulsion, but driven by his own inner light, radiant as the rays of the sun, does he descend from the sky.

sloka: abhyāyataḥ saṃtatadhūmadhūmraṃ vyāpi prabhājālamivāntakasya | rajaḥ pratūrṇāśvarathāṅganunnaṃ tanoti na vyomani mātariśvā ||
translation: Spreading constantly like the smoke of a perpetual fire, the resplendent radiance of the end-maker envelops the sky, together with the dust raised by the wheels of well-equipped chariots.

sloka: bhūreṇunā rāsabhadhūsareṇa tirohite vartmani locanānām | nāstyatra tejasvibhirutsukānāmahni pradoṣaḥ surasundarīṇām ||
translation: On the muddy path, obscured by dust, the luster of the splendid divine women is not diminished; it remains vibrant and shining.

sloka: rathāṅgasaṃkrīḍitamaśvaheṣā bṛhanti mattadvipabṛṃhitāni | saṃgharṣayogādiva mūrcchitāni hādaṃ nigṛhṇanti na dundubhīnām ||
translation: Chariot warriors, intoxicated by gambling, cause great agitation, as if in a state of fainting, but even they cannot restrain the loud beats of the drums.

sloka: asminyaśaḥpauruṣalolupānāmarātibhiḥ pratyurasaṃ kṣatānām | mūrcchāntarāyaṃ muhurucchinatti nāsāraśītaṃ kariśīkarāmbhaḥ ||
translation: In this encounter, the boastful and greedy for fame among the warriors are constantly shaken by their internal turmoil, like the water in a pot trembling due to the blowing wind.

sloka: asṛṅnadīnāmupacīyamānairvidārayadbhiḥ padavīṃ dhvajinyāḥ | ucchrāyamāyānti na śoṇitaughaiḥ paṅkairivāśyānaghanaistaṭāni ||
translation:
With (vidārayadbhiḥ) arrangements (upacīyamānair) of banners (dhvajināḥ) being made for the procession of asṛṅga and others, they proceed (āyānti) as if not touching (na śoṇita) bloody (aughaiḥ) mud (paṅka) but (iva) like (aśyānaghana) solid (ṭāni).

The translation tries to capture the context of a procession being held for asṛṅga and others, where banners are being arranged for them, and they proceed as if not touching the ground, giving an impression of them floating or moving elegantly, not disturbing the bloody mud on the ground, indicating a royal or sacred procession.

sloka: parikṣate vakṣasi dantidantaiḥ priyāṅkaśītā nabhasaḥ patantī | neha pramohaṃ priyasāhasānāṃ mandāramālā viralīkaroti ||
translation: Are ornamented teeth carefully examining your face in the sky? The creeping vine of false attachment does not deceive those who take delight in the noble.

sloka: niṣādisaṃnāhamaṇiprabhaughe parīyamāṇe kariśīkareṇa | arkatviṣonmīlitamabhyudeti na khaṇḍamākhaṇḍalakārmukasya ||
translation: At the onset, I am not separate from the resplendent gem-like sun, as its radiance is fully manifest when the curved rays appear, not diminishing in any way for the steady, unblinking observer.

sloka: mahībhṛtā pakṣavateva bhinnā vigāhya madhyaṃ paravāraṇena | nāvartamānā ninadanti bhīmamapāṃ nidherāpa iva dhvajinyaḥ ||
translation: Like standard-bearers who, being separated, make a loud noise when piercing through the middle of the enemy's formation, they do not retreat, but rather sound their trumpets as they advance towards the fearsome waters.

sloka: mahārathānāṃ pratidantyanīkamadhisyadasyandanamutthitānām | āmūlalūnairatimanyuneva mātaṅgahastairvriyate na panthāḥ ||
translation: Among the great charioteers, there is no path, using even elephant goads as hard as Indra's thunderbolt, that can agitate/disturb those who have stood up (i.e., ready for battle), along with their troops, divisions, and chariots.

sloka: dhṛtotpalāpīḍa iva priyāyāḥ śiroruhāṇāṃ śithilaḥ kalāpaḥ | na barhabhāraḥ patitasya śaṅkorniṣādivakṣaḥsthalamātanoti ||
translation: Like a steadily held blue lotus, not oppressed by the weight of a heavy shower, does not sag the head of a dear one; likewise, a strong-hearted one does not let his resolve waver in a difficult situation.

sloka: ujjhatsu saṃhāra ivāstasaṃkhyamahnāya tejasviṣu jīvitāni | lokatrayāsvādanalolajihvaṃ na vyādadātyānanamatra mṛtyuḥ ||
translation: Untimely ending the life of the shining ones, numbering in the thousands, is not death, which only consumes the physical form, as if rolling it up like a tongue tasting sweets, in all three worlds.

sloka: iyaṃ ca durvāramahārathānāmākṣipya vīryaṃ mahatāṃ balānām | śaktirmamāvasyati hīnayuddhe saurīva tārādhipadhāmni dīptiḥ ||
translation: This, the great strength of mighty chariot-fighters, having set aside their valor, is subdued in an unequal battle, just as the light of even a powerful star is overshadowed in the presence of the sun.

sloka: māyā svideṣā mativibhramo vā dhvastaṃ nu me vīryamutāhamanyaḥ | gāṇḍīvamuktā hi yathāpurā me parākramante na śarāḥ kirāte ||
translation: Is this illusion merely a figment of my own mind, or has my strength been completely destroyed? Just as arrows released from Gandiva return impotent in a rainstorm, so too do my enemies seem to me.

sloka: puṃsaḥ padaṃ madhyamamuttamasya dvidheva kurvandhanuṣaḥ praṇādaiḥ | nūnaṃ tathā naiṣa yathāsya veṣaḥ pracchannamapyūhayate hi ceṣṭā ||
translation: The middle step of a person, when performed with great care using his breaths, must be like the drawing of a bow; indeed, his concealed form then becomes manifest in action.

sloka: dhanuḥ prabandhadhvanitaṃ ruṣeva sakṛdvikṛṣṭā vitateva maurvī | saṃdhānamutkarṣamiva vyudasya muṣṭerasaṃbheda ivāpavarge ||
translation: Like a bowstring, stretched taut once by an angry person, released, the coil unfurls, resembling the spreading out of a well-made arrangement, as if a finger-snap has opened it up.

sloka: aṃsāvavaṣṭabdhanatau samādhiḥ śirodharāyā rahitaprayāsaḥ | dhṛtā vikārāṃstyajatā mukhena prasādalakṣmīḥ śaśalāñchanasya ||
translation: A state of deep concentration, effortless for a steady head, devoid of support; radiant grace shining from a discarded, unaltered countenance.

sloka: prahīyate kāryavaśāgateṣu sthāneṣu viṣṭabdhatayā na dehaḥ | sthitaprayāteṣu sasauṣṭhavaśca lakṣyeṣu pātaḥ sadṛśaḥ śarāṇām ||
translation: The body, due to its being established, abandons [its place] in situations where it is supposed to depart; and in situations where it is supposed to be steady, it falters; just as an arrow does in designated targets.

sloka: parasya bhūyānvivare'bhiyogaḥ prasahya saṃrakṣaṇamātmarandhre | bhīṣme'pyasaṃbhāvyamidaṃ gurau vā na saṃbhavatyeva vanecareṣu ||
translation: The forcible protection of another's property is inappropriate and unlikely to occur, whether it be in the context of Bhishma or a teacher; it certainly does not happen in the forest-dwelling ascetic community.

sloka: aprākṛtasyāhavadurmadasya nivāryamasyāstrabalena vīryam | alpīyaso'pyāmayatulyavṛttermahāpakārāya riporvivṛddhiḥ ||
translation: Even a weak person, by employing the power of a weapon, can subdue the extremely harmful influence of the unmanifest (prākṛtasya). Indeed, such suppression leads to a great benefit for all.

sloka: sa sa saṃpradhāryaivamahāryasāraḥ sāraṃ vineṣyansagaṇasya śatroḥ | prasvāpanāstraṃ drutamājahāra dhvāntaṃ nānaddha ivārdharātraḥ ||
translation: Having learned this [knowledge] from the great sage, the best of warriors reduces the enemy's army, quickly seizes the weapon that causes unconsciousness, as if it were not even midday.

sloka: prasaktadāvānaladhūmadhūmrā nirundhatī dhāma sahasraraśmeḥ | mahāvanānīva mahātamisrā chāyā tatāneśabalāni kālī ||
translation: Engulfed by the dense smoke of a raging fire, hidden is the abode of the thousand-rayed one, like a great cloud covering a great power, as the shadow of darkness called Kali.

sloka: āsāditā tatprathamaṃ prasahya pragalbhatāyāḥ padavīṃ harantī | sabheva bhīmā vidadhe gaṇānāṃ nidrā nirāsaṃ pratibhāguṇasya ||
translation: Having initiated it, she who possesses boldness forcibly seizes the foremost position, just like a terrifying elephant in a gathering; she dispels sleep's inertia, becoming a stimulant for the qualities of brilliance.

sloka: gurusthirāṇyuttamavaṃsajatvādvijñātasārāṇyanuśīlanena | kecitsamāśritya guṇānvitāni suhṛnkulānīva dhanūṃṣi tasthuḥ ||
translation: Some, taking refuge in the well-known ancestry of the best preceptors, have established themselves like choice bow(s) in noble families, endowed with virtues.

sloka: kṛtāntadurvṛtta ivāpareṣāṃ puraḥ pratidvandvini pāṇḍavāstre | atarkitaṃ pāṇitalānnipetuḥ kriyāphalānīva tadāyudhāni ||
translation: Like a previously inauspicious deed coming to fruition for others, the weapons of the Pāndava remain unfired, as if waiting, when enemies approach unchecked in battle.

sloka: aṃsasthalaiḥ kecidabhinnadhairyāḥ skandheṣu saṃślevatāṃ tarūṇām | madena mīlannayanāḥ salīlaṃ nāgā iva srastakarā niṣeduḥ ||
translation: Some, with unbroken courage, have climbed up the trunks of young trees and sit there entwined. With their eyes merged in deep contemplation, they resemble serpents resting on a riverbank, having drunktheir fill of water.

sloka: tirohitendoratha śaṃbhumūrdhnaḥ praṇamyamānaṃ tapasāṃ nivāsaiḥ | sumeruśṛṅgādiva bimbamārkaṃ piśaṅgamuccairudiyāya tejaḥ ||
translation: Worshiped by the ascetics dwelling near the peak of Mount Sumeru, the golden-hued sun, compared to a shining crown jewel on Shambhu's (Lord Shiva's) head, rises upwards, unveiling its radiance.

sloka: chāyāṃ vinirdhūya tamomayīṃ tāṃ tattvasya saṃvittirivāpavidyām | yayau vikāsaṃ dyutirindumaulerālokamabhyādiśatī gaṇebhyaḥ ||
translation: Dispelling the darkness of ignorance, the consciousness of the truth illuminated its own radiance like the moon's rays, and illuminated the assemblies.

sloka: tviṣāṃ tatiḥ pāṭalitāmbuvāhā sā sarvataḥ pūrvasarīva saṃdhyā | nināya teṣāṃ drutamullasantī vinidratāṃ locanapaṅkajāni ||
translation: Leader of luster, you make the root of the deep blue lotus flower bloom quickly; O sandhyā, you bring close the drooping lotus-like eyes of them (the beings) everywhere, as they become drowsy.

sloka: pṛthagvidhānyastravirāmabuddhāḥ śastrāṇi bhūyaḥ pratipedire te | muktā vitānena balāhakānāṃ jyotīṃṣi ramyā iva digvibhāgāḥ  ||
translation: Distinct types of weapons, having fully understood, are again and again wielded by them; like the sparkling stars, spreading in all directions, are the released missiles of the powerful commanders.

sloka: dyaurunnanāmeva diśaḥ praseduḥ sphuṭaṃ visasre saviturmayūkhaiḥ | gatāyāmiva yāmavatyāṃ punaḥ samīyāya dinaṃ dinaśrīḥ ||
translation: Just as the brightly shining sunrises in the named sky and the directions, similarly, each day, the sun sets in the Yamuna river's flow, only to rise again, bringing daily fortune.

sloka: mahāstradurge śithilaprayatnaṃ digvāraṇeneva pareṇa rugṇe | bhujaṅgapāśānbhujavīryaśālī prabandhanāya prajighāya jiṣṇuḥ ||
translation: The victorious one, effortlessly and like a universal emperor, secures himself with a serpent's power, by enclosing (the enemy) with his own strength, as if setting up a perimeter in a battlefield.

sloka: jihvāśatānyullasayantyajasraṃ lasattaḍillolaviṣānalāni | trāsānnirastāṃ bhujagendrasenā nabhaścaraistatpadavīṃ vivavre ||
translation: The hundred tongues of Indra's serpent army gleam and wave, banishing fear and becoming constantly radiant, they cover the expanse of the sky.

sloka: diṅgahastākṛtimudvahadbhirbhogaiḥ praśastāsitaratnanīlaiḥ | rarāja sarpāvalirullasantī taraṅgamāleva nabhorṇavasya ||
translation: Adorned with flawless, gem-studded, wavy forms, moving like a garland in the ocean of the sky, the serpent king Sesha shone brightly, bedecking all directions.

sloka: niḥśvāsadhūmaiḥ sthagitāṃśujālaṃ phaṇāvatāmutphaṇamaṇḍalānām | gacchannivāstaṃ vapurabhyuvāha vilocanānāṃ sukhamuṣṇaraśmiḥ ||
translation: Bearing a hooded snake's form, enveloped by smoke-like exhales, moving like a swaying hood, radiant like the warm sun's rays, does he bring delight to the eyes of all.

sloka: prataptacāmīkarabhāsureṇa diśaḥ prakāśena piśaṅganyantyaḥ | niścakramuḥ prāṇaharekṣaṇānāṃ jvālā maholkā iva locanebhyaḥ ||
translation: Illumined by the radiant splendor of Pratapta-Cāmīkara, the directions have spread out, like great flashes of lightening spreading out from the eyes.

sloka: ākṣiptasaṃpātamapetaśobhamudvahni dhūmākuladigvibhāgam | vṛtaṃ nabho bhogikulairavasthāṃ paroparuddhasya purasya bheje ||
translation: Surrounded by smoky clouds, raised by a gusty wind, and now separate from its shining beauty, such is the condition of this city's appearance.

sloka: tamāśu cakṣuḥśravasāṃ samūhaṃ mantreṇa tārkṣyodayakāraṇena | netā nayeneva paropajāpaṃ nivārayāmāsa patiḥ paśūnām ||
translation: The herdsman quickly dispersed, using a mantra as the cause, the gathering of blind senses and hearing in Tarkshya (eagle)’s ascent, just as one keeps away external prayers with "not these."

sloka: pratighnatībhiḥ kṛtamīlitāni dyulokabhājāmapi locanāni | garutmatāṃ saṃhatibhirvihāyaḥ kṣaṇaprakāśābhirivāvatene ||
translation: With glances illuminated by (the act of) averting (hostile) forces, even the eyes of celestial beings shine; emulating the swiftness of Garuda's flock, (but) only for a moment.

sloka: tataḥ suparṇavrajapakṣajanmā nānāgatirmaṇḍalayañjavena | jarattṛṇānīva viyannināya vanaspatīnāṃ gahanāni vāyuḥ ||
translation: Then, like a great bird (Garuda) named Suparṇa, with outspread wings, wind (Vāyu) moves among the dense treetops, as if swallowing up dry grass; assuming many forms and courses.

sloka: manaḥśilābhaṅganibhena paścānnirudhyamānaṃ nikareṇa bhāsām | vyūḍhairurobhiśca vinudyamānaṃ nabhaḥ sasarpeva puraḥ khagānām ||
translation: With the mind focused on the subtle form of a stone's fracture, in the rear, being illuminated by the rays, and agitated by the wings, the sky, resembling a serpent's hood, appears in front of the birds.

sloka: darīmukhairāsavarāgatāmraṃ vikāsi rukmacchadadhāma pītvā | javānilāghūrṇitasānujālo himācalaḥ kṣība ivācakampe ||
translation: Mountainlike Himācala, appearing to move like a wave when drunk from by darīmukha elephants, rises, its golden sheath having bloomed a deep red from the rāga of alcohol.

sloka: pravṛttanaktaṃdivasaṃdhidīptairnabhastalaṃ gāṃ ca piśaṅgayadbhiḥ | antarhitārkaiḥ paritaḥ patadbhiśchāyāḥ samācikṣipire vanānām ||
translation: Illuminated by celestial bodies during the day and by the stars at night, shaded by moving clouds, the earth is enveloped by the combined shade.

sloka: sa bhogisaṅghaḥ mamugradhāmnāṃ sainyena ninye vinatāsutānām | mahādhvare vidhyapacāradoṣaḥ karmāntareṇeva mahodayena ||
translation: The assembly of pleasure seekers has defeated with their military force the descendants of Vinata through the great sinful deed at the grand sacrifice, as if through an action different from but resembling the great rise/dawn.

sloka: sāphalyamastre ripupauruṣasya kṛtvā gate bhāgya ivāpavargam | anindhanasya prasabhaṃ samanyuḥ samādade'straṃ jvalanasya jiṣṇuḥ ||
translation: Gaining success on the battlefield, a worthy opponent meets his fate, as a blazing fire consumes its fuel; a patient and blameless warrior gains victory.

sloka: ūrdhvaṃ tiraścīnamadhaśca kīrṇairjvālāsaṭairlaṅghitameghapaṅktiḥ | āyastasiṃhākṛtirutpapāta prāṇyantamicchanniva jātavedāḥ ||
translation: Rising above, below, and across, filled with flames, the cloud formation has descended like a lion in its majestic form, as if the concealed fire of the sacrificial ritual has come to life.

sloka: bhittveva bhābhiḥ saviturmayūkhāñjajvāla viṣvagvistṛtasphuliṅgaḥ | vidīryamāṇāśmanināda dhīraṃ dhvaniṃ vitanvannakṛśaḥ kṛśānuḥ ||
translation: Like a spark detaching from a blazing sunbeam, spreading widely and thin, making a gentle, subtle sound – such is the disciplined, slender breath of life.

sloka: cayānivādrīniva tuṅgaśṛṅgānkvacitpurāṇīva hiraṇmayāni | mahāvanānīva ca kiṃśukānāṃ tatāna vahniḥ pavanānuvṛttyā ||
translation: Like the golden mountain peaks, towering and untainted, or ancient cities, or the tall flames of a blazing fire fanned by the wind, what can compare to the kimśukān?

sloka: muhuścalatpallavalohinībhiruccaiḥ śikhābhiḥ śikhino'valīḍhāḥ | taleṣu muktāviśadā babhūvuḥ sāndrāñjanaśyāmarucaḥ payodāḥ ||
translation: With constantly quivering peacock-plume crests, adorned with coral-red young shoots, they became embellished with sparkling drops of rainwater, like clouds darkened by collyrium, turning the water laden with their color.

sloka: lilikṣatīva kṣayakālaraudre lokaṃ vilolārciṣi rohitāśve | pinākinā hūtamahāmbuvāhamastraṃ punaḥ pāśabhṛtaḥ praṇinye ||
translation: Like a playful elephant in the autumn season, Rudra, having performed the great ablution ritual with water drawn by a looped rope, brandishes his weapon again.

sloka: tato dharitrīdharatulyarodhasastaḍillatāliṅgitanīlamūrtayaḥ | adhomukhākāśasarinnipātinīrapaḥ prasaktaṃ mumucuḥ payomucaḥ ||
translation: From that point, beings stuck in a form resembling the earth with equal weight and size, and marked by the characteristics of water, flowing downwards towards the sky, suddenly broke free and escaped in the form of liquid rain.

sloka: parāhatadhvastaśikhe śikhāvato vapuṣyadhikṣiptasamiddhatejasi | kṛtāspadāstapta ivāyasi dhvaniṃ payonipātāḥ prathame vitetire ||
translation: Struck by an external force, your crest adorned with feathers has been destroyed, your radiant form has been thrown off balance, as if a stake has been driven through it; the sound of your fall reverberates like thunder in the sky.

sloka: mahānale bhinnasitābhrapātibhiḥ sametya sadyaḥ kvathanena phenatām | vrajadbhirārdrendhanavatparikṣayaṃ jalairvitene divi dhūmasaṃtatiḥ ||
translation: A sudden and complete dispersion in the sky is occurring as great clouds, previously split apart, come together again at this moment, caused by some unknown agency; a column of smoke-like formation is arising, examined by the movement of birds flying in various directions, indicating the presence of water in the atmosphere in divi (the sky).

sloka: svaketubhiḥ pāṇḍuranīlapāṭalaiḥ samāgatāḥ śakradhanuḥprabhābhidaḥ | asaṃsthitāmādadhire vibhāvasorvicitracīnāṃśukacārutāṃ tviṣaḥ ||
translation: Gathered with their own bright, blue, and dark blue flags, they shine as Indra's banner does, revealing variously hued, gentle breezes that adorn the sky's luster.

sloka: jalaughasaṃmūrcchanamūrcchitasvanaḥ prasaktavidyullasitaidhitadyutiḥ | praśāntimeṣyandhutadhūmamaṇḍalo babhūva bhūyāniva tatra pāvakaḥ ||
translation: The pond, agitated by the splash of water, became still; its surface glowed with reflected light as if a new fire had emerged there, lit by the bright flash of lightning.

sloka: pravṛddhasindhūrmicayasthavīyasāṃ cayairvibhinnāḥ payasāṃ prapedire | upāttasaṃdhyārucibhiḥ sarūpatāṃ payodavicchedalavaiḥ kṛśānavaḥ ||
translation: Separated by the divisions of rainwater collected in a pond that has greatly increased in size, the individual raindrops merge with the water bodies' own form, becoming indistinguishable, impelled by the attraction of twilight's allure.

sloka: upaityanantadyutirapyasaṃśayaṃ vibhinnamūlo'nudayāya saṃkṣayam | tathā hi toyaughavibhinnasaṃhatiḥ sa havyavāhaḥ prayayau parābhavam ||
translation: Approaching unceasingly, the radiant one, without a doubt, splits apart at the root for the purpose of both rise and fall. Thus, the collection of waters has flowed to its defeat.

sloka: atha vihitavidheyairāśu muktā vitānai rasitanaganitambaśyāmabhāsāṃ ghanānām | vikasadamaladhāmnāṃ prāpa nīlotpalānāṃ śriyamadhikaviśuddhāṃ vahnidāhādiva dyauḥ ||
translation: Then, by quickly releasing the pre-ordained commands, a more pure radiance, like that of the sky ignited by fire, is obtained as the blue lotuses blossom, their unblemished stalks opening up in the vitānai grass.

sloka: iti vividhamudāse savyasācī yadastraṃ bahusamaranayajñaḥ sādayiṣyannarātim | vidhiriva viparītaḥ pauruṣaṃ nyāyavṛtteḥ sapadi tadupaninye riktatāṃ nīlakaṇṭhaḥ ||
translation: In this manner, accomplished in various moods, the left-handed archer, well-versed in many battles, will support the enemy's army, just as the contrary of proper conduct occurs suddenly for one practicing unjust actions, then, Nilakantha quickly attains utter destitution.

sloka: vītaprabhāvatanurapyattanuprabhāvaḥ pratyācakāṅkṣa jayinīṃ bhujavīryalakṣmīm | astreṣu bhūtapatināpahṛteṣu jiṣṇurvarṣiṣyatā dinakṛteva jaleṣu lokaḥ ||
translation: Even one who has overcome their inherent power, longs for the victory-granting, arm-strength beauty of hers, as a victor does for sunlight, when heroic beings have been destroyed by time in the universe, just as water does in the presence of sunlight.

sloka: athāpadāmuddharaṇakṣameṣu mitreṣvivāstreṣu tirohiteṣu | dhṛtiṃ guruśrīrguruṇābhipuṣyansvapauruṣeṇeva śarāsanena ||
translation: Now, in situations of lifting a weapon or protecting friends, just like using one's own sharp-edged arrow, one should be endowed with steadfastness, inspired by the greatness of the guru.

sloka: bhūriprabhāveṇa raṇābhiyogātprīto vijihmaśca tadīyavṛddhyā | spaṣṭo'pyavispaṣṭavapuḥprakāśaḥ sarpanmahādhūma ivādrivahniḥ ||
translation: Greatly exhilarated by the eagerness in battle, and growing fonder of it, he appears manifest, though his form is unclear; like a huge fire mixed with smoke, or a great mountain peak shining in the sunlight.

sloka: tejaḥ samāśritya parairahāryaṃ nijaṃ mahanmitramivorudhairyam | āsādayannaskhalitasbhāvaṃ bhīme bhujālambamivāridurge ||
translation: Drawing strength from their own brilliance, resolute like a firm support in the arm, they rob others' wealth while also protecting their own dear friend like a mighty hero in a difficult battlefield.

sloka: vaṃśocitatvādabhimānavatyā saṃprāptayā saṃpriyatāmasubhyaḥ | samakṣamāditsitayā pareṇa vadhveva kīrtyā paritapyamānaḥ ||
translation: Gaining arrogance due to ancestral glory, tormented by envy towards equals, and constantly anxious due to fame, even in a battle against an enemy.

sloka: patiṃ nagānāmiva baddhamūlamunmūlayiṣyaṃstarasā vipakṣam | laghuprayatnaṃ nigṛhītavīryastrimārgagāvega iveśvareṇa ||
translation: Like the root of a tree firmly grasped by a king of serpents, the Lord swiftly restrains the opposing force's power, exerting only slight effort on the threefold path.

sloka: saṃskāravattvādramayatsu cetaḥ prayogaśikṣāguṇabhūṣaṇeṣu | jayaṃ yathārtheṣu śareṣu pārthaḥ śabdeṣu bhāvārthamivāśaśaṃse ||
translation: In the cultivation of habits and tendencies, O Partha, just as victory is achieved in battle according to their true nature, so also should one properly strive in the application, study, and adornment of words, ascertaining their true meaning, and avoiding false notions.

sloka: bhūyaḥ samādhānavivṛddhatejā naivaṃ purā yuddhamiti vyathāvān | sa nirvavāmāsramamarṣanunnaṃ viṣaṃ mahānāga ivekṣaṇābhyām ||
translation: Further increasing his resolve and inner strength, he examines carefully, as a large serpent would inspect food, whether such a battle as this has ever caused him such great distress in the past.

sloka: tasyāhavāyāsavilolamauleḥ saṃrambhatāmrāyataṃlocanasya | nirvāpayiṣyanniva roṣataptaṃ prasnāpayāmāsa mukhaṃ nidāghaḥ ||
translation: The flushed (with excitement) one, as if to soothe his rage, spoke to the heated (with anger) one, who had eyes widened with agitation and whose crest was trembling from the excitement, and asked him to calm down.

sloka: krodhāndhakārāntarito raṇāya bhrūbhedarekhāḥ sa babhāra tisraḥ | ghanoparuddhaḥ prabhavāya vṛṣṭerūrdhvāṃśurājīriva tigmaraśmiḥ ||
translation: With three piercing, sharp beams like a cloud bursting forth in battle, (the sun) illuminated, having risen above the darkness of anger.

sloka: sa pradhvanayyambudanādi cāpaṃ hastena diṅnāga ivādriśṛṅgam | balāni śaṃbhoriṣubhistatāpa cetāṃsi cintābhirivāśarīraḥ ||
translation: Wielding, like Indra, a rain-giving bow that resembles a mountain peak, Shambhu is armed with arrows that are his powers; his mind consumed by anxious thoughts, he dwells within the body.

sloka: sadvāditevābhiniviṣṭabuddhau guṇābhyasūyeva vipakṣapāte | agocare vāgiva copareme śaktiḥ śarāṇāṃ śitikaṇṭhakāye ||
translation: In a truthful mind, fully engaged, as if absorbed in the qualities, even while rejecting those on the opposite side, power, like speech, is present in things that shoot [like arrows], such as the cool-throated [weapon] of Shiva.

sloka: umāpatiṃ pāṇḍusutapraṇunnāḥ śilīmukhā na vyathayāṃbabhūvuḥ | abhyutthitasyādripaternitambamarkasya pādā iva haimanasya ||
translation: Upon seeing the spouse of Uma, the son of Pandu, named Shilimukha did not experience any distress, just as the golden mountain's foot does not shake when it rises.

sloka: saṃprīyamāṇo'nubabhūva tīvraṃ parākramaṃ tasya patirgaṇānām | viṣāṇabhedaṃ himavānasahyaṃ vaprānatasyeva suradvipasya ||
translation: Being accepted, he [the Lord] subsequently displayed intense prowess; his command extends over all groups of Gaṇas; his subduing of the serpent king, impossible for even Himavat to accomplish, was like the taming of a small snake by a powerful man; such is the might of the bestower of blessings to Suradvipa.

sloka: tasmai hi bhāroddharaṇe samarthaṃ pradāsyatā bāhumiva pratāpam | ciraṃ viṣehe'bhibhavastadānīṃ sa kāraṇānāmapi kāraṇena ||
translation: For him, capable of lifting the burden, will bestow strength like a strong arm, able to withstand adversity for a long time, by that very cause, even among all other causes.

sloka: pratyāhataujāḥ kṛtasattvavegaḥ parākramaṃ jyāyasi yastanoti | tejāṃsi bhānoriva niṣpatanti yaśāṃsi vīryajvalitāni tasya ||
translation: The one who has controlled and harnessed their inner strength, whose prowess surpasses all, from whom shine forth radiant fame and valor like light from a luminous body, such a person is exceptional.

sloka: dṛṣṭāvadānādvyathate'rilokaḥ pradhvaṃsameti vyathitācca tejaḥ | tejovihīnaṃ vijahāti darpaḥ śāntārciṣaṃ dīpamiva prakāśaḥ ||
translation: Upon seeing a giving person, the world rejoices and thrives, but pride leaves one who lacks generosity, just as a light dims without fuel.

sloka: tataḥ prayātyastamadāvalepaḥ sa jayyatāyāḥ padavīṃ jigīṣoḥ | gandhena jetuḥ pramukhāgatasya pratidvipasyeva mataṅgajaughaḥ ||
translation: After that, the elephant named Mataṅga, approaching the path of the one seeking victory, tries to defeat him with his scent, just as a rival would.

sloka: evaṃ pratidvandviṣu tasya kīrtiṃ maulīndulekhāviśadāṃ vidhāsyan | iyeṣa paryāyajayāvasādāṃ raṇakriyāṃ śaṃbhuranukrameṇa ||
translation: In this way, establishing his fame, shining like the autumn moon, thus does Śambhu gradually engage in the battle, following the sequence of appropriate steps.

sloka: munervicitrairiṣubhiḥ sa bhūyānninye vaśaṃ bhūtapaterbalaughaḥ | sahātmalābhena samutpatadbhirjātisvabhāvairiva jīvalokaḥ ||
translation: Like a lord of creatures, endowed with superior strength, emerging life in the world with his own natural qualities, just as instigated by Indra with various weapons.

sloka: vitanvatastasya śarāndhakāraṃ trastāni sainyāni ravaṃ niśemuḥ | pravarṣataḥ saṃtatavepathūni kṣapāghanasyeva gavāṃ kulāni ||
translation: Spreading out his arrow's range, anxious armies of his are trembling, as if herds of cattle are being drenched by a steady downpour, for he who is the subduer of the night.

sloka: sa sāyakānsādhvasaviplutānāṃ kṣipanpareṣāmatisauṣṭhavena | śaśīva doṣāvṛtalocanānāṃ vibhidyamānaḥ pṛthagābabhāse ||
translation: With supreme precision, he who lets fly the arrows at the onrushing enemy, seems to split apart the defect-covered eyes of the moon-like warriors, appearing distinctly.

sloka: kṣobheṇa tenātha gaṇādhipānāṃ bhedaṃ yayāvākṛtirīśvarasya | taraṅgakampena mahāhradānāṃ chāyāmayasyeva dinasya bhartuḥ ||
translation: With what agitation, through which did the leader of groups [of beings] experience a division, like the shadow of the lord of days [sun] experiences a disturbance in the great water bodies?

sloka: prasedivāṃsaṃ na tamāpa kopaḥ kutaḥ parasminpuruṣe vikāraḥ | ākāravaiṣamyamidaṃ ca bheje durlakṣyacihnā mahatāṃ hi vṛttiḥ ||
translation: The agitation of the mind cannot reach that one who has fully mastered himself, nor can any change be found in that supreme being. This is because the distinctive marks of such great individuals are subtle and difficult to see.

sloka: visphāryamāṇasya tato bhujābhyāṃ bhūtāni bhartrā dhanurantakasya | bhinnākṛtiṃ jyāṃ dadṛśuḥ sphurantīṃ kruddhasya jihvāmiva takṣakasya ||
translation: As the bowstring is being drawn back, the creatures see the twang of the bow of the angry one take on a different form, as if it were the tongue of a serpent.
