sloka: savyāpasavyadhvanitogracāpaṃ pārthaḥ kirātādhipamāśaśaṅke | paryāyasaṃpāditakarṇatālaṃ yantā gajaṃ vyālamivāparāddhaḥ ||
translation: Partha, acting as a left-handed warrior, has strung the fierce bow, taking up the Kirata king's challenge, as if he is not worried about the approaching elephant, just like an expert using a machine.

sloka: nijaghnire tasya hareṣujālaiḥ patanti vṛndāni śilīmukhānām | tejasvibhiḥ sindhumukhāgatāni yādāṃsi yādobhirivāmburāśeḥ ||
translation: The arrows of Hara (Lord Shiva) have pierced and made fallen all around the tufts of reeds, just as masses of clouds reach the mouths of rivers; such (are) the torrents (that come) from the rainclouds.

sloka: vicchedamantaḥ padavīnirodhaṃ vidhvaṃsanaṃ cāviditaprayogaḥ | netārilokeṣu karoti yadyattataccakārāsya śareṣu śaṃbhuḥ ||
translation: The destroyer, Shambhu, skillfully uses the piercing weapon, ending the suppression of paths when such a need arises in that world.

sloka: soḍhāvagītaprathamāyudhasya krodhojjhitairvegitayā patadbhiḥ | chinnairapi trāsitavāhinīkaiḥ pete kṛtārthairiva tasya bāṇaiḥ ||
translation: The initial anger of the warrior, who has not been challenged in combat, has been abandoned through his forcibly thrown weapons; his arrows, even those that have only grazed the enemy's vehicles, are considered to have accomplished their purpose.

sloka: alaṃkṛtānāmṛjutāguṇena gurūpadiṣṭāṃ gatimāsthitānām | satāmivāparvaṇi mārgaṇānāṃ bhaṅgaḥ sa jiṣṇordhṛtimunmamātha ||
translation: For those who have followed the guru's taught path of refined qualities, the end of the journey of sages is like the breaking of an arrow at the completion of a religious rite. Indeed, Jiṣṇu has attained firmness.

sloka: bāṇacchidaste viśikhāḥ smarāreravāṅmukhībhūtaphalāḥ patantaḥ | akhaṇḍitaṃ pāṇḍavasāyakebhyaḥ kṛtasya sadyaḥ pratikāramāpuḥ ||
translation: Arrows shattered, (their) tips now resemble the speech of one who remembers, falling like unbroken fruits from the bow of the Pāṇḍava. A swift retribution for what was done.

sloka: citrīyamāṇānatilāghavena pramāthinastānbhavamārgaṇānām | samākulāyā nicakhāna dūraṃ bāṇāndhvajinyā hṛdayeṣvarātiḥ ||
translation:
Pursuing the targets of the unsteady disturbed mind,
With arrows labeled "mine" in the heart,
How can one approach the distant divine?

sloka: tasyātiyatnādatiricyamāne parākrame'nyonyaviśeṣaṇena | hantā purāṃ bhūri pṛṣatkavarṣaṃ nirāsa naidāgha ivāmbu meghaḥ ||
translation: With utmost effort exerted in that [particular] endeavor, like a rain cloud shedding a heavy shower to alleviate the drought, the warrior, comparing to others, vanquishes [the enemy].

sloka: anāmṛśantaḥ kvacideva marma priyaiṣiṇānuprahitāḥ śivena | suhṛtprayuktā iva narmavādāḥ śarā muneḥ prītikarā babhūvuḥ ||
translation: Occasionally, indeed, some have become playful speakers, drawing near to the beloved's vulnerable spots, as if they are friendly and associated with auspiciousness, towards the sage's arrows of affection.

sloka: astraiḥ samānāmatirekiṇīṃ vā paśyanniṣūṇāpi tasya śaktim | viṣādavaktavyabalaḥ pramāthī svamālalambe balamindumauliḥ ||
translation: Even one who, armed with equal weapons, observes (an opponent) in the middle of a battlefield, if they despair and fail to speak up or act, their strength and valor, like a snake hidden in a hole, remains dormant.

sloka: tatastapovīryasamuddhatasya pāraṃ yiyāsoḥ samarārṇavasya | maheṣujālānyakhilāni jiṣṇorarkaḥ payāṃsīva samācacāma ||
translation: Then, having emerged with vigor from austerities, the sun, like a great archer, strung all the waters of the ocean of the great battle with his arrows.

sloka: rikte savisrambhamathārjunasya niṣaṅgavaktre nipapāta pāṇiḥ | anyadvipāpītajale satarṣaṃ mataṅgajasyeva nagāśmarandhre ||
translation: Offering his hand in friendly greeting, the lion-like Arjuna, free from pride, descended to the underwater cave, as if it were a mere puddle, to meet the wise Mattangajasha, who lived there, just like one would approach any other person on a regular ground.

sloka: cyute sa tasminniṣudhau śarārthāddhvastārthasāre sahaseva bandhau | tatkālamoghapraṇayaḥ prapede nirvācyatākāma ivābhimukhyam ||
translation: Upon the release of the arrow in that very moment, having destroyed its intended purpose, along with the one who had been serving as an ally, just as a desire that has been rendered fruitless approaches, so too does it meet its end, facing utter rejection.

sloka: āghaṭṭayāmāsa gatāgatābhyāṃ sā vegamagrāṅgulirasya tūṇau | vidheyamārge matirutsukasya nayaprayogāviva gāṃ jigīṣoḥ ||
translation: With a thrust, the eager one should apply force to the pair of moving parts at the front end of the plow, as if setting the mind on the path of duty, just like a eager farmer desires for the cow to move.

sloka: babhāra śūnyākṛtirarjunastau maheṣudhī vītamaheṣujālau | yugāntasaṃśuṣkajalau vijihmaḥ pūrvāparau loka ivāmburāśī ||
translation: Arjuna, like a pair of powerful serpents, moved in the beginning and end of the universe, emerging from the dried up oceans of the yuga-antas, assuming the form of emptiness.

sloka: tenānimittena tathā na pārthastayoryathā riktatayānutepe | svāmāpadaṃ projjhya vipattimagnaṃ śocanti santo hyupakāripakṣam ||
translation: Even the sages mourn for one, who, without using proper means, discards their own well-being and falls into distress, and for that person who takes sides against those who deserve help.

sloka: pratikriyāyai vidhuraḥ sa tasmātkṛcchreṇa viśleṣamiyāya hastaḥ | parāṅmukhatve'pi kṛtopakārāttūṇīmukhānmitrakulādivāryaḥ ||
translation: Even a virtuous person, in response to hostility, detaches themselves from it with difficulty, yet remains friendly towards those who show enmity towards him, along with their families and communities.

sloka: paścātkriyā tūṇayugasya bharturjajñe tadānīmupakāriṇīva | saṃbhāvanāyāmadharīkṛtāyāṃ patyuḥ puraḥ sāhasamāsitavyam ||
translation: Afterward, as the wife has made up her mind, she should firmly muster the courage to act as a helpmate for her husband, who has just performed the sacrificial rite.

sloka: taṃ śaṃbhurākṣiptamaheṣujālaṃ lauhaiḥ śarairmarmasu nistutoda | hṛtottaraṃ tattvavicāramadhye vakteva doṣairgurubhirvipakṣam ||
translation: "Lord Shiva said, 'O great one, your misdeeds, like a trap made of iron arrows, have found weaknesses in the hearts of others, just as a skilled archer finds their mark. Now, submit yourself to an analysis of truth, for your faults, as if spoken by your opposing teachers, will no longer go unnoticed.'"

sloka: jahāra cāsmādacireṇa varma jvalanmaṇidyotitahemalekham | caṇḍaḥ pataṃgānmarudekanīlaṃ taḍitvataḥ khaṇḍamivāmbudasya ||
translation: The one who, compared to earlier, has now acquired this armor, shining like a streak of lightning, that can shatter the dark cloud, tearing it apart; who is he?

sloka: vikośanirdhautatanormahāseḥ phaṇāvataśca tvaci vicyutāyām | pratidvipābaddharuṣaḥ samakṣaṃ nāgasya cākṣiptamukhacchadasya ||
translation: On the hood of the immense serpent, whose hoods have been cleansed, and whose hood is unfurled, the anger of the snake, bound to each island, is evident; his agitated mouth open wide.

sloka: vibodhitasya dhvaninā ghanānāṃ harerapetasya ca śailarandhrāt | nirastadhūmasya ca rātrivahnervinā tanutreṇa ruciṃ sa bheje ||
translation: With the sound of his conch, the awakened one, Lord Hari, dispelled the darkness from the cave of the mountain as well as the smoke from the night fire, revealing its true luster.

sloka: acittatāyāmapi nāma yuktāmanūrdhvatāṃ prāpya tadīyakṛcchre | mahīṃ gatau tāviṣudhī tadānīṃ vivavratuścetanayeva yogam ||
translation: Upon attaining mental concentration, even that named 'acittatā,' the purest yogic state is achieved, making the impure mind capable of resting on the earthly plane, like a cleansed vessel.

sloka: sthitaṃ viśuddhe nabhasīva satve dhāmnā tapovīryamayena yuktam | śastrābhighātaistamajasramīśastvaṣṭā vivasvantamivollilekha ||
translation: Firmly established in the pure sky-like expanse, united with a strength born from austerity and good character, just as the sun continuously rises, so too does Tvastr, the divine craftsman, constantly illuminate.

sloka: saṃrambhavegojjhitavedaneṣu gātreṣu bādhiryamupāgateṣu | munerbabhūvāṇiteṣurāśerlauhastiraskāra ivātmamanyuḥ ||
translation: In the presence of a sage, when excitement and haste arise in relation to sensory experiences in the body, it is as if one's own self is a deafening iron tool in one's hand.

sloka: tato'nupūrvāyatavṛttabāhuḥ śrīmānkṣarallohitadigdhadehaḥ | āskandya vegena vimuktanādaḥ kṣitiṃ vidhunvanniva pārṣṇighātaiḥ ||
translation: Then, with arms outstretched in a manner beyond usual, the resplendent one, whose body is anointed with sacred substances, shakes the earth with a thunderous sound, as if wielding a weapon, with a swift and forceful release.

sloka: sāmyaṃ gatenāśaninā maghonaḥ śaśāṅkakhaṇḍākṛtipāṇḍureṇa | śaṃbhuṃ bibhitsurdhanuṣā jaghāna stambaṃ viṣāṇena mahānivebhaḥ ||
translation: Having approached Shambhu in the guise of a sage with a slender body bearing the crescent moon on his crest, Mahadeva, in the form resembling a mighty elephant, struck down the pillar with his deadly, irresistible weapon.

sloka: rayeṇa sā saṃnidadhe patantī bhavodbhavenātmani cāpayaṣṭiḥ | samuddhatā sindhuranekamārgā pare sthitenaujasi jahnuneva ||
translation: With a weapon (cāpa) named "rayeṇa" (prosperity), she who holds together (sā, san, nidadhe) sets in motion (patantī) the natural tendency (bhavā) of the self (udbhavena, ātmani) to aim (apayaṣṭiḥ) for a single (aneka, mārgā) path (mārgā) among those (pare) that have arisen (samuddhatā) like the sun (ojasi) in the midst of a vast expanse of water (sindhuḥ). She does this as if (iva) she were "jahnunā" (a name for Indra).

sloka: vikārmukaḥ karmasu śocanīyaḥ paricyutaudārya ivopacāraḥ | vivikṣipe śūlabhṛtā salīlaṃ sa patribhirdūramadūrapātaiḥ ||
translation: Regrettable is the action performed by one who is averse to change, like a servile offering made reluctantly and out of duty, who pours water using a sharpened stick on a secluded peak, far from the sight of others.

sloka: upoḍhakalyāṇaphalo'bhirakṣanvīravrataṃ puṇyaraṇāśramasthaḥ | japopavāsairiva saṃyatātmā tepe munistairiṣubhiḥ śivasya ||
translation: A sage, established in the holy retreat, devoted to protecting (others) with valor and virtue's fruit, self-restrained through austerities like constant chanting and fasting, endures with arrows (the insults) of adversaries, for Shiva's sake.

sloka: tato'grabhūmiṃ vyavasāyasiddheḥ sīmānamanyairatidustaraṃ saḥ | tejaḥśriyāmāśrayamuttamāsiṃ sākṣādahaṃkāramivālalambe ||
translation: Having achieved the mark of unwavering determination, he then firmly established himself on the ground, standing out far beyond others in his accomplishments. His radiant power and splendor took on a form that directly revealed his self-confidence, as if he were embracing his own ego.

sloka: śarānavadyannanavadyakarmā cacāra citraṃ pravicāramārgaiḥ | hastena nistriṃśabhṛtā sa dīptaḥ sārkāṃśunā vāridhirūrmiṇeva ||
translation: Proceeding unerringly, just like the sun's rays, unstained by actions, in various paths, wielding a water pot, he/she shines brightly, like a ray of sunlight on water.

sloka: yathā nije vartmani bhāti bhābhiśchāyāmayaścāpsu sahasraraśmiḥ | tathā nabhasyāśu raṇasthalīṣu spaṣṭadvimūrtirdadṛśe sa bhūtaiḥ ||
translation: Just as a thousand rays, illuminated by their own nature, shine forth in the water; so too does a distinct, multiform entity become clearly visible in the sky during the rapidity of a battlefield.

sloka: śivapraṇunnena śilīmukhena tsarupradeśādapavarjitāṅgaḥ | jvalannasistasya papātaṃ pāṇerghanasya vaprādiva vaidyuto'gniḥ ||
translation: With a tip dipped in auspicious materials, like the fire that falls, completely free from impurities, as a flash of lightning from the sky, falling on the body of the one who is engaged in austerities, having a glowing appearance.

sloka: ākṣiptacāpāvaraṇeṣujālaśchinnottamāsiḥ sa mṛdhedhūtaḥ | riktaḥ prakāśaśca babhūva bhūmerutsāditodyāna ivaṃ pradeśaḥ ||
translation: The target of the arrow, torn away, lies uncovered; becoming manifest, it becomes like a field irrigated by the merging rivers of earth.

sloka: sa khaṇḍanaṃ prāpya parādamarṣavānbhujadvitīyo'pi vijetumicchayā | sasarja vṛṣṭiṃ parirugṇapādapāṃ dravetareṣāṃ payasāmivāśmanām ||
translation: Having obtained the power to shatter [the enemy], desiring even to conquer in his second attempt, he unleashed a shower of arrows upon them, as if pouring down rain upon a group of stones.

sloka: nīrandhraṃ parigamite kṣayaṃ pṛṣatkairbhūtānāmadhipatinā śilāvitāne | ucchrāyasthagitanabhodigantarālaṃ cikṣepa kṣitiruhajālamindrasūnuḥ ||
translation: The earth's daughter, having approached and entered the cave, as a rain shower did the lord of mountains scatter the amassed collection in the interior of the rocky crevices; Indra's son, having made it arise.

sloka: niḥśeṣaṃ śakalitavalkalāṅgasāraiḥ kurvadbhirbhuvamabhitaḥ kaṣāyacitrām | īśānaḥ sakusumapallavairnagaistairātene balimiva raṅgadevatābhyaḥ ||
translation: The supreme lord, Īśāna, adorned with flowers, is made manifest in the world through every subtle detail of the assemblies of plant life, appearing like a sacrificial offering amidst various divine forms in the sky, assuming a form like that.

sloka: unmajjanmakara ivāmarāpagāyā vegena pratimukhametya bāṇanadyāḥ | gāṇḍīvī kanakaśilānibhaṃ bhujābhyāmājaghne viṣamavilocanasya vṛkṣaḥ ||
translation: Like a crocodile emerging from the water, arrows released from bows rush towards the fearsome, multi-eyed tree that was struck by the golden Gāṇḍīva weapon held in both arms, eager to drink the amṛta that flows from Indra's celestial realm.

sloka: abhilaṣata upāyaṃ vikramaṃ kīrtilakṣmyorasugamamarisainyairaṅkamabhyāgatasya | janaka iva śiśutve supriyasyaikasūnoravinayamapi sehe pāṇḍavasya smarāriḥ ||
translation: Just as King Janaka tolerates the disobedience of his beloved, only son, who has been approached by the enthusiastic army of rivals seeking victory and fame, so too does the rememberer of the Pandava endure.

sloka: tata udagra iva dvirade munau raṇamupeyuṣi bhīmabhujāyudhe | dhanurapāsya sabāṇadhi śaṃkaraḥ pratijaghāna ghanairiva muṣṭibhiḥ ||
translation: From there, resembling a turtle, the powerful Bhima, armed with a mace, prepared for battle against the two-wheeled chariot-riding Munis; Shankara, brandishing his bow, countered them with a hail of dense projectiles, just like a cloud.

sloka: harapṛthāsutayordhvanirutpatannamṛdusaṃvalitāṅgulipāṇijaḥ | sphuṭadanalpaśilāravadāruṇaḥ pratinanāda darīṣu darībhṛtaḥ ||
translation: Hara, born from the earth, whose body is covered in mud and adorned with small pieces of gravel, loudly sounded his barbaric cry, reverberating in the direction he faced.

sloka: śivabhujāhatibhinnapṛthukṣatīḥ sukhamivānubabhūva kapidhvajaḥ | ka iva nāma bṛhanmanasāṃ bhavedanukṛterapi sattvavatāṃ kṣamaḥ ||
translation: Like a thunderbolt striking the naturally fierce and mighty Shiva, who might be patient and forgiving even towards those who, despite their great wisdom, commit wrongs?

sloka: vraṇamukhacyutaśoṇitaśīrasthagitaśailataṭābhabhujāntaraḥ | abhinavauṣasarāgabhṛtā babhau jaladhareṇa samānamumāpatiḥ ||
translation: Freshly adorned with newly bloomed saraka flowers, Uma's consort, resembling the ocean, shines, his body adorned with a garland, blood dripping from his mouth, wounds, and hair, after slaying the buffalo demon.

sloka: urasi śūlabhṛtaḥ prahitā muhuḥ pratihatiṃ yayurarjunavṛṣṭayaḥ | bhṛśarayā iva sahyamahībhṛtaḥ pṛthuni rodhasi sindhumahormayaḥ ||
translation: Time and again, spears sent upon Arjuna from the sky were intercepted as if a great mountain range was stopping a massive flood.

sloka: nipatite'dhiśirodharamāyate samamaratniyuge'yugacakṣuṣaḥ | tricatureṣu padeṣu kirīṭinā lulitadṛṣṭi madādiva caskhale ||
translation: Upon the fall of his crown, the steadfast warrior's eyes match the pace of the twin grains of pearls, as if in a dance, as his gaze wavers, swayed by emotion, in the midst of the four quarters.

sloka: abhibhavoditamanyuvidīpitaḥ samabhisṛtya bhṛśaṃ javamojasā | bhujayugena vibhajya samādade śaśikalābharaṇasya bhujadvayam ||
translation: Having raised his anger that was previously suppressed, and making great efforts, he forcibly took apart the pair of arms [of the elephant] with his own pair of arms, and then placed [the elephant's] jewel-like tusks on one side.

sloka: pravavṛte'tha mahāhavamallayoracalasaṃcalanāharaṇo raṇaḥ | karaṇaśṛṅkhalasaṃkalanāgururgurubhujāyudhagarvitayostayoḥ ||
translation: The great battle of the unshakeable warriors has begun, their pride swelling with joined weapons, garlands, and ornaments.

sloka: ayamasau bhagavānuta pāṇḍavaḥ sthitamavāṅmuninā śaśimaulinā | samadhirūḍhamajena nu jiṣṇunā sviditi vegavaśānmumuhe gaṇaiḥ ||
translation: Is this the very Bhagavan, the Pandava, stationed by the moon-crested one, identified by the group as one who has mastered his senses, or is it someone else entirely?

sloka: pracalite calitaṃ sthitamāsthite vinamite natamunnatamunnatau | vṛṣakapidhvajayorasahiṣṇunā muhurabhāvabhayādiva bhūbhṛtā ||
translation: Withstanding, like a steady flagpole, the swaying of what's swaying, stable and unmoving in both ascension and descension; bearing, as does the earth, constant changes, fears, and even the absence of support.

sloka: karaṇaśṛṅkhalaniḥsṛtayostayoḥ kṛtabhujadhvani valgu vivalgatoḥ | caraṇapātanipātitarodhasaḥ prasasṛpuḥ saritaḥ paritaḥ sthalīḥ ||
translation: Surrounding the river, sprung from the fetters of the elephant's limbs, are the charming, delicate sounds produced by the striking of feet at their descent and rise.

sloka: viyati vegapariplutamantarā samabhisṛtya rayeṇa kapidhvajaḥ | caraṇayoścaraṇānamitakṣitirnijagṛhe tisṛṇāṃ jayinaṃ purām ||
translation: Having subdued the intense desire that was surging within, the monkey-bannered one, Kapidhvaja, emerged from his hermitage, victorious over the three; his steps unobstructed, marked by immeasurable glory and splendor.

sloka: vismitaḥ sapadi tena karmaṇā karmaṇāṃ kṣayakaraḥ paraḥ pumān | kṣeptukāmamavanau tamaklamaṃ niṣpipeṣa parirabhya vakṣasā ||
translation: struck with wonder, at that very moment; by that action, he who pursues the destruction of actions, the supreme man; should embrace, with a cloak, that weary one, who seeks to leave, from his chest.

sloka: tapasā tathā na mudamasya yayau bhagavānyathā vipulasattvatayā | guṇasaṃhateḥ samatiriktamaho nijameva sattvamupakāri satām ||
translation: With austerity, similarly not by mere pretense, has Bhagavan not departed elsewhere, but due to his abundant pure nature, separate from the collection of qualities, he himself enhances the pure nature of the virtuous.

sloka: atha himaśucibhasmabhūṣitaṃ śirasi virājitamindulekhayā | svavapuratimanoharaṃ haraṃ dadhatamudīkṣya nanāma pāṇḍavaḥ ||
translation: After that, seeing the divine one wearing a crown of white ash on his head and adorned with a garland that enhances his own captivating appearance, the Pandava bows in respect.

sloka: sahaśaradhi nijaṃ tathā kārmukaṃ vapuratanu tathaiva saṃvarmitam | nihitamapi tathaiva paśyannasiṃ vṛṣabhagatirupāyayau vismayam ||
translation: Perceiving his own form, adorned with a bow, unstrung, but ready for use, hidden within him, even the Lord of Vṛṣabha's gait would amaze.

sloka: siṣicuravanimambuvāhāḥ śanaiḥ surakusumamiyāya citraṃ divaḥ | vimalaruci bhṛśaṃ nabho dundubherdhvanirakhilamanāhatasyānaśe ||
translation: Irrigating the earth gently, just as a skilled one would, with showers arising from pure, lotus-like clouds, a sound resembling a drum echoes throughout the clear sky, extinguishing its silence.

sloka: āseduṣāṃ gotrabhido'nuvṛttyā gopāyakānāṃ bhuvanatrayasya | rociṣṇuratnāvalibhirvimānairdyaurācitā tārakiteva reje ||
translation: Of the separate herdsman groups, protecting the three worlds, like a resplendent star, endowed with radiant jewel-like qualities, who can guard the unguarded flocks?

sloka: haṃsā bṛhantaḥ surasadmavāhāḥ saṃhradikaṇṭhābharaṇāḥ patantaḥ | cakruḥ prayatnena vikīryamāṇairvyomnaḥ pariṣvaṅgamivāgrapakṣaiḥ ||
translation: Swans, large and divine, adorned with necklaces, are descending with a flapping sound similar to that of flags moved by the wind, making a conscious effort in the sky.

sloka: muditamadhuliho vitānīkṛtāḥ sraja upari vitatya sāṃtānikīḥ | jalada iva niṣedivāṃsaṃ vṛṣe marudupasukhayāṃbabhūveśvaram ||
translation: With joy, those who are elated and have spread out (their) flags high, resembling clouds that have gathered, have become the masters of the vast sky along with the bull (Indra) who is pleased by the wind's breeze.

sloka: kṛtadhṛti parivanditenoccakairgaṇapatibhirabhinnaromodgamaiḥ | tapasi kṛtaphale phalajyāyasī stutiriti jagade hareḥ sūnunā ||
translation: Consecrated by the throng of Ganapati's, whose hairs stand on end due to their uplifting worship, the sun declares that spiritual practice bearing fruit surpasses even eulogies to Lord Hari in this world.

sloka: śaraṇaṃ bhavantamatikāruṇikaṃ bhava bhaktigamyamadhigamya janāḥ | jitamṛtyavo'jita bhavanti bhaye sasurāsurasya jagataḥ śaraṇam ||
translation: Seekers of devotion come to you, the extremely compassionate one, who is accessible only through unwavering devotion. Conquerors of death, they become invincible in the face of all worldly fears, seeking refuge in you, O ruler of both asuras and devas in this universe.

sloka: vipadeti tāvadavasādakarī na ca kāmasaṃpadabhikāmayate | na namanti caikapuruṣaṃ puruṣāstava yāvadīśa na natiḥ kriyate ||
translation: As long as one, infatuated by desires, has not yet fallen into despair, they do not pay respect to a single person, nor does obeisance to the Lord take place.

sloka: saṃsevante dānaśīlā vimuktyai saṃpaśyanto janmaduḥkhaṃ pumāṃsaḥ | yanniḥsaṅgastvaṃ phalasyānatebhyastatkāruṇyaṃ kevalaṃ na svakāryam ||
translation: Cultivating generosity, people look beyond worldly existence, contemplating the suffering inherent in birth. That pure compassion, unattached to results, is not simply one's duty, but the highest good.

sloka: prāpyate yadiha dūramagatvā yatphalatyaparalokagatāya | tīrthamasti na bhavārṇavabāhyaṃ sārvakāmikamṛte bhavatastat ||
translation: Upon reaching here from afar, if [one] attains the fruit of going to another world, then surely there is a tirtha here, not external to the ocean of worldly desires, for the fulfillment of all desires in death.

sloka: vrajati śuci padaṃ tvayi prītimānpratihatamatireti ghorāṃ gatim | iyamanagha nimittaśaktiḥ parā tava varada na cittabhedaḥ kvacit ||
translation: Proceeding, pure one, toward your abode, filled with devotion, one overcomes the terrible fate of a disturbed mind, O sinkss one, by your power, O giver of boons, such that mind's division is never present.

sloka: dakṣiṇāṃ praṇatadakṣiṇa mūrtiṃ tattvataḥ śivakarīmaviditvā | rāgiṇāpi vihitā tava bhaktyā saṃsmṛtirbhava bhavatyabhavāya ||
translation: Upon recognizing the true form of the deity, which bows to the right and is auspicious, even one's passionate devotion towards it will lead to constant remembrance, even towards one's own destruction.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā dṛśyānyācaraṇīyāni vidhāya prekṣākārī yāti padaṃ muktamapāyaiḥ | samyagdṛṣṭistasya paraṃ paśyati yastvāṃ yaścopāste sādhu vidheyaṃ sa vidhatte ||
translation: Having seen the sightworthy objects, the observer, having established proper conduct, proceeds to liberation's path. For one who sees rightly, the beyond becomes visible; he who honors you appropriately, such a one should be ordained.

sloka: yuktāḥ svaśaktyā munayaḥ prajānāṃ hitopadeśairupakāravantaḥ | samucchinatsi tvamacintyadhāmā karmāṇyupetasya sudustarāṇi ||
translation: United in their own power, O sages, imparting instruction beneficial to people through apt comparisons, you break through the extremely difficult karmas of one who is absorbed in the incomprehensible realm.

sloka: saṃnibaddhamapahartumahāryaṃ bhūri durgatibhayaṃ bhuvanānām | adbhutākṛtimimāmatimāyastvaṃ bibharṣi karuṇāmaya māyām ||
translation: You, possessing a wonderfully mysterious maya, carry a greatly compassionate maya, capable of binding even the unattainable, causing fear to all living beings in this world, and releasing them from it.

sloka: na rāgi cetaḥ paramā vilāsitā vadhūḥ śarīre'sti na cāsti manmathaḥ | namaskriyā coṣasi dhāturityaho nisargadurbodhamidaṃ tavehitam ||
translation: The married woman does not find ultimate delight in the passionate one, nor does Manmatha (the god of love) exist in the body. Prostrations to you, O fire god, this natural and profound truth is your command.

sloka: tavottarīyaṃ karicarma sāṅgajaṃ jvalanmaṇiḥ sārasanaṃ mahānahiḥ | sragāsyapaṅktiḥ śavabhasma candanaṃ kalā himāṃśośca samaṃ cakāsati ||
translation: Your upper garment, closely resembling a blazing jewel, serves as armor; a row of beads, ashes, and sandalwood paste, all mixed together, looks the same.

sloka: avigrahasyāpyatulena hetunā sametabhinnadvayamūrti tiṣṭhataḥ | tavaiva nānyasya jagatsu dṛśyate viruddhaveṣābharaṇasya kāntatā ||
translation: The two forms, united by a balance equal to that of a balance scale, stand unshakable due to a certain cause that cannot be violated. Only your form is seen in the world, not that of another, to be incompatible with various decorations.

sloka: ātmalābhapariṇāmanirodhairbhūtasaṃgha iva na tvamupetaḥ | tena sarvabhuvanātiga loke nopamānamasi nāpyupameyaḥ ||
translation: Not attained by all beings in the world, nor can there be any comparison to you, who, like a gathered community, has mastered control over the transformations of your own self.

sloka: tvamantakaḥ sthāvarajaṅgamānāṃ tvayā jagatprāṇiti deviśam | tvaṃ yogināṃ hetuphale ruṇatsi tvaṃ kāraṇaṃ kāraṇakāraṇānām ||
translation: You, O Death, are the end for both mobile and immobile beings; you, O Goddess, are called the life force of the world. For yogis, you are the cause and effect; you are the cause of causes of all causes.

sloka: rakṣobhiḥ suramanujairditeḥ sutairvā yallokeṣvavikalamāptamādhipatyam | pāvinyāḥ śaraṇagatārtihāriṇena māhātmyaṃ bhava bhavate namaskriyāyāḥ ||
translation: The supremacy is attained by the justly ruling one, who is protected by powerful commanders, born from the sun's rays, in this world, who grants shelter to those who seek protection from distress. Salutations to such a noble being!

sloka: tarasā bhuvanāni yo bibharti dhvanati brahma yataḥ paraṃ pavitram | parito duritāni yaḥ punīte śiva tasmai pavanātmane namaste ||
translation: Salutations to that pure soul, who from the inner self, supports the existence of the worlds, produces the sacred vibrations of the Brahman, and purifies all the surrounding impurities.

sloka: bhavataḥ smaratāṃ sadāsane jayini brahmamaye niṣeduṣām | dahate bhavabījasaṃtatiṃ śikhine'nekaśikhāya te namaḥ ||
translation: To the victorious one, always seated at your own contemplative site, I bow to you, O many-rayed shining one, who burns away the continuation of worldly existence for those who remember you and contemplate on the brahman.

sloka: ābādhāmaraṇabhayārciṣā cirāya pluṣṭebhyo bhava mahatā bhavānalena | nirvāṇaṃ samupagamena yacchate te bījānāṃ prabhava namo'stu jīvanāya ||
translation: Salutations to the origin of seeds, who, by attaining liberation through the great flame that consumes old age, fear of death, and suffering, becomes worthy of respect.

sloka: yaḥ sarveṣāmāvarītā varīyān sarvairbhāvairnāvṛto'nādiniṣṭhaḥ | mārgātītāyendriyāṇāṃ namaste'vijñeyāya vyomarūpāya tasmai ||
translation: I bow to the one who is unattached, superior, and uninfluenced by all worldly behaviors; who has never had a beginning and is steadfast; beyond the senses, yet known as the form of vyoma (ether or space).

sloka: aṇīyase viśvavidhāriṇe namo namo'ntikasthāya namo davīyase | atītya vācāṃ manasāṃ ca gocaraṃ sthitāya te tatpataye namo namaḥ ||
translation: We bow again and again to the ruler of all creation, who is near yet beyond the reach of speech and mind, who transcends the limits of words and thoughts, and who is established as the ultimate goal.

sloka: asaṃvidānasya mameśa saṃvidāṃ titikṣituṃ duścaritaṃ tvamarhasi | virudhya mohātpunarabhyupeyuṣāṃ gatirbhavāneva durātmanāmapi ||
translation: For one who lacks self-awareness, it is not appropriate for you, O Lord, to endure their wicked deeds; even for those who, deluded by ego, try to regress to their former ways, there is still a path, albeit difficult, for such deeply mistaken souls.

sloka: āstikyaśuddhamavataḥ priyadharma dharmaṃ dharmātmajasya vihitāgasi śatruvarge | saṃprāpnuyāṃ vijayamīśa yayā samṛddhyā tāṃ bhūtanātha vibhutāṃ vitarāhaveṣu ||
translation: By being established in pure reverence for the sacred, a noble-born son will obtain victory, the power of supreme authority, and prosperity in battles through the very path that has been ordained for him by his personal dharma, one that is both dear and fundamental to him; furthermore, he will gain triumph over his enemies.

sloka: iti nigaditavantaṃ sūnumuccairmaghonaḥ praṇataśirasabhīśaḥ sādaraṃ sāntvayitvā | jvaladanalaparītaṃ raudramastraṃ dadhānaṃ dhanurupapadamasmai vedamabhyādideśa ||
translation: Having reverently honored and respectfully consoled his son, who had been thus admonished by Magha, then, taking up a flaming weapon, red like a tongue of fire, along with his bow and arrows, [the teacher] initiated the instruction of the Veda to him.

sloka: sa piṅgākṣaḥ śrīmānbhuvanamahanīyena mahasā tanuṃ bhīmāṃ bībhrattriguṇaparivārapraharaṇaḥ | parītyeśānaṃ triḥ stutibhirupagītaḥ suragaṇaiḥ sutaṃ pāṇḍorvīraṃ jaladamiva bhāsvānabhiyayau ||
translation: That Pingaksha, the illustrious one, endowed with threefold excellences and weapons, after paying homage to the supreme commander with threefold prayers, set out resembling a flashing cloud, like the son of Pandu, valiant and renowned.

sloka: atha śaśadharamaulerabhyanujñāmavāpya tridaśapatipurogāḥ pūrṇakāmāya tasmai | avitathaphalamāśīrvādamāropayanto vijayi vividhamastraṃ lokapālā viteruḥ ||
translation: Having received permission from the lord of the moon, the thirty gods, fulfilled in their desires, bestow on him varied invincible weapons, proclaiming unfailing rewards for the one who is worthy.

sloka: asaṃhāryotsāhaṃ jayinamudayaṃ prāpya tarasā dhuraṃ gurvīṃ voḍhuṃ sthitamanavasādāya jagataḥ | svadhāmnā lokānāṃ tamupari kṛtasthānamamarāstapolakṣmyā dīpaṃ dinakṛtamivoccairupajaguḥ ||
translation: Having quickly reached and inspired the unconquerable victor, I have established myself as a firm support for the world. With its own inherent nature, the earth has risen up to meet him, just like the sun's radiant light dispels darkness.

sloka: vraja jaya ripulokaṃ pādapadmānataḥ san gadita iti śivena śyādhito devasaṃghaiḥ | nijagṛhamatha gatvā sādaraṃ pāṇḍuputro dhṛtagurujayalakṣmīrdharmasūnuṃ nanāma ||
translation: Having heard the praise of Panduputra (Arjuna) from the assembly of gods, who has defeated the king of enemies from the lotus mouth of Shiva, he went home respectfully and named Dhritagurujayalakshmirdharmasoonu (a worthy son who has conquered his teacher's grace and wealth).
